for English Learner GATE and Special Ed Students CCTP and Early Education Common Core Technology Project Ad Hoc Committee Version Agenda am Closing Remarks Ms Mnica Ratliff Public Comment Persons who wish to address this committee may signup at the meeting Adjournment The Committee may consider and act upon motions Board Reports or other business referred to it by the Board of Education The Board of Education may also refer any item on this Order of Business for the consideration of a committee or meeting of the Board of Education Individuals wishing to speak at the Committee meeting must sign up at the meeting There will be no sign ups prior to the meeting Speaker forms will be available at the pillar at the rear of the Board Room Requests for disability related modifications or accommodations shall be made hours prior to the meeting to the Board Secretariat in person or by calling If you or your organization is seeking to influence an agreement policy site selection or any other LAUSD decision registration may be required under the Districts Lobbying Disclosure Code Please visit wwwlausdnetethics to determine if you need to register or call Materials related to an item on this Order of Business distributed to the Board of Education are available for public inspection at the Security Desk on the first floor of the Administrative Headquarters and at httpwwwlaschoolboardorgCCTP Items circulated after the initial distribution of materials are available for inspection at the Security Desk Common Core Technology Project Ad Hoc Committee Version percent up time over hour day the regular school day is a little higher maintenance during nonschool hours impacts the percentage of up time Top causes of network outages or delays over hours at schools Circuit down or equipment failures Router wireless controller core switch Sites outside of Phase that are CCTP wireless classroom ready sites schools Sites to be modernized by March An additional sites Sites to be modernized by June An additional sites LOS ANGELES UNIFIED SCHOOL DISTRICT Information Technology Questions Network bandwidth capacity CCTP schools vs Non CCTP schools a direct feedback loop for teachers and principals to provide us with ideas and requests for the kind of training teachers and parents need Teachers and principals are invited to send feedback at any time to cctplausdnet We have built a systematic process to collect feedback and data from principals and teachers regarding professional development activities at the end of every principal and teacher training The training facilitators and organizers review the survey data Here are sample questions from a recent CCTP principal meeting LOS ANGELES UNIFIED SCHOOL DISTRICT Curriculum and Instruction Questions When will the Pearson curriculum be completed at what point within the threeyear contract What is the specific time frame for what units of Math and ELA Pearson Curriculum will be completed at what point for Phase and Pearson curriculum is complete but LAUSD is only allowed access to the content according to the timeline promised in the contract Second semester curriculum will be available in January Full curriculum will be available in August Was the Pearson curriculum done when we signed the contract The ELA and K math curriculum was fully developed but it wasnt available in digital format for the iPad The California Department of Education reviewed and approved the K math curriculum this year which is available to the public as a nondigital version httpflipbookspearsonschoolcomcaliforniareviewccsoc_for_math LOS ANGELES UNIFIED SCHOOL DISTRICT Curriculum and Instruction Questions Can this committee or a group of teachers see the entire curriculum and say that theyve seen it so that we can lay this question to rest If the curriculum is complete why cant we see it now If not why not We made the request to Pearson Pearson will only make the curriculum available to us within the contract timeframe If we follow Dr Deasys idea of slowing this down to stay in Phase a little longer is Pearson matching our timeline or are they matching some other timeline Pearson content will be available based on the original contract The full content will be available in August At what point will the Pearson apps provide actual data so teachers know if the content is being mastered or not In Phase there will be assessments available through Schoolnet LOS ANGELES UNIFIED SCHOOL DISTRICT Curriculum and Instruction Questions When will we get the high school math curriculum August How often does the District replace curriculum The California Department of Education sets the calendar and cycle of adoption Historically the state has been on a to year adoption cycle for each subject How can we use bond funding on ecurriculum thats essentially a textbook Staff has worked with bond counsel and confirmed that the bond proceeds may be used for an instructional software license of a threeyear duration Which school staff will be assigned responsibility of managing the iPads at each school This is a school site decision Each school principal is asked to designate people per school such as an assistant principal technology coordinator teacher librarian etc LOS ANGELES UNIFIED SCHOOL DISTRICT Curriculum and Instruction Questions If a child is in kindergarten does heshe have access to only kindergarten content or is there an option of working above grade level Is it loaded on the iPad There are opportunities for enrichment in every lesson As with current adopted curriculum the intent is not to go ahead as with independent study but rather to go deeper within the grade level content How are we going to provide students with hard copies of instructional materials if a parent opts out of allowing the iPad to come home Pearson will provide printable PDF math homework exercise books for students to use at home if they cannot take the device home LOS ANGELES UNIFIED SCHOOL DISTRICT Curriculum and Instruction Questions Please provide the list of apps that were included on the iPads in Phase I in addition to the Pearson content Each iPad is preloaded with over education and productivity applications See CCTP PreLoaded Apps Handout for complete list Please provide a list of apps that teachers have added during Phase I as mentioned by Ms Lucas The following are examples of apps that teachers have downloaded Imagine Learning purchased by individual schools Edmodo CoachMyVideo Socrative ST Math purchased by individual schools Engrave Dropbox LOS ANGELES UNIFIED SCHOOL DISTRICT Curriculum and Instruction Questions What is the future plan for teachers being able to use apps they find on their own without having to wait months for District approval Also who will pay for them for the teachers iPad and if they need to be loaded on to each students iPad Presently teachers use professional judgment to acquire apps based on classroom and school site needs using an LAUSD specific Apple ID Apps may also be pushed through the MDM Payment is a school site decision unless the app is provided districtwide In that case funding would come from central What about parents who want to put either educational apps or apps that track usage on the iPad Will they be allowed to What is the process Who will pay for that This is a great questionsuggestion and the project team is now working to determining a process for providing parents with this ability If parents choose to purchase paid apps in addition to the preloaded or free apps they will be responsible for paying for these apps LOS ANGELES UNIFIED SCHOOL DISTRICT Curriculum and Instruction Questions What else can students do on the iPad Students will use all tools on the device to grow as creative collaborative critical thinkers who manage manipulate and produce knowledge The Pedagogy Wheel handout lists a variety of ways students and teachers may interact with the device All activities fit within the matrix of Blooms Cognitive Domains rememberunderstand apply analyze evaluate and create and the SAMR model substitution augmentation modification and redefinition Here are a few of the countless examples of how students may use apps in the classroom Students may collaborate and communicate with peers and instructors email blogs google docs LMS Students use this device as a research tool to acquire specific purposeful informationGoogle search Brain pop NASA Khan Academy Sid the Science Kid etc LOS ANGELES UNIFIED SCHOOL DISTRICT Curriculum and Instruction Questions What else can students do on the iPad contd Students use the device to record and demonstrate knowledge Pages Educreations Popplet Explain Everything etc Students and teachers use interactive whiteboards to assess learning midlesson Student work may also be saved for further evaluation Sketchbook Evernote Explain Everything Educreations Annotate and interact with a variety of digital formats including PDF photos Pages documents videoetc to demonstrate learning Evernote Teachers may share interactive content with students and monitor understanding through realtime quizzes nearpod LOS ANGELES UNIFIED SCHOOL DISTRICT Curriculum and Instruction Questions What else can students do on the iPad contd Synthesize and produce knowledge using creativity apps which allow drawing voice and video recording integration of various media formats etc iMovie iPhoto Garageband Videocasting Storyboards Keynote Collect and organize text iBooks Enhance mathematical understanding and problem solve using tools games and specific tutorials PickaPath GraphCalc Khan Academy Numbers LOS ANGELES UNIFIED SCHOOL DISTRICT Curriculum and Instruction Questions Which school staff will be assigned responsibility of managing the iPads at each school This is a school site decision Each school principal is asked to designate people per school such as an assistant principal technology coordinator teacher librarian etc Digital Library Compatibility Digital Library resources are webbased and compatible with multiple platforms Students and staff may access the DL from school without any login as long as they are on the Districts Internet Network Remote access with a Single SignOn went live as of Tuesday October The remote access link can be found in the Quick Links section of the Integrated Library Textbook Support Services ILTSS website wwwiltssorg Most resources on the Digital Library can be emailed or saved as a PDF Smartphone access for feebased websites depends on each website LOS ANGELES UNIFIED SCHOOL DISTRICT Digital Library Questions How many of the resources in the districts digital library are available when the iPad uses a wireless network besides LAUSD through general Internet access All resources are available Go through Safari to connect to the Internet From the ILTSS home page wwwiltssorg click on Digital Library Remote Access Enter SSO Access to all paid subscription sites There may be a few issues with a particular item requiring Adobe Flash but this is being worked on by the vendors The Digital Library Free Sites link works without special remote accessSSO needed LOS ANGELES UNIFIED SCHOOL DISTRICT Digital Library Questions Will the professional development include how to use the Destiny Library software to see what resources are available in a teachers school library that support specific Common Core Standards Integrated Library and Textbook Support Services ILTSS provides PD for Teacher Librarians TLs focused on CCSS and the role of the TL and library resources ILTSS also provides Destiny PD to schools who do not have a TL as time and resources allow Will iPad users be able to use the device to access the Destiny Library database and is there a shortcut on the iPad to Destiny Already available for the iPad ILTSS is working closely with ITD to make the app available via the Districts App Catalog The TLs already know about it and are spreading the word We are currently working on a Widget shortcut to be added to the App Catalog for the Digital Library LOS ANGELES UNIFIED SCHOOL DISTRICT Digital Library Questions How are librarians and librarian aides integrated into this digital library network and CCTP Teacher Librarians are credentialed teachers The focus of PD for Teacher Librarians has been on the Common Core and technology instructional resources such as the Digital Library and appropriate Apps to help Teacher Librarians better lead the Common Core efforts at their schools As teachers they teach students and colleagues how to use available resources When funding is available at the school site they also purchase appropriate resources to further enhance the materials available Library Aides are classified staff much like education and instructional aides They do not teach but they assist teachers and students How many books can be downloaded onto an iPad at one time within the available storage This varies based on how large the books are and how many other apps are installed on the device Some books may download chapters at a time which allows users to fit many more books onto a device than if they had to download the entire copy at one time LOS ANGELES UNIFIED SCHOOL DISTRICT Digital Library Questions Are we transitioning to eBooks that will be accessible for all students in the District If so how Is there money put aside ILTSS is actively researching such a possibility at the District level Unfortunately universal access to such a library is not yet available There currently is no funding set aside for such a library if appropriate access could be negotiated Further there is no funding identified for the renewal and expansion of the current Digital Library subscriptions Is the District going to work with the LA public library system to provide students with access to free digital resources ILTSS and the Los Angeles Public Library have already started sharing information ILTSS staff presented at a meeting of the Young Adult LAPL librarians with a focus on what resources and apps to support Common Core had been shared to date with the Districts Teacher Librarians There will be a joint meeting of both sets of librarians in March One of the LAPL librarians commented that the Districts Digital Library of subscription and free sites was richer than the LAPL one LOS ANGELES UNIFIED SCHOOL DISTRICT Testing Schedule for What is the testing schedulewhat month is the first test Which classes are going to take it first The SBAC Field Test window opens on March and closes on June but CDE is going to assign schools a shorter window within the entire set of days All LAUSD students in grades and along with a small sample of students in grades and will participate in the Field Test for both Math and ELA Administered online the Field Test will closely resemble the summative assessment that students will participate in during the spring of Because the Field Test is a test of the test students will not receive scores LOS ANGELES UNIFIED SCHOOL DISTRICT Safety and Students Responsibilities Please provide the full communication strategy around online bullying and hacking targeted for different levels The project will facilitate digital citizenship training for principals and leadership team members Leadership teams will facilitate this training at school sites District policy currently exists around bullying of any nature including cyber bullying see Bulletins and The CCTP instructional team is working with School Operations to align CCTP discipline issues to current district policies Instead of creating new discipline policies for issues related to CCTP we will leverage the existing policies and discipline matrix Please provide the revised the acceptable use policies The acceptable use policy has not been changed LOS ANGELES UNIFIED SCHOOL DISTRICT Safety and Students Responsibilities Please provide a copy of the new Progressive Discipline Plan Based on Ed Code requirements LAUSDs discipline plan see Bulletin applies to all student behaviors including use of technology The CCTP team is creating an intervention matrix and school memo to provide guidance to schools a draft will be ready in December Please provide the disciplinary action matrix referenced in the informative sent out by Mr Matt Hill and Mr Chandler dated September th After drafting a separate matrix the CCTP team determined that LAUSDs discipline plan applies to all student behaviors including use of technology What are the plans for what will be done with the iPads while kids are at afterschool activities and when theyre moving into a class where theyre not going to use the iPad where are they expected to store it If this is a local control issue what recommendations is the District giving This is determined locally because each campus school site grade level is slightly different and schools must find what works best for them Parent Education Questions What is the Districts plan in terms of parent education Parent training is provided by school staff Training focuses on the rationale for transition to CCSS shift in culture and expectations for students how use of technology supports improved student learning how parents can reinforce learning at home with the device digital and other resources for support apps websites school contact person Training will be provided by PCSB to District parent committees Parent Education Questions Please provide information on the needs assessment you are doing to see what PD parents need what questions are being asked where is it being done by whom etc We are customizing parent training for specific needs Parents want differentiated training based on needs of specific student by level elementary middle and high school other studentspecific needs Special Education English Learner gifted parent familiarity with technology parent familiarity with digital citizenship and internet safety We will convene a focus group of parents to provide feedback on Common Core Technology Plan and on training modules Schools will receive toolkits for conducting needs assessments and providing differentiated parent training Parent Responsibility Questions Please provide any information you have on what the school did that got to the percent of parents returning acknowledgement forms The principal and teachers were extremely proactive and communicative with their students and their families about the value of the program The school used a variety of outreach methods including ConnectEd written and online communication and inperson meetings Please clarify the parental acknowledgement form It still seems to indicate that parents can be held financially liable while District staff has stated orally that parents will not be financially responsible for lost or stolen Students and parents are only financially liable in the case of willful neglect 
LAUSD DEVICE PROCUREMENT SURVEY DEVICE Have you purchased a laptop or tablet device for student use What was the brand and model of the device purchased Did the device have WiFi capabilities How much random access memorystorage memory does the device have Did the device come with a case Did the device come with an extended or accidental protection warranty How long was the battery life Is the battery covered under the warranty Were there any spare or replacement devices included in the price if yes what is the ratio How long would it take to replace a defective or damaged device Did the device come with a charging or docking module Did you purchase these items separately Did the device include additional accessories eg keyboards headphoneearphones etc SOFTWARE Did the device come preinstalled with software If yes what software products were included Did you receive any curriculum software aligned to the Common Core Standards What topics and grade levels were provided curriculum software Who was the content provider What did you pay for the curriculum Is there a license fee If so how much per year are you paying Page of LAUSD DEVICE PROCUREMENT SURVEY TRAINING Was there professional training provided for the use of the device andor curriculum Was there training provided for all teachers or select personnel who are trainers Was this included in the pricing or did it cost an additional amount LOGISTICS How was the device delivered to the District school and students Were there additional charges for delivery FUNDING Was there any portion of the purchase made with bond funding If yes what percentage of the purchase was bond funded Did any costs involve or include infrastructure upgrades What was the method of procurement ie IFB RFP Sole Source or other Page of 
 
Jaime Aquino Deputy Superintendent of Instruction Los Angeles Unified School District S Beaudry Ave th floor Los Angeles CA November Jaime I have received your request for a full set of curriculum materials They are not yet available through the app store they will be available according to the timeline in the LAUSDAPPLE contract Mathematics curriculum Attached is the link to the full K CCSOC math curriculum that has been publicly available since July httpflipbookspearsonschoolcomcaliforniareviewccsoc_for_math This link comprises the student materials and course overviews for the K CCSOC math curriculum They are presented as screen shots and PDFs becauseas a digital curriculum designed for mobile device deliveryuntil the curriculum is through production and available for downloading in the Apple app store it is difficult to share except in this way In addition to the web link we will provide a flash drive with the formatted teacher content PDFs that was submitted to the CDE for the instructional materials adoption and which was requested by and acceptable to the CDE for their detailed review Apple will be able to provide more details on when the Phase materials are available for downloading through the app store English language arts The ELA curriculum is fully written but currently is in production These production processes include a variety of detailed steps including formatting and layout of content in the digital templates resolution of graphics for different aspect ratios captioning layer of videos QAQC testing of interactive elements etc Delivery Schedule Please note that all units for Phase are on schedule for delivery as per the LAUSDAPPLE contract which specifies the units and timeframes We realize that its frustrating to not be able to get the fully produced digital curriculum immediately and upon request but we developed the production schedule and delivery plan for LAUSD in conjunction with LAUSD back in July We believe that this schedule is consistent with your position stated in your first addendum March to your original RFP We believe that we have created this delivery plan both in collaboration with LAUSD and with integrity according to the terms outlined by LAUSD in its RFP and contracting process For future formal requests it would be best to work through APPLE Please let me know if theres anything more I can do to support LAUSDs efforts Sherry King Vice President of Programs Common Core System of Courses Legal information will go in this space for example registration numbers association numbers registration address banks details and any other information that may be legally required for your footer Bank Account Registration Address Long First Line Address Long Second Address City Post Code Reg Code

Revised to remove the limit on the number of speakers to the action item and to allow speakers minutes each BOARD OF EDUCATION OF THE CITY OF LOS ANGELES Governing Board of the Los Angeles Unified School District REVISED SPECIAL MEETING ORDER OF BUSINESS South Beaudry Avenue Board Room pm Tuesday January Roll Call Pledge of Allegiance Board Member Resolution for Action Dr Vladovic Filling of the Board of Education Vacancy Noticed Regular Board Meeting The Board may make an appointment or call for a special election to fill the vacancy in Board District The Board will receive input from as many speakers as wish to address the Board when the item is before the Board for action Speakers will be limited to minutes each Those individuals who wish to address the Board on this item should pull a speaker form from the slots located on the pillar in the rear of the Board Room Speakers will be heard in numerical order as indicated on the speaker form Board Member Resolution For Initial Announcement Ms Garcia Ms Galatzan Dr Vladovic Celebration of Black History Month Whereas Carter G Woodson a Harvardtrained historian like WEB Du Bois before him believed that truth would not be denied and that reason would prevail over prejudice and as a result announced Negro History Week in to raise the awareness of the contributions of African Americans Whereas The first event was celebrated during a week in February encompassing the birthdays of Abraham Lincoln and Frederick Douglas two key figures in the history of African Americans Whereas When this week was officially established in the Library of Congress National Archives and Records Administration National Endowment for the Humanities National Gallery of Art National Park Service Smithsonian Institution and United States Holocaust Memorial Museum joined in to pay official tribute to the generations of African Americans who struggled with adversity to achieve full citizenship in American society Whereas this year marks the th anniversary of Freedom Summer a voter registration project in Mississippi part of a larger effort by civil rights groups such as the Congress on Racial Equality CORE and the Student NonViolent Coordinating Committee SNCC to expand black voting in the South Bd of Ed Special Meeting revised Rev Order of Business pm Revised to remove the limit on the number of speakers to the action item and to allow speakers minutes each Whereas this year also marks the th anniversary of The Civil Rights Act of the nations benchmark civil rights legislation that prohibits discrimination on the basis of race color religion sex or national origin Passage of the Act ended the application of Jim Crow laws in which the Court held that racial segregation purported to be separate but equal was constitutional Whereas The Governing Board of the Los Angeles Unified School District stated that the academic performance of African American students which is among the four lowest academic performing groups gave demands for an urgent action by the Los Angeles Unified School District Whereas The District recognizes the importance of culturally relevant and historically accurate education in improving academic performance and has implemented the Academic English Mastery Program AEMP in several of its schools and Whereas Black History Month is an opportunity for all students and stakeholders to enrich their educational experience and to deepen their understanding of the role of African Americans in the development of the United States and the world now therefore be it Resolved That the Governing Board of the Los Angeles Unified School District recognizes February as Black History Month and be it finally Resolved That the Superintendent will work with all schools of the District to recognize and celebrate Black History Month through culturally relevant activities and through in depth discussions of historically relevant topics Adjournment Please note that the Board of Education may consider at this meeting any item referred from a Board Meeting five calendar days prior to this meeting Education Code b The Board of Education may also refer any item on this Order of Business for the consideration of a committee or meeting of the Board of Education Requests for disability related modifications or accommodations shall be made hours prior to the meeting to the Board Secretariat in person or by calling Individuals wishing to speak at a Board meeting must sign up at the meeting There will be no sign ups in advance of the meeting Speakers must sign up prior to the item being acted upon by the Board Speakers should plan to arrive early as items with no speakers may be acted on at the beginning of the meeting If you or your organization is seeking to influence an agreement policy site selection or any other LAUSD decision registration may be required under the Districts Lobbying Disclosure Code Please visit wwwlausdnetethics to determine if you need to register or call Materials related to an item on this Order of Business distributed to the Board of Education are available for public inspection at the Security Desk on the first floor of the Administrative Headquarters and at httplaschoolboardorgSpclBd Items circulated after the initial distribution of materials are available for inspection at the Security Desk Bd of Ed Special Meeting revised Rev Order of Business pm 
BOARD OF EDUCATION OF THE CITY OF LOS ANGELES GOVERNING BOARD OF THE LOS ANGELES UNIFIED SCHOOL DISTRICT BUDGET FACILITIES AND AUDIT COMMITTEE South Beaudry Avenue Board Room pm Thursday January External Representatives Mr Steve Martines AALA Representative Mr Luis Rojas AALA Representative Mr Tim Delia UTLA Representative Mr Joe Skala SEIU Representative Mr Stephen English BOC Representative Mr Scott Folsom PTSA Representative Committee Members Mr Bennett Kayser Chairperson Ms Mnica Ratliff Mr Steven Zimmer District Staff Mr Ken Bramlett Inspector General Ms Megan Reilly Chief Financial Officer Mr Mark Hovatter Chief Facilities Executive Mr Greg McNair Office of General Counsel Board Secretariat Contact Noemi Fernandez Tel Email noemifernandezlausdnet The meeting convened at pm NOTES OPENING REMARKS Mr Bennett Kayser Chair gave a brief description of the days items and introduced Mr Ken Bramlett OIG FISCAL YEAR ANNUAL WORK PLAN UPDATE Mr Ken Bramlett Inspector General reviewed the proposed work plan He said for the Internal Audit Unit there were specific areas to be covered He indicated that new areas are related to facilities and bond projects and are in other areas He also stated of the projects are carried over from the past year and are additions to the original work plan for a total of In his presentation he showed the specific areas and gave a brief description of each area He suggested the audit of the Title program be delayed until the Board Member vacancy in Board District is filled since so many Title I schools are in that District Mr Bramlett responded to questions from the Committee He said he would send the Committee additional information on the proposed School Trend Review in response to a question He was asked about follow up to previous audits to which he said that he asks his staff to review for each audit that has been completed since his arrival It was suggested that he do an audit of his audit recommendations to determine the effectiveness of his recommendations There were several questions and comments about the funding for the Inspector Generals Office and staffing Mr Bramlett said he would review all of the audits having correction action plans going back years for audits related to charter schools and years for all others He specifically mentioned that training is being prepared for principals related to Pcard and Imprest accounts at school sites Budget Facilities and Audit Committee Notes pm PUBLIC COMMENT The following speaker addressed the Committee on the Inspector General item Ms Kim Kaufman Common Core Technology Project TITLE I BUDGET OVERVIEW Ms Kathy Norris Deputy Budget Director said she was responding to the Committees previous request for an overview of the Title budget She first reviewed the purpose of Title and its origins She said the program was last reauthorized by Congress in She noted that funding to the District has dropped percent in the last two years due to sequestration and declining enrollment It is now predicted to be million for the school year Ms Norris said she would forward to the Committee the decline in per pupil funding Ms Norris discussed the CORE waiver that was received by the District and some other districts which gives the District flexibility with million and said this funding needs to be spent in specific areas Ms Deborah Ernst Director Federal and State Education Programs responded to a question about parent input in the expenditure of Title funds She said that the School Site Committee continues to provide oversight for Title expenditures at school sites She said that because of a change to state funding the Economic Impact Aid EIA funds were converted by the state to Local Control Funding Formula funds and no longer come under the designation of Title As such they do not come under the oversight of the School Site Committee Ms Ernst was asked to come forward at future meetings to discuss the effectiveness of Title programs Ms Norris was asked to detail the costs of administration of Title programs and the indirect costs She was also asked to provide the Committee with the amount of funding going directly to instruction and learning not just the money that goes to schools SCHOOL CONSTRUCTION BOND SCHOOL UPGRADE PROGRAM OVERVIEW Mr Mark Hovatter Chief Facilities Executive spoke about the school construction bond work done up to this point focused on school construction He said the program is now shifting to school modernization from new school construction The most recent bond Measure Q will concentrate on modernization He said the Board will have for action on Tuesday a report which recommends how the Measure Q and funds remaining from other measures be spent Mr Hovatter described past growth that caused overcrowding at school sites He stated that while billion was invested in constructing new schools in billion of additional capital needs was identified He said the School Upgrade Program establishes the framework to develop projects to upgrade repair and build school facilities The Board action will not authorize funding at this point but will define the project categories and the amounts reserved in each category Projects will be brought to the Board individually for approval He finished his presentation by asking for the opportunity to bring the prioritization plan for the project to a future Committee meeting Responding to questions from the Committee Mr Hovatter talked about the technology initiatives that have accelerated technology upgrades such as WiFi He also discussed the school cafeteria modernization program Mr Hovatter explained that about of the students current housed in temporary buildings will be accommodated in a permanent building as a result of this program He said that it would take about billion to build new buildings to replace all of the temporary buildings The issue of replacing all temporary buildings was asked to be discussed at future Committee meetings Budget Facilities and Audit Committee Notes pm CLOSING REMARKS Mr Kayser asked Ms Megan Reilly to briefly discuss the California budget proposal released by Governor Brown today She mentioned the hopeful economic proposals and said that there is a plan to pay down funds for past year that were withheld She said the District still would not have the equivalent annual amount that were received in but should receive enough to cover next years deficit The following speakers addressed the Committee on the subjects indicated PUBLIC COMMENT continued Mr David Serrano Mr Roy Cervantes California Charter School Assn Mr Tyler Baier Bright Star Schools Mr Roberto Fonseca Parent Ms Sonia Luchini Parent Ms Michelle Hope Walker One God Facilities charter school allocation Adequate school facilities Title and CORE Waiver Special Ed funding iPads laptops and Uniform Complaints Mr Kayser adjourned the meeting at pm ADJOURNMENT Budget Facilities and Audit Committee Notes Los Angeles Unified School District Local Control Accountability Plan Overview Edgar Zazueta Office of the Superintendent Los Angeles Unified School District Key Components of the Local Control Funding Formula LCFF Based on specific considerations Equity additional Resources for students with greater needs Lowincome students English Learners Foster Youth Local decisionmaking and stakeholder involvement Accountability Transparency Alignment of budgeting with accountability plans Local Control Funding Formula LCFF The District receives a Base Grant for every student The District receives a Supplemental Grant for every highneeds student The District receives a Concentration Grant for every highneeds student over total enrollment Supplemental Grant Concentraon Grant Supplemental Grant Base Grant Base Grant Base Grant Illustration of How LCFF Works Elementary District Concentration Threshold percent of enrollment Funding Each Student Generates Base K Rate K Adjustment ELLIFoster Supplement ELLIFoster ConcentraCon Total Student ELLI ELLI NonEL LI Legislative Requirements Expending supplemental and concentration funds To increase or improve services for English learners low income students and foster youth in proportion to the increase in funds apportioned on the basis of the number of unduplicated count of the students The LEA may use these funds for schoolwide or LEAwide purposes in manner that is not more restrictive than the restrictions provided for in Title of No Child Left Behind State Board of Education will adopt regulations by January Getting Informed LAUSD should ensure that its diverse communities are informed about the intent and the requirements of the law Specifically communities should understand The principles of LCFF equity local decisionmaking accountability transparency alignment The funding targets of LCFF The requirements for community involvement andor review requirements for planning and budgeting The process for review and adoption of the LCAP Local Control Accountability Plan LCAP Local Governing boards must adopt an LCAP by July utilizing a template issued by the SBE The adopted LCAP will be in effect for a year period and will be subject to updates on or before July st of each year Plans must be aligned to the LEA budget and shall include for the LEA and each school a description of Annual goals for all pupils and each subgroup to be achieved for each of the state priorities identified in statute and any additional local priorities Specific actions the LEA will take during each year to achieve the annual goals Specific action in the LCAP shall not supersede provisions in existing local bargaining agreements State Priority Areas to consider in the LCAP Student Achievement ImplementaCon of Common Core Standards School Climate Parental Involvement Basic Services Course Access Student Engagement State Priority Areas Other Student Outcomes Required Data for Priority Areas Student Achievement Performance on Standardized tests Score on API of College and Career Ready of ELs that are Reclassied of students with AP score of or higher of students determined prepared for college by EAP Student Engagement School aGendance rates Chronic absenteeism rates Middle school dropout rates High school dropout rates High school graduaon rates Other Student Outcomes Other indicators of student performance in required areas of study May include performance on other exams Parental Involvement Eorts to seek parent input Promoon of parental parcipaon Basic Services Rate of teacher misassignment Student access to standardsaligned instruconal material Facilies in good repair ImplementaCon of Common Core Implementaon of Common Core Standards for all students including EL Course Access Student access and enrollment in all required areas of study School Climate Student suspension rates Other measures student Expulsion rates Consult Districts Must Solicit Input from Various Stakeholders in the LCAP Stakeholders that should be consulted School employees Teachers Principals Administrators Classified Staff etc Parents SchoolSite and DistrictLevel committees Students Schoolsite and DistrictLevel committees Plan and Adopt Solicit wriWen comments from public Develop Proposed Plan Present proposed plan to Advisory commiWees Solicit comments and recommendaCons from public in a public hearing Respond in wriCng to comments of Parent Advisory CommiWees ConCnuously consult with Employees Parents and Students Adopt Plan in a Public Hearing Board adopts both the LEA Budget and LCAP concurrently QUESTIONS 
Presentaon to Early Childhood Educaon and Parent Engagement Ad Hoc Commiee January wwwlausdnet What must school districts do to comply with the law Funcon of the PAC and EL PAC The school district shall present the local control and accountability plan to the parent advisory commiee PAC and the English learner parent advisory commiee EL PAC for review and comment before it considers the adopon of the local control and accountability plan Educaon Code secon a What must school districts do to comply with the law How the PAC and EL PAC are to be Formed A parent advisory commiGee shall include parents or legal guardians of pupils to whom one or more of the denions in Secon apply [Educaon Code secon Denes three subgroups of students Eligible for free or reduced price meal Foster youth and English learner] What must school districts do to comply with the law EL PAC The governing board of a school district shall establish an English learner parent advisory commiGee if the enrollment of the school district includes at least percent English learners and the school district enrolls at least pupils who are English learners Educaon Code secon b This subdivision shall not require the governing board of the school district to establish a new English learner parent advisory commiGee if the governing board of the school district already has established a commiGee that meets the requirements of this subdivision Educaon Code secon b Parent Advisory Commiee Timeline ESC East CORE WaiverLCFF Stakeholder Meeng ESC East Saldivar Room pm Meeng with Foster Care Administrator Mary Lee regarding PAC representaon of foster guardians ECE and Parent Engagement Ad Hoc CommiGee Meeng Board Room pm Board Meeng ESC South CORE WaiverLCFF Stakeholder Meeng Banneker Special Educaon Center Expanding and Improving Californias Early Learning System Californias Early Learning System New policy framework aimed at improving Californias early learning system so that it serves more children in better programs and all children are ready for success in school poised to become momentous year for early learning Bolstered by powerful body of research increasing public support and a strong economy leaders at local state and national levels calling for greater investment in early learning The Latest Senate President pro Tempore Darrell Steinberg was joined by fellow senators SSPI Tom Torlakson and Elk Grove Police Chief Lehner at a press conference to announce a measure to provide California children one of the highest quality kindergarten readiness programs in the nation The legislation is known as the Kindergarten Readiness Act or SB Joint authors of the bill include Senators Beall Block de Len DeSaulnier Hancock Hill Lara Leno Liu and Wolk with Assemblymember Bonta as a coauthor Last month Assembly Speaker Prez also led the effort to include early learning in the Assembly Democrats Budget Blueprint Californias Early Childhood Education System TK for All Creating Greater Equity in School Readiness New Model Details Provides all year olds with highquality TK that meets the specific learning and development needs of children Combines the best quality standards from the current TK and State Preschool programs creating a model that best supports the needs of year olds and ensures sustainable gains in school performance Allows a mixed delivery system in which school districts and charter schools may contract with private TK providers who meet quality standards to build on the expertise and passion of the current providers Utilize the same funding formula that K grades useAverage Daily Attendance ADA with additional resources provided for lowincome English language learners and foster children No funds would be taken away from existing statecontracted child development system Allows existing federal and state preschool funds to be focused on additional early care and education programs for lowincome and year olds given them an added boost when they need it most Has a five year phase in starting in to allow ample time to expand services to all children whose parents wish to enroll them TK for All Higher Quality Programs for Our Children Standards would be based on Preschool Learning Foundations and aligned with Kindergarten Common Core Standards New TK Model Head Teacher Assoc Teacher Class Size TeacherChild Rao Length of Day Quality Standards Credenaled AA Degree to hours TK for All Five Year PhaseIn New TK model has five year phasein to allow districts and providers to expand access slowly teachers and associate teachers time to obtain their education and training and gradual implementation in line with improving state budget projections New TK Esmated Addional Year Olds Served Esmated Addional TK Funding Total million million million million million million is based on a esmated enrollment rate which is similar to the experience of other states with preschool for all such as Oklahoma Georgia and Florida TK for All New Opportunities for Teachers At end of the five year phasein head teachers would be required to hold credential and units in early childhood education At end of the five year phasein associate teachers would be required to hold an Associates degree and units in early childhood education Estimated new teaching positions and associate teaching positions would be created Compensation would be on par with K colleagues TK for All Funding is Feasible and Flexible Funding would be based on twosession model ampm which would allow a teacher and associate teacher to serve children per session Would create unique base ADA for TK and overall average funding would be about per child in each session TK would continue to be eligible for school facilities funding TK for All Expanded Fullday Services for Families Who Need It Most million of million previously spent on partday State Preschool for year olds would stay within child development system and fund fullday wraparound TK for lowincome children Local districts and providers could choose to extend TK to fullday by using wraparound State Preschool funding Local Control Funding Formula LCFF and Title I Developing a New California Strong Start Birth through Age Program Research shows a childs brains develop faster in first three years than at any other period in their life Recent Stanford University research found disparities in vocabulary and language already evident at months between infants from lower and higherincome families By months there is already a six month gap in skills critical to language development By age theres a twoyear gap Developing a New California Strong Start Birth through Age Program New California Strong Start program would create innovative comprehensive highquality program for our states most vulnerable young children Californias Proposed Strong Start Program Concept Through the new Strong Start and Head Start programs California could more than double number of year olds and infants and toddlers served This framework would combine partday and fullday State Preschool for year olds with General Child Care for infants and toddlers program Strong Start program would create nations first evidencebased comprehensive locally controlled birth through age program million of million previously spent on partday State Preschool will help fund new California Strong Start Californias Proposed Strong Start Program Comprehensive HighQuality Services Services could include o Full and partday State Preschool for year olds o Full and partday infant and toddler care o Family engagement and support o Voluntary home visitation o Nutrition and other health services o Early intervention o Early childhood mental health Californias Proposed Strong Start Program Comprehensive HighQuality Standards Over fiveyear period quality would be increased New program would be aligned with current quality improvement efforts such as Race to the TopEarly Learning Challenge and First Californias Child Signature Program Program model would be comprehensive and flexible to allow local communities to easily blend and braid with other programs such as First California and federal home visitation programs child care CalWORKs federal Early Head Start early childhood mental health and health programs The Impact on Children is Positive More Children Served in Better Programs All children receive one year in quality TK program All children living in poverty receive two years of quality kindergarten readiness Combines best quality standards from TK and State Preschool creating developmentally appropriate model to ensure sustainable gains in school performance More than twice as many lowincome infants and toddlers may receive comprehensive quality early learning program Questions THANK YOU Early Childhood Education and a Thriving LA Investing in Human Capital LAUSD ECE and Parent Engagement Ad Hoc Committee December John K Harris ECE Works Strategic Counsel PLC CDP Project Purpose The First LA Career Development Policy Project is focused on achieving policy goals to create longterm sustainable change for the ECE Workforce Promote polices that improve education training compensation retention of a high quality ECE workforce Advocating for Education All children deserve the opportunity for a fair start High quality ECE creates a foundation for school success An educated populace is key to prosperity UCLA Partnerships First LA UCLA Anderson Forecast Partnership Engage business leaders in the conversation around the relationship between education and long term economic competitiveness Highlight the role of quality ECE in workforce development Develop the Human Capital Index HCI Investing in Children Human Capital Index measures education attainment For each additional schooling year per capita Income per person Unemployment rate HCI today predicts economic prosperity in or years ECE is the most efficient and effective way to achieve growth and prosperity ECE is the foundation for Human Capital Heckman High quality ECE programs have rate of return compared to in the post WWII stock market Chicago ParentChild Centers Quality parent engagement programs are effective in producing longterm gains P alignment and Montgomery County A large urban school district success HCI drives the local Economy Good Jobs HighHCI Workers Tax Revenue Quality Schools LA has had slow growth in human capital LA has fallen behind Los Angeles Human Capital Index ranks out of the top US Metro Areas th th th th The gains are not enough LA has one of the lowest gains in HCI in the top metro areas LA has integrated a larger proportion of lowskilled immigrants than any other metro area A Tale of Cities in LA million people HCI best in the country Strong economy million people HCI worst in the country Lagging economy A Low HCI has prevented employment from bouncing back SF SV WLA CA Other LA UCLA Anderson Forecast Report Conclusions LAs economic recovery and human capital have been falling behind other major cities We see two communities in LA growing apart a rising LA leads the country in human capital while a falling LA comes in last We find that regions with high human capital will predict higher income level higher home value and higher employment while regions with low human capital predict just the opposite ECE is the most efcient and effective investment a city can make to improve human capital Cities can lead on ECE Mayors in San Antonio Boston Chicago New York and others have pushed for greater ECE opportunities in their cities If Los Angeles had the HCI of San Francisco personal income per capita would be higher Reframing Repositioning Investing in ECE and the ECE workforce Strengthens our human capital Is an economic development issue Helps businesses attract and retain todays workforce working parents Millennials Framing the issue through economics Engages business legislators civic leaders and researchers The Opportunity Find new ways to frame this issue and align with others Look for policy opportunities that may not be ECEbased but advance important goals Collaborate and offer a unified voice where possible strength in numbers Thank You Visit Us at wwweceworksorg Find us on Facebook wwwfacebookcomeceworks Twitter eceworks Contact us at wwweceworksorgcontact 
BOARD OF EDUCATION OF THE CITY OF LOS ANGELES Governing Board of the Los Angeles Unified School District EARLY CHILDHOOD EDUCATION AND PARENT ENGAGEMENT COMMITTEE South Beaudry Avenue Board Room pm Thursday January Committee Members Mr Bennett Kayser Chair Ms Mnica Ratliff District Staff Members Ms Maureen Diekmann Executive Director Early Childhood Education Division Ms Rowena Lagrosa Executive Director Parent Community Student Services Branch Board Secretariat Contact Noemi Fernandez Tel Email noemifernandezlausdnet The meeting convened at pm External Representatives Ms Kim Pattillo Brownson The Advancement Project Ms Araceli SandovalGonzalez Early Edge California Ms Candace Nafissi Los Angeles Chamber of Commerce Ms Tessa Charnofsky First LA Ms Sonja Luchini Community Advisory Committee Mr Lester Garcia SEIU Local Ms Wendy Peel Associated Administrators Los Angeles Ms Celia Ayala Los Angeles Universal Preschool Ms Robin Potash United Teachers Los Angeles Ms Jonna Harris th District Parent Teacher Association Ms Ana Carrion District English Learner Advisory Committee NOTES WELCOME INTRODUCTIONS VISION Each of the Committee members and representatives introduced themselves LOCAL CONTROL ACCOUNTABILITY PLAN REQUIREMENTS AND UPDATE Mr Bennett Kayser Chairperson introduced Mr Edgar Zazueta Director External Affairs opened the presentation of the Local Control Funding Formula LCFF and the Local Control Accountability Plan He briefly reviewed the past system of revenue limits and the categorical program funding He said in the past similar populations in different parts of the state could receive disparate amounts of funds for education Local flexibility and meeting student needs are accommodated with the new funding formulas Mr Zazueta explained that the funding would now have a base grant for every student a supplemental grant for students with specific needs and a concentration grant for students in Districts with highly concentrated populations of students who receive supplemental funding He said that the state requires that the District in partnership with parents create a threeyear plan for the expenditure of the funds from LCFF in the priority areas In response to the Committee questions Mr Zazueta said he was still analyzing Governor Browns budget proposal He said that the amount being dedicated to LCFF funding was increased from the original proposals Committee Representatives had several comments on the parent engagement plans Early Childhood Education and Parent Engagement Committee Notes pm A specific question of interest to the Committee prompted Mr Zazueta to comment on what he believed was the future for early education within the District ESTABLISHMENT OF THE LOCAL CONTROL FUNDING FORMULA PARENT ADVISORY COMMITTEE Ms Rowena Lagrosa Executive Director Parent Community Student Services Branch said the law requires the District form a Parent Advisory Committee and an English Learner Parent Advisory Committee She described how a single District committee will be formed to meet the requirement of the law by having individuals meeting the requirements specified will be chosen from each of the Educational Service Centers and additional individuals selected by each Board Member will form a member committee Ms Lagrosa said meetings to select parents for the Committee will begin in February following stakeholder meetings that have already begun UCLA ANDERSON FIRST LA CITY HUMAN CAPITAL INDEX CHCI Mr John Harris Strategic Counsel PLC said his company is working on the Career Development Policy for First LA The project is called ECE Works Early Childhood Education Mr Harris presented a video on the project which is designed to promote policies that improve education training compensation and retention of a high quality early childhood education workforce He said that First LA has formed a partnership with the UCLA Anderson Forecast which has a quarterly publication The goal is to engage business leaders in the relationship between education and longterm economic competitiveness The UCLA Anderson Forecast has created a Human Capital Index which shows that for each additional year of schooling the average person gains in annual income and the unemployment rate drops Additionally early childhood education programs have a rate of return for the investment dollar Early childhood education is the most efficient and effective way to achieve economic growth and prosperity Mr Harris and Mr Zazueta responded to comments from the Committee EXPANDING AND IMPROVING CALIFORNIAS EARLY LEARNING SYSTEM Mr Scott Moore Chief Policy Advisor Early Edge California said he believes there is momentum in Sacramento for early childhood education He said that Los Angeles is often at the forefront He said there are universal preschool advocates and transitional Kindergarten programs in the area and proposals for expanding transitional Kindergarten from of the eligible students to all students Mr Moore said there is a proposed measure to allow California to have the highest quality Kindergarten readiness program in the nation He said there would be Transitional Kindergarten for all students and a new program which would double the number of year olds and infants in programs in a new California Strong Start program This program would build on the Early Head Start program Mr Moore responded to questions and comments from the Committee Early Childhood Education and Parent Engagement Committee Notes pm The following speakers addressed the Committee on the subjects indicated PUBLIC COMMENT Mr Roberto Fonseca Parent Ms Maria Daisy Ortiz Parent Ms Michelle Hope Walker Parent Ms Jacquelyn Smith Conkelton Surrogate parent Parent Advisory Committee composition Parent Advisory Committee funding Parent participation on committees African American student representation Mr Kayser adjourned the meeting at pm ADJOURNMENT Early Childhood Education and Parent Engagement Committee Notes pm 
 
Options for Providing a Voice to Board District Presentation to the Board of Education Office of the General Counsel David R Holmquist General Counsel Background Board of Education Meeting Board voted to call for a special election for the Board District seat that was left vacant by the untimely death of Board Member Marguerite LaMotte Board asked the Office of the General Counsel to present potential options for providing a representative voice to Board District City Council Unanimously approved an ordinance that consolidates the special election approved by the Board of Education with the previously scheduled state primary election Board of Education Will receive presentation from the Office of General Counsel on available options per request made by the Board of Education at the January Board Meeting Voters of Board District Will vote to fill the school board vacancy Voters of Board District Will vote in a runoff election if necessary Office of the General Counsel Board VacancyPresentation to the Board of Education January Potential Options to Consider Current Board Members One Board member becomes an advocate for Board District Multiple Board members take on role of advocacy eg those whose Districts share a geographical boundary with District Committee Structure Advocate Board could convene a committee comprised of chairperson and committee members Board could select or establish a process for selecting an individual this person could potentially be aan Employee Contract employee Other Board members taking on responsibility would not receive an additional vote Advocate would serve as a nonvoting representative only NOTE This presentation is not intended be an exhaustive list of options because the options vary widely it is intended to provide guidelines and examples that will help Board Members design and implement a solution with the assistance of staff Office of the General Counsel Board VacancyPresentation to the Board of Education compensation Spend discretionary funds Initiate project scope for Facilities projects Initiate ribbon cutting activities Initiate naming of new schools Ethics Subject to the Districts Code of Ethics closed session items Access to attorneyclient privileged documents OIG investigations Hiring decisions eg hirefire staff Potential Option Current Board Members Committee Advocate Yes Yes NO Advisory employee NO unless employee NO unless employee NO unless employee Board members taking on responsibility would not receive an additional vote An employee or authorized representative may attend closed session if they are necessary to assist the Board in making a decision Office of the General Counsel Board VacancyPresentation to the Board of Education January Questions Office of the General Counsel Board VacancyPresentation to the Board of Education January Appendix Office of the General Counsel Board VacancyPresentation to the Board of Education January Overview of the Law Section Overview California Education Code California Constitution Article IX Education Section Midterm school trustee vacancies in California school districts are usually filled pursuant to provisions of the California Education Code Where all or a part of a school district is within the borders of a charter city the city charter may provide for the manner of election and appointment of board members and for their qualifications compensation removal and for the number constituting such board It shall be competent in all charters framed under the authority given by section of Article IX to providethe manner in which the time at which and the terms for which the members of boards of education shall be elected or appointed Article IX section a California Education Code Provides that section and other related statutes do not apply where a city charter addresses school board elections and vacancies unless the charter so provides or the charter fails to provide for any or all of the matters specified in the statutes Section provides in pertinent part Any unified school district that is coterminous within or includes within it boundaries a chartered city Shall be governed by the board of education provided for in the charter Section[] shall not apply to such unified school districts except as follows a As provided for in the charter of the city b if the charter of the city fails to provide for any or all of the matters specified in Section[] [that section] shall apply as to the matter not provided for in the charter Office of the General Counsel Board VacancyPresentation to the Board of Education January Overview of the Law contd Section Overview Los Angeles City Charter Article IVElections Sections Los Angeles City Charter Article IV Section The Los Angeles City Charter makes specific provision for election of Los Angeles Unified School District Board Members Specifically addresses the filling of midterm school board vacancies Addresses vacancies by providing two options allowing the Board to fill a vacancy by appointment or by special election but not both appointment and election the preamble for Section provides explicitly that the Board must choose either appointment or election Vacancies in the office of Members of the Board of Education shall be filled by either appointment or election in the manner set forth in this section The City of Los Angeles is a charter city The Board has called for an election as a result there cannot be an interim appointment of a voting Board Member to fill the vacant District seat This conclusion reached by the Office of the General Counsel has been confirmed by outside counsel and the City Attorney for the City of Los Angeles Office of the General Counsel Board VacancyPresentation to the Board of Education January

OfficeDivision Telephone No Office of the Deputy Superintendent of Instruction BOARD REPORT Action Proposed Staff proposes that the Board of Education amend the Information Technology Division ITD Strategic Execution Plan SEP to update the Common Core Technology Project CCTP also known as Project and take the following actions cid Add schools to the Project as follows cid schools Phase schools as shown in Attachment B cid Upto seven infrastructureready high schools Phase L cid All nonPhase and Phase District K schools including all charter schools located on District campuses cid Purchase and equip Project schools as follows cid Phase schools with approximately iPads of which are for students including for magnet center students and the remaining for schoolbased certificated staff including for magnet center certificated staff as described in Attachment B cid Phase and schools and Phase magnet centers with approximately physical keyboards for all grade students and half of the students in kindergarten and st grade The approach to provide Phase schools with keyboards in conjunction with the Phase authorization was contemplated at the inception of the Project Page of Board of Education December Bd of Ed Rpt No LOS ANGELES UNIFIED SCHOOL DISTRICT Board of Education Report cid Phase schools and Phase magnet centers with approximately storagecharging carts cid NonPhase and schools with storagecharging carts stocked with tablet devices and physical keyboards necessary to successfully conduct the Smarter Balanced Assessment Consortium field testing next Spring Based on the number of students required to take the four separate assessments staff estimates the total nottoexceed number of storagecharging carts to be purchased to be approximately consisting of iPads and physical keyboards of each per cart At the conclusion of the school site surveys the number of stocked storagecharging carts needed at each site as described in Attachment C will be adjusted accordingly An informative detailing the results of the school site surveys will be provided upon completion cid Phase L schools with approximately laptop computers of which are for students including for magnet center students and the remaining for schoolbased certificated staff including for magnet center certificated staff It is intended that each laptop computer will be equipped with preloaded content and software through subsequent procurements cid Authorize staff to execute all instruments necessary to implement approved Phases and project scopes for the CCTP including procurement actions under Public Contract Code sections andor where appropriate for the purchase of laptop computers keyboards and accessories The delegated authority authorized for the Apple Inc contract for CCTP on June will be exercised to meet the capacity needs described in this Board Report The proposed actions will enable the District to comply with the Board of Educations directive to implement a second phase of the CCTP advancing efforts to modernize classrooms to prepare students to master Common Core State Standards and proficient use of digital learning technology equip educators with tools to advance student learning in the classroom and further close the digital divide between those students who have and do not have access to the most advanced learning tools available Background Bd of Ed Rpt No Page of Board of Education December LOS ANGELES UNIFIED SCHOOL DISTRICT Board of Education Report These actions will also enable the District to evaluate and analyze the impact of deploying multiple classes of classroom technologies thereby increasing understanding of how to modernize classrooms to maximize student potential for learning in the most efficient and cost effective way possible Several factors drove the selection of schools included in Phases L and including but not limited to further meeting the Districts obligations to commit to equity and access as mandated by the Office for Civil Rights OCR consent agreement the need to understand the impact of classroom technology modernization among a wider spectrum of lower and higher performing schools and the need to prepare for a technologyenabled learning environment that can accommodate a wide range of different devices Expected Outcomes Approval of the proposed actions and the subsequent investment in the CCTP will begin immediately upon approval Board Options and Consequences Approval of this action will enable implementation of Phases L and and other project scopes for CCTP Failure to approve the proposed actions will restrict the CCTP to Phase schools and may limit the ability of all schools including Phase schools to participate effectively in the Smarter Balanced Assessment Consortium field testing next Spring Policy Implications This action is consistent with the Districts longterm goal to address unmet school facilities needs as described in Measures R Y and Q Budget Impact The estimated total investment for the proposed actions is This project is being undertaken as part of the School Upgrade Program SUP and as such will be funded with Bond Program Funds allocated to the Common Core Technology Project Category of Need identified in the SUP Spending Targets In addition to the investment of capital funds necessary for this project there is an estimated General Fund impact of for Phase and In addition Bond Counsel is reviewing the CCTP to determine what additional Phase IL and General Fund impacts will be incurred in details of these estimates are included in Attachment D Bond Oversight Committee Recommendations This item was considered by the School Construction Bond Citizens Oversight Committee BOC at its meeting of November The BOCs adopted resolution including the vote of the Committee is included as an attachment Bd of Ed Rpt No Page of Board of Education December LOS ANGELES UNIFIED SCHOOL DISTRICT Board of Education Report Staff has concluded that this proposed ITDSEP amendment will facilitate implementation of the SEP and therefore it will not adversely affect the Districts ability to successfully complete the SEP Attachments cid Common Core Technology December INTEROFFICE CORRESPONDENCE Los Angeles Unified School District Office of the Superintendent TO Members Board of Education FROM Dr John E Deasy Superintendent INFORMATIVE DATE November SUBJECT UPDATE TO THE COMMON CORE TECHNOLOGY PROJECT PHASES L AND PROPOSAL At the December Board of Education meeting staff is scheduled to present for action a proposal to update Common Core Technology Project CCTP with Phases L and This informative summarizes the Initial Proposal for Phases L and the Bond Citizens Oversight Committees BOC response and the revised proposal for action on December th Initial Proposal The initial proposal developed as a result of the Student Success Through an EvaluationBased Common Core Technology Project Resolution adopted last week recommended Phases L and be defined as follows Purchase and equip cid schools with tablet devices including preloaded content protective case and warranties for all students cid Phase and schools with physical keyboards for all grade students and half of the students in kindergarten and st grade cid All nonPhase schools with tablet devices including preloaded content and software a protective case and warranties for all schoolbased certificated staff including teachers administrators and other appropriate staff cid Remaining nonPhase and schools with storagecharging carts stocked with tablet devices and physical keyboards as needed to enable full participation in Spring Smarter Balanced Assessment Consortium field testing cid Upto seven nonPhase or high schools with laptop devices including associated content software and equipment for all students and all schoolbased certificated staff including teachers administrators and other appropriate staff Under this initial proposal the District would procure approximately cid additional iPads cid for all students at Phase schools cid for all schoolbased administrators including teachers and other certificated staff at all nonPhase schools cid as part of the storagecharging carts to be provided to nonPhase and schools cid physical keyboards cid for use by students at Phase and schools cid as part of the storagecharging carts to be provided to nonPhase and schools cid additional storagecharging carts cid laptops cid for all students at Phase L schools cid for all schoolbased certificated staff at Phase L schools Members Board of Education November BOC Recommendations Earlier this week staff presented this proposal to the BOC for its consideration After much discussion the BOC adopted a Resolution attached which made certain recommendations about Phases L and of the CCTP Specifically the BOC Resolution recommends that the Board approve cid cid the purchase and equipping of schools with tablet devices for all students and schoolbased certificated staff the plan to purchase and equip upto seven nonPhase and high schools with laptops including associated software and equipment for all students and schoolbased certificated staff including teachers administrators and other appropriate staff On all other items the BOC recommends that the Board direct staff to return at a later date with additional information and a new proposal for consideration I have reviewed the BOCs Resolution and discussed yesterdays meeting at length with senior leadership and the CCTP team Given the significant concerns raised regarding the equipping of schools with tablet devices for schoolbased certificated staff prior to the completion of the evaluation process staff is revising the proposal to eliminate this element I understand that the BOC also raised concerns about the purchase of storagecharging carts at non Phase and schools However I believe it is imperative that all of our students are prepared and able to participate in this important testing next spring Therefore staffs revised proposal continues to include a recommendation to purchase and equip nonPhase and schools with storagecharging carts stocked with tablet devices and keyboards Please be advised that on November State Superintendent Tom Torlakson announced that ninetyfive percent of students will take a sampling of both ELA and mathematics items plus one performance task for one subject The remaining five percent of students will take either ELA or mathematics items plus one performance task for either subject See attached letter from Superintendent Torlakson The BOCs recommendation to proceed without the purchase of carts was not based on an assumption that testing was unnecessary or undesirable rather the BOC was concerned that the proposed number of carts to be purchased exceeded the minimum necessary for testing Please note that staffs proposed cart purchase estimates are a nottoexceed estimate Staff will continue to work diligently to purchase only the number of carts necessary to successfully conduct testing An informative will be provided with the results of the school site surveys which will serve as the basis to determine the actual number of stocked storagecharging carts needed at each site This informative will be provided in advance of the purchase Finally to ensure Phase and schools are similarly equipped for the Spring testing staff continues to recommend purchasing keyboards for these schools This is consistent with our approach since the inception of Phase Members Board of Education November Revised Proposal Note Magnet Centers at Phase schools were inadvertently left out of the initial proposal and have been included in the revised proposal Under the revised proposal if approved by the Board the District would procure approximately cid additional iPads cid for all students at Phase schools cid for all students at Phase magnet centers cid for all schoolbased certificated staff at Phase schools cid for all schoolbased certificated staff at Phase magnet centers cid as part of the storagecharging carts to be provided to nonPhase and schools cid physical keyboards cid for use by students at Phase and schools cid for use by students at Phase magnet centers cid as part of the storagecharging carts to be provided to nonPhase and schools cid additional storagecharging carts cid for Phase schools including magnet centers cid storagecharging carts for nonPhase schools cid laptops cid for all students at Phase L schools cid for all students at Phase L magnet centers cid for all
