cidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcid GARR ACADEMY OF MATHEMATICS AND ENTREPRENEURIAL STUDIES GAMES CHARTER SCHOOL FACTS IN SUPPORT OF REVOCATION DECEMBER LEGAL AUTHORITY California Education Code sections c through k govern revocation of charter schools State regulations also outline the charter revocation process under Title of the California Code of Regulations sections et seq Pursuant to Education Code section c the authorizing entity may revoke the charter of a charter school if it finds through a showing of substantial evidence that the charter school did any of the following A Committed a material violation of any of the conditions standards or procedures set forth in the charter B Failed to meet or pursue any of the pupil outcomes identified in the charter C Failed to meet generally accepted accounting principles or engaged in fiscal mismanagement D Violated any provision of law c The authority that granted the charter shall consider increases in pupil academic achievement for all groups of pupils served by the charter school as the most important factor in determining whether to revoke a charter d Requires the authorizing entity to notify the charter school in writing of any violation and give the charter school a reasonable opportunity to remedy the violation prior to revocation e Prior to revoking a charter for failure to remedy a violation pursuant to subdivision d and after expiration of the schools reasonable opportunity to remedy without successfully remedying the violation the chartering authority shall provide a written notice of intent to revoke and notice of facts in support of the revocation to the charter school No later than days after providing the notice of intent to revoke a charter the chartering authority shall hold a public hearing in the normal course of business on the issue of whether evidence exists to revoke the charter No later than days after the public hearing the chartering authority shall issue a final decision to revoke or decline to revoke the charter unless the chartering authority and the charter school agree to extend the issuance of the decision by an additional days The chartering authority shall not revoke a charter unless it makes written factual findings supported by substantial evidence specific to the charter school that support its findings Substantial evidence has been defined as relevant evidence that a reasonable mind might accept as adequate to support a conclusion Hosford v State Personnel Bd CalAppd quoting Gubser v Department of Employment CalAppd and case law states [e]vidence is substantial if any reasonable trier of fact could have GAMES Charter School Facts in Support of Revocation Page of considered it reasonable credible and of solid value Kearl v Board of Medical Quality Assurance CalAppd PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND At a public hearing held on August the Los Angeles Unified School District Board of Education Board of Education authorized District staff to issue the Notice of Violations to Garr Academy of Mathematics and Entrepreneurial Studies Charter School GAMES or charter school providing the charter school with a reasonable opportunity to remedy the violations The Notice of Violations outlined the grounds for revocation based on Violations Of Law Students Due Process Rights Ralph M Brown Act California Public Records Act Conflict Of Interest Laws Ed Code cD Fiscal Mismanagement SelfDealing And Misappropriation Of Public Funds Failure To Maintain Fiscal Records Ed Code cC Violation of Material Provisions of its Charter Element Governance Element Suspension and Expulsion Procedures Ed Code c A Concerns Regarding General Capacity To Operate Charter School See Exhibit LAUSD Board of Education Report Approval of the Issuance of Notice of Violations for Garr Academy of Mathematics and Entrepreneurial Studies Pursuant to Education Code Sections c and d and stamped board approval August LAUSD evaluated GAMES response and on October issued a reply outlining areas of additional remedial actions required On October GAMES Board President replied agreeing to some but not all of LAUSDs additional remedial actions LAUSD staff determined that GAMES failed to refute the violations and did not provide sufficient remedies or proposed plans in response to the violations However taking into consideration GAMES pupil academic achievement LAUSD proposed under a Memorandum of Understanding MOU to conditionally suspend the revocation process if GAMES agrees to all the remedial actions including specifically that it transitions to a new governing board with new board members by July On November the LAUSD Board of Education held a public hearing and approved the conditional suspension of GAMES revocation process on the condition that GAMES signs and executes the Districts proposed MOU outlining all corrective actions taken including the replacement of the governing board by July The Board of Education also approved the issuance of the Notice of Intent to Revoke and Notice of Facts in Support of Revocation See Exhibit LAUSD Board of Education Report Approval of the Conditional Suspension of the Revocation Process and Approval of Issuance of Notice of Intent to Revoke and Adoption of Notice of Facts in Support of Revocation for Garr Academy of Mathematics and Entrepreneurial GAMES Charter School Facts in Support of Revocation Page of Studies Pursuant to Education Code Section e and stamped board approval November GAMES Board President and legal counsel were present and addressed the Board of Education requesting that the Board reject staff recommendation to issue the conditional suspension and Notice of Intent to Revoke GAMES submitted a letter to the Board of Education stating its reasons why it does not agree with the Districts request to replace the GAMES governing board The Notice of Intent to Revoke and Notice of Facts in Support of Revocation along with the November board report were served via certified mail and email to GAMES and its governing board on November notifying the charter school that the revocation hearing will be held on December at the LAUSD Board of Education Board Room See Attachment F Service was also made to legal counsel via email on November FINDINGS OF FACT IN SUPPORT OF REVOCATION Substantial evidence exists to support a finding that GAMES charter should be revoked on the following grounds Violations Of Law Students Due Process Rights Ralph M Brown Act California Public Records Act Conflict Of Interest Laws Ed Code cD Fiscal Mismanagement SelfDealing And Misappropriation Of Public Funds Failure To Maintain Fiscal Records Ed Code cC Violation of Material Provisions of its Charter Element Governance Element Suspension and Expulsion Procedures Ed Code c A Concerns Regarding General Capacity To Operate Charter School The District hereby incorporates all the evidence presented to the LAUSD Board of Education throughout the revocation process The following documents are attached hereto to support a finding that substantial evidence exists to revoke GAMES charter Attachment A LAUSD Notice of Violations with exhibits dated August Attachment B GAMES Response and Exhibits dated September Attachment C LAUSD Charter Schools Division Reply to GAMES Response dated October Attachment D GAMES Supplemental Response dated October Attachment E GAMES Letter to LAUSD Board of Education submitted November Attachment F Notice of Intent to Revoke and Notice of Facts in Support of Revocation for purposes of this attachment exhibits are excluded exhibits are duplicative of Attachments AD above which were part of the documentation for the Notice of Intent to Revoke Letter GAMES Charter School Facts in Support of Revocation Page of to GAMES serving Notice of Intent to Revoke and Notice of Facts in Support of Revocation with attachments November Based on the above evidence and documentation attached and incorporated hereto GAMES has committed and failed to remedy the following grounds for revocation The below written findings are the same written findings contained in the Notice of Intent to Revoke and Notice of Facts in Support of Revocation issued by the Board of Education on November and served on GAMES I VIOLATIONS OF LAW STUDENTS DUE PROCESS RIGHTS RALPH M BROWN ACT CALIFORNIA PUBLIC RECORDS ACT CONFLICT OF INTEREST LAWS ED CODE CD A Violation of Students Due Process Rights At the GAMES Board meeting on March which was attended and observed by the CSD assigned administrator the Board had added to the agenda and discussed an incident that had occurred the same day involving two students At that same meeting the Board voted to expel one of the students Although the parent was provided a Notice of Suspension that suspended the student for two days the school failed to provide the parent or student with notice of the expulsion recommendation or an opportunity to be heard by the Board In response to a CSD Notice to Cure issued April the school denies that the Board expelled the student but rather asserts that the Board only discussed the expulsion recommendation and that the parent disenrolled the student on or about the following day Under Education Code section which GAMES charter indicates it follows if a pupil is expelled from a public school the pupil or pupils parent may appeal the decision and shall be entitled to a hearing to determine whether the pupil should be expelled The hearing shall be held within schooldays and before a hearing officer or impartial administrative panel Any classification of public schools students which affects the fundamental interest of the student in education must be examined under state constitutional provisions with that strict and searching scrutiny appropriate to such a case Serrano v Priest Cald see also Butt v State of California Cal th Since charter schools are public schools charter school students have the same constitutionally grounded fundamental interest in education as all public school students Expulsion affects a students fundamental interest in education therefore charter school students facing expulsion are entitled to constitutional due process protection Cal Const art I subd a EVIDENCE Attachment A NOTICE OF VIOLATIONS Exhibit March Notice of Suspension Exhibit Correspondence from parent Exhibit May letter from GAMES to CSD Exhibit Declaration of Ruben Diaz Specialist Administrator see also Attachment F Notice of Intent to Revoke and Notice of Facts in Support of Revocation GAMES Charter School Facts in Support of Revocation Page of GAMES Response GAMES responded that while the alleged violation unquestionably did not occur the Charter School nevertheless acknowledges that it can improve its processes around student suspension and expulsion GAMES proposed the following remedial actions cid Strict Compliance with Charter Policy and Procedures to Ensure Due Process The GAMES Board and administrators will carefully follow the GAMES Charter Element in any future suspension andor expulsion proceedings cid SuspensionExpulsion Training Will Be Provided to the Board and Administrators The Law Offices of Young Minney Corr LLP will provide a mandatory training to the Board and to all School administrators who handle student discipline matters to ensure that there is a thorough understanding of the appropriate due process required by law and under the GAMES charter and policy The GAMES Board voted on September to hold this training during its regular Board meeting on October cid Letter to Parent Regarding Lack of Commencement of Expulsion Process The Charter School will send a letter no later than September to the change to the posted Board agenda for its meeting on March Notably the agenda was changed to include the expulsion matter described above The above action violated the Brown Acts requirement to post an agenda containing a brief general description of each item of business to be transacted or discussed at the meeting including items to be discussed in closed session at least hours before a regular meeting Cal Govt Code Section a Further the Brown Act prohibits action or discussion on any item not appearing on the posted agenda Cal Govt Code Section a No legal exceptions applied which would have allowed the GAMES board to take action on the expulsion item which was not on the posted agenda item Cal Govt Code Section b EVIDENCE Attachment A Notice of Violations Exhibit March GAMES Board Interest Violations GAMES paid in to Ms Wanda Briscoe thenBoard president and current Board president as a fundraising consultant Under conflict of interest laws applicable to public entities and public officials the Board President as a public official had a direct financial interest in the financial transaction which paid her fees as a fundraising consultant California Government Code Section prohibits a public official from being financially interested in a contract or sale in both his or her public and private capacities Thomson v Call Cal d stating the purpose of section is to make certain that every public officer be guided solely by the public interest rather than by personal interest when dealing with contracts in an official capacity EVIDENCE Attachment A NOTICE OF their Supplemental Response of October B Expulsion Procedures Element As stated above under Violations of Law a pupil was expelled without proper notice and a hearing in violation of the students due process Furthermore the Boards action violated the following provisions of the charter cid GAMES shall provide due process for all students including adequate notice to parentsguardians and students regarding the grounds for suspension and expulsion and their due process rights regarding suspension and expulsion including rights to appeal cid A student recommended for expulsion is entitled to a hearing if requested by the parent or guardian to determine whether the student should be expelled The student will continue to be suspended during the expulsion process The hearing shall be held in a timely manner if requested not to exceed days after the Principal or designee GAMES Charter School Facts in Support of Revocation Page of determines that one of the acts listed under Grounds for Suspension and Expulsion has occurred The hearing will continue to be presided over by the Board of Directors Written notice of the hearing shall be forwarded to the student and the students parentguardian at least ten days before the date of the hearing by the principal or his designee The notice shall include cid The date and place of the hearing cid A statement of the specific facts charges and offenses upon which the proposed expulsion is based cid A copy of the GAMES student discipline guidelines andor grounds for suspension and expulsion which relate to the alleged violation cid The opportunity for the student or the students parentguardian to appear in person or to employ and be represented by counsel cid The right to inspect and obtain copies of all documents to be used at the hearing cid The opportunity to confront and question all witnesses who testify at the hearing cid The opportunity to question all evidence presented and to present oral and documentary evidence on the students behalf including witnesses cid Expulsion Procedures Students recommended for expulsion are entitled to a hearing before the Board to determine whether the student should be expelled The expulsion panel consists of board members and an administrator not involved in the behavior determination The hearing shall be held within thirty school days after the Principal or designee determines that the student has committed an expellable offense Pending the expulsion hearing the school will ensure that the students and their families receive classroom materials and current assignments cid The Expulsion Board Members will conduct the expulsion hearing The hearing will be held in closed session unless the student makes a written request for a public hearing three days prior to the hearing cid Written notice of the student and the hearing shall be forwarded parentguardian at least ten days before the hearing date The notice shall include o The date and place of the hearing A statement of the specific facts charges to and offenses upon which the proposed expulsion is based o A copy of the schools disciplinary rules which relate to the alleged violation Notification of the students parentguardian obligation to provide information about the students status at the school to any other school district or school to which the student seeks enrollment o The opportunity for the student to appear in person or to employ and be represented by counsel or a nonattorney advisor o The right to inspect and obtain copies of all documents to be used at the hearing o The opportunity to question all witnesses who testify at the hearing o The opportunity to question all evidence presented and to present oral and documentary evidence on the students behalf including witnesses o Written Notice to Expel GAMES Charter School Facts in Support of Revocation Page of cid The Principal or designee shall send written notice of the decisions to expel to the student or parentguardian within days of the decision This notice shall include the following o The specific offense committed by the student for any of the acts listed in Grounds for Suspension and Expulsion above o Notice of the students or parentguardian obligation to inform any new district in which the student may attend the students current status with GAMES o Notice of the right to appeal the expulsion to the full Board of Directors of GAMES The expulsion panel is made up of select Board members and the Principal Notice of the students or parentguardians obligation to inform any new district in which the student seeks to enroll of the students status with GAMES o The reinstatement eligibility review date o A copy of the rehabilitation plan o Type of educational placement during the period of expulsion EVIDENCE Attachment A NOTICE OF VIOLATIONS Exhibit GAMES Charter Petition pp see also Attachment F Notice of Intent to Revoke and Notice of Facts in Support of Revocation GAMES Response cid This alleged violation contains only language from the GAMES charter petition The Charter School believes that it has responded to the substance of the alleged violation above in response Supplemental Response of October IV CONCERN REGARDING GENERAL CAPACITY TO OPERATE CHARTER SCHOOL In addition to and as confirmed by the specific violations described above based on document review considering removal of Board members who do not attend meetings ADDITIONAL PROPOSED REMEDIAL ACTIONS GAMES commits to having legal counsel attend Board meetings at a minimum through the March Board meeting and possibly through the June meeting The Board will make a determination on or about the March Board meeting as to whether the presence of legal counsel is still needed to ensure compliance GAMES will recruit up to three new Board members who have experience on a charter school board on a public entity board or operating a charter school GAMES engage in the recruitment process deliberately as it does not wish to inject instability into the Charter Schools governance by adding new members in a hasty manner The GAMES Board will engagement in the recruitment process between now and the end of the calendar year with a target goal of bringing on new members on or around the March Board meeting However if the CSD does not agree with a deliberate approach to GAMES Charter School Facts in Support of Revocation Page of increasing Board capacity the Charter School would be glad to hear alternate suggestions or recommendations from CSD GAMES will also consider additional parent representation on the Board The Board already has a Board member application form and is currently developing a rubric which Board members can utilize to evaluate potential candidates GAMES anticipates voting to adopt this rubric during its October Board meeting Attachment B GAMES Response September On October GAMES submitted further response to CSD letter dated October from Board to evaluate school administrators and leadership including making necessary adjustments and the implementation of the terms defined in the charter at the end of each year and for the term of the charter cid Agreement that the Board shall remove Board members who do not attend Board meetings as well as add a parent representative in accordance with its Bylaws by December cid Agreement to conduct a Board selfassessment and prepare a deliberative plan to add new members to the Board no later than July cid Agreement that new Board members will go through a CSD Capacity Interview Districts Position GAMES failed to refute the violation or remedied the violations The District has considered the pupil academic achievement for all groups of pupils served by GAMES as the most important factor in determining whether to revoke the charter Ed Code c The school has a API Growth Score of reflecting a growth of points and met growth targets for most subgroups Their SPF rating for last year was Service and Support and their AGT in ELA and Math were both at predicted Notwithstanding the pupil academic achievement of the school as stated throughout this Notice of Intent to Revoke and Notice of Facts in Support of Revocation the District has ongoing concerns regarding the governing boards capacity to exercise its fiduciary obligations and operate the school effectively and ethically The evidence herein demonstrates a pattern of violations of law conflict of interest issues and selfdealing fiscal mismanagement and breach of material terms of its charter The GAMES governing board has a pattern stemming from at least of having issues related to governance and conflicts of interest Based on these concerns the District does not believe that GAMES proposed plan to recruit additional board members without replacing members who had been on the board when these violations occurred as well as board leadership who engaged in the very issues raised in this revocation process is sufficient to successfully remedy the violations GAMES Charter School Facts in Support of Revocation Page of LAUSDS RESPONSE TO GAMES NOVEMBER LETTER TO THE BOARD OF EDUCATION As indicated above the LAUSD Board of Education held a public hearing on November and approved the conditional suspension of GAMES revocation process on the condition that GAMES signs and executes the Districts proposed MOU outlining all corrective actions taken including the replacement of the governing board by July The Board of Education also issued the Notice of Intent to Revoke and Notice of Facts in Support of Revocation At the November public hearing GAMES legal counsel submitted a letter to the Board of Education stating that GAMES will agree to all but one of the provisions in the proposed MOU GAMES indicated that it was not willing to agree that its governing board prepare a deliberative plan to replace the entire governing board with new board members no later than July According to the letter GAMES board believes that replacing all board members by the end of the current school year will be disruptive to the operations of the school and will result in more chaos and an environment that is not conducive to student learning GAMES proposed that instead of replacing the board in its entirety the board will do the following Evaluate new candidates for membership on the Board in accordance with its application evaluation rubric Seek to seat new board members who have experience in business law fundraising community outreach finance and mental health Determine an ideal size for the board within the range allowed for by its bylaws Consult with the Charter Schools Division regarding the size and composition of its Board The letter also represented that GAMES API growth score was representing a point increase schoolwide and experienced a point growth for African American students and point growth for socioeconomically disadvantaged students The letter also represented that it has been unfairly subjected to a substantial and unwarranted attack on its capacity both as a Board and as individual Board members See Attachment E GAMES letter to LAUSD Board of Education November The District has considered the pupil academic achievement for all groups of pupils served by GAMES as the most important factor in determining whether to revoke the charter Ed Code c The District acknowledges that the school has a API Growth Score of reflecting a growth of points and met growth targets for most subgroups Their SPF rating for last year was Service and Support and their AGT in ELA and Math were both at predicted The District has considered the positive record of academic achievement for all groups of pupils GAMES and its Board of Directors were given several opportunities to remedy the violations presented so that the school could continue to provide a viable educational option to students under new governance leadership Based on the academic achievement of the school and a desire to find alternatives to revocation the District presented a MOU to conditionally suspend This section is in response to new information submitted by GAMES after the Districts production of the Notice of Intent to Revoke and Notice of Facts in Support of Revocation GAMES Charter School Facts in Support of Revocation Page of the revocation process if the GAMES board agrees to transition into new board membership and composition by July The District considers that a new board membership is the ultimate remedy to the ongoing concerns and systemic violations that have occurred at the schools board level As stated throughout the records in the revocation proceedings including the Notice of Violations Notice of Intent to Revoke and Notice of Facts in Support of Revocation and herein Facts in Support of Revocation the District has ongoing concerns regarding the governing boards capacity to exercise its fiduciary obligations and operate the charter public school effectively and in compliance with all applicable laws These violations continue to be a concern as exemplified in the weeks prior to the November public hearing wherein the GAMES Board had to cancel a board meeting due to a lack of compliance with provisions of the Brown Act which has been a violation noted throughout the process Moreover even as of the writing of this report and at this juncture of the revocation process the GAMES Board has not submitted evidence of remedy for items that are clearly within the governing boards access and power eg signed original Form Statements of Economic Interest for two board members and one staff member Accordingly the District maintains that GAMES has committed and failed to remedy the violations listed in the Notice of Violations Response dated October Attachment D GAMES Supplemental Response dated October Attachment E GAMES Letter to LAUSD Board of Education submitted November Attachment F Notice of Intent to Revoke and Notice of Facts in Support of Revocation for purposes of this attachment exhibits are excluded exhibits are duplicative of Attachments AD above which were part of the documentation for the Notice of Intent to Revoke Letter to GAMES serving Notice of Intent to Revoke and Notice of Facts in Support of Revocation with attachments November GARR ACADEMY OF MATHEMATICS AND ENTREPRENEURIAL STUDIES GAMES CHARTER SCHOOL FINAL DECISION TO REVOKE December LEGAL AUTHORITY Garr Academy of Mathematics and Entrepreneurial Studies GAMES or Charter School is a charter school authorized by the Los Angeles Unified School District Board of Education Board of Education GAMES charter petition was originally approved by the Board of Education on June and renewed on February Education Code section c through e authorizes the revocation of a charter school based on the following provisions c A charter may be revoked by the authority that granted the charter under this chapter if the authority finds through a showing of substantial evidence that the charter school did any of the following A Committed a material violation of any of the conditions standards or procedures set forth in the charter B Failed to meet or pursue any of the pupil outcomes identified in the charter C Failed to meet generally accepted accounting principles or engaged in fiscal mismanagement D Violated any provision of law c The authority that granted the charter shall consider increases in pupil academic achievement for all groups of pupils served by the charter school as the most important factor in determining whether to revoke a charter d Requires the authorizing entity to notify the charter school in writing of any violation and give the charter school a reasonable opportunity to remedy the violation prior to revocation e Prior to revoking a charter for failure to remedy a violation pursuant to subdivision d and after expiration of the schools reasonable opportunity to remedy without successfully remedying the violation the chartering authority shall provide a written notice of intent to revoke and notice of facts in support of the revocation to the charter school No later than days after providing the notice of intent to revoke a charter the chartering authority shall hold a public hearing in the normal course of business on the issue of whether evidence exists to revoke the charter No later than days after the public hearing the chartering authority shall issue a final decision to revoke or decline to revoke the charter unless the chartering authority and the charter school agree to extend the issuance of the decision by an additional days The chartering authority shall not revoke a charter unless it makes written factual findings GAMES Charter School Final Decision to Revoke Page of supported by substantial evidence specific to the charter school that support its findings State regulations also outline the charter revocation process under Title of the California Code of Regulations sections et seq Substantial evidence has been defined as relevant evidence that a reasonable mind might accept as adequate to support a conclusion Hosford v State Personnel Bd CalAppd quoting Gubser v Department of Employment CalAppd and case law states [e]vidence is substantial if any reasonable trier of fact could have considered it reasonable credible and of solid value Kearl v Board of Medical Quality Assurance CalAppd SUBSTANTIAL EVIDENCE cid The Board has considered and has before it this date the following documents Facts in Support of Revocation with the following attachments Attachment A LAUSD Notice of Violations with exhibits dated August Attachment B GAMES Response and Exhibits dated September Attachment C LAUSD Charter Schools Division Reply to GAMES Response dated October Attachment D GAMES Supplemental Response dated October Attachment E GAMES Letter to LAUSD Board of Education submitted November Attachment F Notice of Intent to Revoke and Notice of Facts in Support of Revocation for purposes of this attachment exhibits are excluded exhibits are duplicative of Attachments AD above which were part of the documentation for the Notice of Intent to Revoke Letter to GAMES serving Notice of Intent to Revoke and Notice of Facts in Support of Revocation with attachments November cid The Board further takes into consideration any additional written or oral evidence GAMES presented to the Board at the public hearing regarding revocation REVOCATION PROCEEDINGS Notice of Violations At a public hearing held on August the LAUSD Board of Education authorized the District to issue a Notice of Violations to GAMES Charter School providing GAMES with a reasonable opportunity to remedy the violations The Notice of Violations provided GAMES with a reasonable opportunity to demonstrate remedy of the violations by September and GAMES did not object to the time period given to remedy nor did it request additional time to demonstrate remedy GAMES Charter School Final Decision to Revoke Page of The Notice of Violations outlined the grounds for revocation based on Violations Of Law Students Due Process Rights Ralph M Brown Act California Public Records Act Conflict Of Interest Laws Ed Code cD Fiscal Mismanagement SelfDealing And Misappropriation Of Public Funds Failure To Maintain Fiscal Records Ed Code cC Violation of Material Provisions of its Charter Element Governance Element Suspension and Expulsion Procedures Ed Code c A Concerns Regarding General Capacity To Operate Charter School GAMES Response to Notice of Violations On September GAMES submitted its response to the Districts Notice of Violations presenting corrective actions that have been taken as well as prospective corrective actions that the charter school purports it will take LAUSD reviewed and evaluated the response and all supporting documentation provided by GAMES On October LAUSD replied to GAMES outlining areas of additional remedial actions requested On October GAMES Board President replied agreeing to some but not all of LAUSDs additional remedial actions LAUSD staff determined that GAMES failed to refute the violations and did not provide sufficient remedies or proposed plans in response to the violations However taking into consideration GAMES pupil academic achievement LAUSD proposed under a Memorandum of Understanding MOU that the revocation process would be conditionally suspended if GAMES agrees to all the remedial actions including specifically that it transitions to a new governing board with new board members by July Notice of Intent to Revoke and Notice of Facts in Support of Revocation On November the LAUSD Board of Education held a public hearing and approved the conditional suspension of GAMES revocation process on the condition that GAMES signs and executes the Districts proposed MOU outlining all corrective actions taken including the transition into a governing board with new members by July The Board of Education also approved the issuance of the Notice of Intent to Revoke and Notice of Facts in Support of Revocation GAMES Board President and legal counsel were present and addressed the Board of Education requesting that the Board reject staff recommendation to issue the conditional suspension and Notice of Intent to Revoke GAMES submitted a letter to the Board of Education stating its reasons why it does not agree with the Districts request to replace the GAMES governing board The Notice of Intent to Revoke and Notice of Facts in Support of Revocation along with the November board report were served via certified mail and email to GAMES and its governing board on November notifying GAMES that a GAMES Charter School Final Decision to Revoke Page of revocation hearing will be held on December at the LAUSD Board Room Service was also made to legal counsel via email on November Revocation Hearing At a public hearing held on December the Board of Education considered all evidence presented by the District and GAMES THE LOS ANGELES UNIFIED SCHOOL DISTRICT BOARD OF EDUCATION HEREBY FINDS BY SUBSTANTIAL EVIDENCE THE FOLLOWING cid GAMES Charter School has been provided reasonable opportunity to remedy the violations identified in the Notice of Violations and pursuant to Education Code sections c subdivisions A C and D committed and failed to remedy the following violations Violations Of Law Students Due Process Rights Ralph M Brown Act California Public Records Act Conflict Of Interest Laws Ed Code cD Fiscal Mismanagement SelfDealing And Misappropriation Of Public Funds Failure To Maintain Fiscal Records Ed Code cC Violation of Material Provisions of its Charter Element Governance Element Suspension and Expulsion Procedures Ed Code c A LAUSD also outlined concerns regarding the general capacity of the GAMES governing board to exercise its fiduciary obligations and operate a public charter school effectively and in compliance with applicable laws based on the governing boards demonstrated pattern of noncompliance as documented in the Facts in Support of Revocation cid Written Findings After consideration of all evidence before it the Board adopts the facts findings and conclusions contained in the Facts in Support of Revocation and all attachments therein as its written findings supported by a showing of substantial evidence to support revocation of the Charter School and incorporates such findings into this Final Decision to Revoke as though set forth fully herein The Board further takes into consideration any additional written or oral evidence GAMES presented to the Board at the public hearing regarding revocation cid Revocation of Charter cid Pursuant to Education Code section e the Board hereby revokes the charter of Garr Academy of Mathematics and Entrepreneurial Studies GAMES Charter School cid The Board hereby issues this Final Decision to Revoke as its Final Decision GAMES Charter School Final Decision to Revoke Page of cid GAMES may appeal the revocation to Los Angeles County Board of Education LACBOE within days following the final decision If LACBOE does not issue a decision within days of the appeal or upholds the authorizing entitys revocation GAMES may appeal the revocation to the State Board of Education SBE cid During the pendency of any appeal to LACBOE or SBE GAMES will cease operations pursuant to Education Code section i since the violations in part are based on fiscal mismanagement and violation of law Ed Code sections f and i APPROVED PASSED AND ADOPTED by the Board of Fiscal Priorities Noticed March and Postponed from Previous Board Meetings ADOPTED AS AMENDED Whereas The Los Angeles Unified School District has suffered tremendous adverse fiscal impacts due to the nations economic crisis including the elimination of critical programs and the staff supporting them Bd of Ed Regular Meeting Stamped Order of Business pm Whereas The State of California continues to shamefully sit at the bottom of the nation in perpupil funding consequently we must do more with less Whereas Devastating cuts have been made to arts and music education early education adult education libraries afterschool programs outdoor education and nursing and counseling services while class sizes increased salaries were cut summer school was eliminated and the school year shortened Whereas Through the efforts of Governor Jerry Brown the voters and the organizations that worked so hard to pass Propositions and next years budget is expected to improve Whereas The Governors proposed Local Control Funding Formula LCFF should also positively impact the situation locally as it provides a base grant of about per student which would be supplemented with extra funds for districts with large numbers and concentrations of students qualifying for free and reduced price lunch English Language Learners and foster youth encompassing the vast majority of District students Whereas Often when new money comes into a system it is spent in a nonholistic hodgepodge fashion riddled with pet projects minimal community input and little planning Whereas There remains a preexisting structural deficit to deal with and Whereas The students families members of the community and District employees have shared the pain and should have a voice in the Districts recovery efforts as well as a sense of transparency and Whereas California school districts are required by the State Education Code Section to hold a public hearing regarding categorical budgeting now therefore be it Whereas LCFF mandates parental inclusion through a Local Control Accountability Plan LCAP which requires the District to notify members of the public of the opportunity to submit written comments hold at least one public hearing to solicit recommendations regarding the specific actions and expenditures proposed to be included in the plan present the LCAP or annual update to the relevant advisory committees pursuant to Education Code Section for review and comment now therefore be it Resolved That prior to the Los Angeles Unified School Districts annual final budget adoption the District shall make use of the Parent Community Service Branches in each Educational Service Center Parent Centers the Facilities Services Community Relations KLCS and the Public Information Office to coordinate promote and conduct at least five public hearings one in each Educational Service Center aligned to the budget cycle so as to better inform the budgetary decisionmaking process and to best reflect the communitys priorities going forward Resolved further That the District shall convene a discussion budget briefing with its employees and bargaining units as those closest to the students seeking their advice as to how resources should be used Resolved further That input be solicited from the appropriate Student Body Presidents regarding students priorities be solicited from the Superintendents Student Advisory Council and be it finally Bd of Ed Regular Meeting Stamped Order of Business pm Resolved further That the Governing Board of the Los Angeles Unified School District shall conduct a Committee of the Whole meeting within days to publically discuss and rank its priorities and to align dollars to those priorities and be it finally Resolved That the Superintendent shall within days identify and present plans including accountability metrics to seek additional sources of funding on behalf of our students Ms Galatzan Ms Garca Local Control Funding Formula Strategy and Implementation Noticed June and Postponed from the Regular Board Meeting of June POSTPONED TO THE REGULAR BOARD MEETING OF Whereas Governor Jerry Browns proposed Local Control Funding Formula LCFF attempts to rectify longstanding funding disparities between school districts across California Whereas The LCFF aims to simplify education funding and create a system that is transparent clear and equitable Whereas The LCFF does away with categorical funding much of which no longer serves its intended purpose Whereas The LCFF aims to make education funding equitable but not equal and to leave no student in the state behind Whereas To make sure funding is equitable and recognizing that some students need more services than others the LCFF allocates additional funding to students who live in poverty are foster children or are English Learners supplemental funding and further funding on top of that to districts where more than half the students fall in one of those categories concentration grants and Whereas Every child in the Los Angeles Unified School District is entitled to a certain level of basic services to support his or her education now therefore be it Resolved That the Governing Board of the Los Angeles Unified School District will continue to advocate for Governor Browns proposed Local Control Funding Formula in Sacramento Resolved further That when education funds come to the District in the form of supplemental funding and a concentration grant that money will follow the child to the school site Resolved further That the Superintendent and his staff will come back in days with different allocation models where the dollars follow the child Resolved further That those models will take into consideration the base level of funding every school needs to survive and thriveregardless of zip code size or composition Resolved further That the Superintendent will bring back a timeline to the Board for determining what that base level of funding is and be if finally Resolved That the above process to determine what services and programs are part of a schools base funding will include parent school and community participation Bd of Ed Regular Meeting Stamped Order of Business pm Mr Kayser Supporting a Pathway to US Citizenship through Adult Education Noticed June and Postponed from the Regular Board Meeting of July POSTPONED TO THE REGULAR BOARD MEETING OF Whereas The Immigration Reform and Control Act IRCA reformed the United States immigration law which granted legal status to more than million of the nations undocumented immigrants Whereas When Congress passed the IRCA of it required the million undocumented immigrants who were legalized under that law to enroll in at least hours of English courses before obtaining green cards Whereas Currently this number has increased to million undocumented immigrants in the United States and of which million reside in California and are students Whereas The proposed Immigration Reform Act will remove barriers for thousands of students making it the first critical step in supporting education for our students Whereas With the passage of the Immigration Reform Act the adult English as a Second Language ESL system would face challenges including the influx of thousands of new students Whereas The current system in place for teaching English to the nations immigrants state and federally funded classes has been greatly reduced by state budget cuts since the recession began and there is insufficient funding currently to meet the needs of the numbers of people who both need and want Englishlanguage instruction Whereas The Governing Board of the Los Angeles Unified School District in served approximately students and in served approximately in the Adult and Career Education Division and Whereas In the year the Adult and Career Education Division has only budgeted for an average of ten hour a week ESL classes in each of the adult service areas in the District now therefore be it Resolved That the Governing Board of the Los Angeles Unified School District directs the Superintendent and the Office of Government Relations to work with Governor Jerry Brown the State Legislature and Federal representatives to address the inequitable funding system in adult education specifically ESL classes that have been historically underfunded and are now negatively impacted by flexibility Board Member Resolutions for Initial Announcement Mr Zimmer Arts at the Core Implementing the Arts Education and Creative Network Plan FOR ACTION AT THE REGULAR BOARD MEETING OF Whereas The Los Angeles Unified School District affirming its commitment to providing all students with equitable and rigorous learning opportunities and curricula to provide graduates with the skills and knowledge necessary for college readiness career training and preparation for life after high school unanimously adopted the historic Arts at the Core Resolution on October Bd of Ed Regular Meeting Stamped Order of Business pm Whereas The Arts Education and Creative Network Plan presents a comprehensive strategy for integrating arts instruction with the Common Core State Standards Whereas The Arts Education and Creative Network Plan identifies the need to expand collaboration and strategic partnerships among nonprofit and government agencies qualified to assist the District in implementing an updated shared delivery model meaningful data collection and the documentation and dissemination of best practices in arts education Whereas The Superintendent was charged with developing an implementation plan that includes cid Increased funding for both discrete and integrated arts education for all students in the District cid Support for high quality professional development in pedagogy and curriculum cid Systemic data collection to measure the progress of student learning in and through the arts cid Oversight for implementation across the District and annual benchmarks for success cid A budget within five years or sooner that matches or exceeds funding levels from the academic year in order to help ensure sequential arts course offerings for all elementary and secondary schools cid Strategies for increasing the numbers of elementary arts teachers within years or sooner to be commensurate with other large urban districts such as Dallas New York City Chicago Seattle Pittsburgh and Philadelphia and for increasing the number of middle school arts teachers to ensure a minimum of three arts disciplines offered in every middle school cid Policy guidelines that are consistent with the California Department of Education guidelines that allow use of state and federal categorical funds for research based arts education strategies to bridge the achievement gap through improving student achievement in English Language Arts ELA and Math at Title I schools and for other categorical funds that may be used for professional development strategic partnerships with nonprofit arts organizations model program development and the dissemination of best practices cid Budgeting provisions for individual school sites to receive a dollar amount each year based on student enrollment to supplement centrally funded teachers for purposes such as art supplies additional days of credentialed elementary arts teacher services secondary off norm credentialed arts teachers arts productions professional development and qualified services from external arts partners and cid Provisions for recruiting training evaluating and retaining highly qualified arts teachers for the future reaffirming the Districts current commitment to protect an adequate number of credentialed and tenured arts teachers and centrally funded dedicated arts teachers to ensure foundational instruction in the arts from future Reductions in Force now therefore be it Resolved That the Governing Board of the Los Angeles Unified School District recognizes and commends the positive momentum made by the Superintendent and his staff toward achieving the requirements of the Arts at the Core Resolution through the Arts Education and Creative Network Plan Resolved further That the Board adopts the Arts Education and Creative Network Plan as a working document to be revised on an ongoing basis until each criterion of the resolution is achieved Bd of Ed Regular Meeting Stamped Order of Business pm Resolved further That the Board directs the Superintendent to continue expand renew or join any alliance that seek to increase the funding base needed to ensure that a quality arts education and instruction is a right for every student in the District and be it finally Resolved That the Board directs the Superintendent to report back at a public Board Meeting on the implementation of all strategies called for in the Arts Education and Creative Network Plan within sixty days Ms Galatzan Increasing Parent Engagement Through District Volunteer Programs FOR ACTION AT THE REGULAR BOARD MEETING OF Whereas The purpose of the Los Angeles Unified School District School Volunteer Program is to enhance student achievement by engaging and leveraging the rich talents and expertise of our local school communities Whereas One of the Districts five core beliefs is that families are our partners and one of the Districts five goals is parent and community engagement Whereas School volunteers reinforce classroom learning by assisting teachers in classrooms with noninstructional tasks and supporting school personnel in the effective operation of schools Whereas School volunteers promote positive partnerships between the home schools and the community and serve as positive role models for students by helping them develop more positive attitudes about themselves their schools and their communities Whereas Research shows that parental involvement is associated with higher student achievement outcomes including grades standardized test scores and a variety of other measures like teacher ratings Whereas According to the Districts Parent and Community Student Services Branch PCSB volunteers are a vital resource for many schools and LAUSD is home to over volunteers Districtwide Whereas The School Volunteer Program Office was cut and the responsibilities were shifted to the PCSB in without any extra funding or resources Whereas While many District services were cut during the last five years due to dire financial straits small investments in parent engagement and involvement yielded huge and invaluable rewards Whereas The current fingerprinting fee of is required for persons volunteering in any school for more than hours per week or less than hours per week but with significant contact with students LAUSD Policy Bulletin Office of Curriculum Instruction and School Support LAUSD District Goals LAUSDs Core Beliefs Retrieved from httphomelausdnetappspagesindexjspuREC_IDtypedpREC_ID LAUSD District Goals Retrieved from httphomelausdnetappspagesindexjspuREC_IDtypedpREC_ID Jeynes W H Parental involvement and student achievement A metaanalysis Family Involvement Research DigestCambridge MA Harvard Family Research Project Retrieved July from httpwwwgseharvardeduhfrppublications_resourcespublications_seriesfamily_involvement_research_digestsparental_involvement_and_ student_achievement_a_meta_analysis Bd of Ed Regular Meeting Stamped Order of Business pm Whereas Currently volunteers must commute up to miles to be fingerprinted at the District Headquarters even though in the past volunteers could also go to one of the Youth Services satellite fingerprint sites that were available throughout the District Whereas Tuberculosis TB screenings for persons interested in volunteering can cost up to at some vendor sites but are offered for free or at a low cost at other sites including community clinics and District Wellness Centers Whereas Since approximately percent of District students qualify for free or reducedprice meals high fees and long commutes can prevent or discourage lowincome families from participating as volunteers in their local schools and Whereas The PCSB has been working to strengthen the volunteer policy so that it is more efficient affordable and welcoming to school volunteers and less burdensome for schools now therefore be it Resolved That the Governing Board of Los Angeles Unified School District directs the Superintendent to examine easier and more affordable options for fingerprinting services and to work with the Districts Human Resources Division and Employee Relations team to provide fingerprinting services every month at all LAUSD Live Scan sites throughout the District Resolved further That the Districts School Volunteer Program Bulletin must include an attachment that contains an expanded list of LAUSD Wellness Centers and community clinicsat least one in each Board Districtthat offer TB screenings for no cost or a low cost Resolved further That the Board directs the LA Trust Wellness Centers and the Districts Nursing Services Division to support onsite TB testing throughout the District as a result of this resolution Resolved further That the Superintendent shall examine the feasibility and funding options to support the creation and management of an online volunteer application system to be implemented in the school year Resolved further That the District develop a communication plansuch as beginning of the year packets for current District students and enrollment packets for Kindergarteners and new enrolleesto inform parents of the LAUSD School Volunteer Program and explore new ways of promoting the volunteer program using multimedia Resolved further That the District shall organize and carry out a onestopshop Volunteer Day at least once in the fall and once in the spring at each Educational Service Center in which prospective volunteers can get fingerprinted TB tested checked on Megans Law List and complete the volunteer application online if applicable all in the same day and location and be it finally Resolved That the Superintendent report back to the Board in days with an implementation planincluding the timeline communication feasibility and longterm funding optionsthat addresses all of the previously mentioned policy changes and feasibility issues for the academic year Mr Kayser Dr Vladovic Support of AB Gomez FOR ACTION AT THE REGULAR BOARD Bd of Ed Regular Meeting Stamped Order of Business pm Whereas The Los Angeles Unified School District is committed to creating opportunities and utilizing resources so that our graduates will be engaged and effective citizens in our society MEETING OF Whereas Assemblymember Jimmy Gomez DLos Angeles has authored and introduced Assembly Bill that aims to provide children in California a more indepth education on the voting and electoral process and the tools they need to be civically engaged as they grow into adulthood Whereas Existing law requires that the State Board of Education requests a review and revision of course requirements in the historysocial science framework Whereas The California education code requires all high school graduates to have completed and passed a course in United States government and civics Whereas AB would require that when the historysocial science framework is revised the Instructional Quality Commission IQC include voter education information in high school American government and civics courses Whereas While the content of the Districts current material addresses the voting process and the importance of voting AB aims to expand upon the current material including but not limited to how to research ballot propositions how and where to find further candidate information and voting rights Whereas Historically young voters ages have been underrepresented in elections as shown in the November national election with only of eligible young voters registered Whereas Young voters are expected to increase to one third of all eligible voters in the United States by it is important to expand the resources available to our future electorate Whereas California has a responsibility to increase civic engagement not only with first generation voters but also with the children of newly registered voters Whereas California is home to many new immigrants including Latino and Asian families who are and will continue to be a vital part of our economy Whereas It has been found that many times children of nonEnglishspeaking parents have taken on the duty of translator teaching their own parents how to navigate the electoral process reading and interpreting candidate statements and propositions and Whereas Assemblymember Jimmy Gomez and the District wish to create more effective opportunities for students to become engaged citizens now therefore be it Resolved That the Governing Board of the Los Angeles Unified School District supports Assembly Bill Mr Kayser Mr Zimmer Elementary Physical Education FOR ACTION AT THE REGULAR BOARD MEETING OF Bd of Ed Regular Meeting Stamped Order of Business pm Whereas The US Surgeon General Centers for Disease Control and Prevention National Institute for Health Government Accountability Office Institute of Medicine and National Association for Sport and Physical Education all identify increasing physical activity through quality physical education programs as one of the most critical things to fight the childhood obesity epidemic Whereas The California State Legislature has found and declared that the physical fitness and motor development of children in the public elementary schools is of equal importance to that of other elements of the curriculum Cal Educ Code a Whereas California voters are in nearly unanimous agreement that it is important for schools to encourage more physical activity during the school day more Californians favor physical education in schools than any other obesity prevention policy across most party and socioeconomic lines and support requiring physical education classes for four years in high school according to and Field Polls commissioned by The California Endowment Whereas A John Hopkins University study showed that for every weekday an adolescent participated in physical education classes the odds of becoming an overweight adult decreased by five percent and participating in physical education classes everyday decreased the odds of becoming an overweight adult by percent Whereas Evidencebased research published by the Institute of Medicine the California Endowment and others documents the importance of quality physical education teachers and programs to improve student health youth development and academic performance Whereas A study by the California State Board of Education found that children engaged in daily physical activity outperformed other students on exams exhibited superior academic performance and attitudes toward school improved scores on shortterm memory tests and reaction times and increased creativity Whereas the Institute of Medicine and The City Project recommend teachers receive training and ongoing professional development in physical education Whereas In a pilot program at four elementary schools Marvin Allesandro Overland and Norwood Elementary Schools in Los Angeles County with increased physical activity minutes and quality physical education students API scores increased and points respectively as did their fitness level and Norwood over a fouryear period increased points Whereas Evidencebased research by The City Project and Samuels Associates found that secondary school teachers provided more moderate to vigorous physical activity than elementary teachers potentially attributable to the fact that secondary school teachers are disproportionately ones with specialized training and credentials in physical education Whereas A major report by the Institute of Medicine on physical education and physical activity in school recommends that at least half of physical education class time be spent engaged in moderate to vigorous physical activity Whereas Evidencebased research published by the Institute of Medicine and the California Endowment documents health disparities based on race color national origin gender and socioeconomic status Bd of Ed Regular Meeting Stamped Order of Business pm Whereas the report by the Institute of Medicine recommends that physical activity be considered in all school policy decisions to improve academic performance health and development for all children and that physical education and activity be monitored in school Whereas The Districts own Office of Inspector General found in an internal audit that the district elementary physical education program was not in compliance with District policy of the elementary schools visited did not have proof of school wide schedule of physical education and Whereas The California Court of Appeal has held that districts can be sued for failure to comply with the California Education Code minutes requirement and that parents and students have standing to sue when a school district fails to comply now therefore be it Resolved That the Governing Board of the Los Angeles Unified School District directs the Superintendent to ensure all Physical Education Teacher Incentive Program funding is restored to its specific status to provide physical education instruction by teachers with a single subject credential in physical education in elementary schools and provide equipment and supplies Resolved That the Superintendent identify the schools that previously received the funding so that they have the first priority to continue their funding Resolved That the Superintendent prioritizes funding for underresourced schools Resolved That the Superintendent deliver to the Board by September an implementation plan created by OCISS Physical Education department to equitably apply the funding to other elementary schools throughout the following years Resolved That the Superintendent deliver to the Board an annual report on compliance with this motion and resolutions for any corrective actions needed before the end of each school year Resolved That the Superintendent ensure that all District physical education bulletins are reviewed updated and disseminated to ensure compliance with state and federal education codes within days and be it finally Resolved That options for funding shall include but not be limited to Federal and State grants foundation and private sector support and identified cost savings to fund existing PETIP schools for the school year Correspondence and Petitions Report of Correspondence APPROVED BY CONSENT VOTE Approval of Minutes APPROVED BY CONSENT VOTE Please note that the Board of Education may consider at this meeting any item referred from a Board Meeting five calendar days prior to this meeting Education Code b The Board of Education may also refer any item on this Order of Business for the consideration of a committee or meeting of the Board of Education which meets on the Thursday immediately after this meeting Requests for disability related modifications or accommodations shall be made hours prior to the meeting to the Board Secretariat in person or by calling Individuals wishing to speak at a Board meeting must sign up at the meeting There will be no sign ups in advance of the meeting Speakers must sign up prior to the item being acted upon by the Board Speakers should plan to arrive early as items with no speakers may be acted on at the beginning of the meeting If you or your organization is seeking to influence an agreement policy site selection or any other LAUSD decision registration may be required under the Districts Lobbying Disclosure Code Please visit wwwlausdnetethics to determine if you need to register or call Materials related to an item on this Order of Business distributed to the Board of Education are available for public inspection at the Security Desk on the first floor of the Administrative Headquarters and at httplaschoolboardorgRegBd Items circulated after the initial distribution of materials are available for inspection at the Security Desk Bd of Ed Regular Meeting Stamped Order of Business pm Page of EXHIBIT LAUSD Board of Education Report and stamped Board
