Holmquist Janelle Ruley [PROPOSED] Memorandum of Understanding By and Between the Los Angeles Unified School District and Garr Academy of Mathematics and Entrepreneurial Studies Whereas Garr Academy of Mathematics and Entrepreneurial Studies GAMES or Charter School is an independent charter school governed by the nonprofit public benefit corporation Garr Academy of Mathematics and Entrepreneurial Studies and authorized by the Los Angeles Unified School District District hereinafter collectively referred to as Parties Whereas on August LAUSD through its Charter Schools Division CSD presented the LAUSD Board of Education a recommendation to issue a Notice of Violations pursuant to Education Code section c citing violations of law including deprivation of students due process rights the Ralph M Brown Act California Public Records Act conflict of interest laws fiscal mismanagement material breach of terms of its charter including governance and expulsion procedures and concerns regarding governing board capacity to oversee operations of the charter school Whereas on August the Board of Education approved the issuance of the Notice of Violations to GAMES and provided GAMES with a reasonable opportunity to remedy the violations by September Whereas on September GAMES responded to the Districts Notice of Violations and provided the District with some documentation of corrective actions Whereas on October CSD replied to GAMES response to the Notice of Violations outlining additional remedial actions requested and whereas GAMES issued a supplemental response on October agreeing to some but not all additional corrective actions Whereas the District in the interest of maintaining stability and continuity of educational services for GAMES students and in lieu of proceeding with revocation at this time agrees to suspend the revocation proceedings on the condition that GAMES agrees to all of the required corrective actions contained herein [Proposed] MOU and Whereas the District retains and reserves its right as the oversight entity of GAMES to initiate revocation proceedings pursuant to Education Code section subsections c d and e Page of NOW THEREFORE THE PARTIES AGREE AND COVENANT AS FOLLOWS Compliance with Corrective Actions GAMES agrees that it will continue to comply and maintain actions consistent with the corrective actions taken thus far including but not limited to the following a Violation of Students Due Process Rights Related to Expulsion Proceedings cid Strict compliance with Charter Policy and Procedures to ensure due process The GAMES Board and administrators will revise Element of its charter and present the material revision to the District for approval by December GAMES shall follow the revised GAMES Charter Element in any future suspension andor expulsion proceedings cid to SuspensionExpulsion Training Will Be Provided the Board and Administrators The Law Offices of Young Minney Corr LLP will provide a mandatory training to the Board and to all School administrators who handle student discipline matters to ensure that there is a thorough understanding of the appropriate due process required by law and under the GAMES charter and policy The GAMES Board shall provide evidence of the training which was held on October as represented by GAMES in its response to the Notice of Violations forthwith cid The Charter School will send a letter to the Parent in question confirming that the expulsion process on the Student never commenced and confirming that the Student is currently in good standing at the Charter School Evidence of the letter shall be provided to the CSD forthwith cid Submit to the CSD an acknowledgement that the recommendation for expulsion brought before the GAMES Governing board is nulledvoided and that the matter is closed The acknowledgment shall include that any and all actions against the student regarding this incident has been addressed through the suspension Evidence shall include but not be limited to board agenda board minutes and parent notification Evidence shall be provided to the CSD forthwith b Brown Act Violations cid The GAMES Board shall continue utilizing Brown Actcompliant Request to Speak forms cid Every new GAMES Board member and administrator will receive a comprehensive training on the Brown Act conflicts of interest laws best governance practices and the states transparency laws including the Public Records Act The Board and administrators will also finance schedule annual training by a qualified educational Page of professional to review fiscal control policies and best practices for public charter schools cid Agree to submit via email to the CSD copies of the GAMES Board Agendas the day agendas are posted to the public from December to July cid Submit to the CSD copies of the GAMES board meeting minutes from December to July cid Submit to the CSD evidence of Brown Act Training as well as a report after every board meeting attended by GAMES counsel to summarize how the current GAMES board and any new members are developing capacity to ensure ongoing compliance into the future whether counsel is present or not c Conflict of Interest Violations cid Charter schools its board members and employees must abide by conflict of interest policies applicable to public entities including California Government Code and the California Political Reform Act cid CSD requires a signed written statement by each current GAMES board member and any new board members assuring compliance with applicable conflicts of interest laws policies and the LAUSD Policy on Charter School Authorizing by December and as they become new members of the board cid GAMES shall ensure annual submission of Forms to LAUSD d California Public Records Act Violations cid GAMES agrees to submit to the CSD at the end of each school year and for the term of the charter a GAMES Boardcertified list containing cid The date each Public Records Act request was placed by the public to the GAMES Board cid The date the GAMES Board satisfied each PRA request and supporting evidence e Failure to Maintain Fiscal Records Fiscal Irregularities cid The GAMES Board will send a demand letter to the lastknown address of the thought misappropriation of funds Evidence of action shall be provided to the CSD forthwith the person responsible to be for Page of cid Contact collection agency for retrieval If no response is made to the demand letter and the cost of retrieval is less than the amount of money misappropriated the matter will be given to a collection agency Evidence of action shall be provided to the CSD forthwith cid The CSD requests that GAMES provides evidence and efforts taken until the funds are recuperated cid All corporate records including but not limited to Board meeting agendas and minutes tax documents and District and Staterequired documents will be maintained in the locked cabinet in an organized fashion cid The CSD requests that GAMES provides all of the IRS forms that has been requested cid GAMES governing board shall ensure compliance with fiscal controls policies and procedures f Governance and Board Capacity Issues cid GAMES commits to having legal counsel attend Board meetings at a minimum through the March Board meeting and possibly through the June meeting The Board will make a determination on or about the March Board meeting as to whether the presence of legal counsel is still needed to ensure compliance with the Brown Act and all other applicable laws cid GAMES Governing Board shall carefully evaluate school administration for ongoing effectiveness and shall provide evidence of documentation used to evaluate school administrators and leadership including making necessary adjustments and the implementation of the terms defined in the charter at the end of each year and for the term of the charter cid GAMES governing board shall remove board members who do not attend meetings as well as add a parent representative as suggested by the GAMES governing board in accordance with their bylaws by December cid GAMES governing board shall conduct a selfassessment and prepare a deliberative plan to replace the entire governing board with new board members no later than July cid That new Governing Board members shall engage in a CSD Capacity Interview Page of cid Every new GAMES Board member and administrator will receive a comprehensive training on the Brown Act conflicts of interest laws best governance practices and the states transparency laws including the Public Records Act The Board and administrators will also finance schedule annual professional to review fiscal control policies and best practices for public charter schools training by a qualified educational BreachNotice to Cure Parties agree that failure to meet the corrective actions and benchmarks shall be grounds for the District to continue revocation proceedings In addition the District reserves the right to initiate revocation proceedings at any time upon evidence that GAMES has committed grounds subject to revocation under Education Code section Modifications This Memorandum of Understanding may be modified or supplemented only through written agreement of the Parties Severability In the event any provision of this MOU is found to be illegal or unenforceable such illegality or unenforceability shall not prevent enforcement of all other provisions of the Agreement Term This Memorandum of Understanding shall remain in effect through GAMES charter term [SIGNATURES ON FOLLOWING PAGE] Page of Date For the District For the Charter School Page of NOTICE OF INTENT TO REVOKE AND NOTICE OF FACTS IN SUPPORT OF REVOCATION GARR ACADEMY OF MATHEMATICS AND ENTREPRENEURIAL STUDIES GAMES Education Code Section e November Pursuant to its oversight obligations and revocation statutes and corresponding regulations the Los Angeles Unified School Districts Board of Education LAUSD Board issues this NOTICE OF INTENT TO REVOKE AND NOTICE OF FACTS IN SUPPORT OF REVOCATION to Garr Academy of Mathematics and Entrepreneurial Studies GAMES and its governing board for committing violations of law fiscal mismanagement and material violations of GAMES Charter LEGAL AUTHORITY Education Code e provides in relevant part Prior to revoking a charter for failure to remedy a violation pursuant to subdivision d and after expiration of the schools reasonable opportunity to remedy without successfully remedying the violation the chartering authority shall provide a written notice of intent to revoke and notice of facts in support of the revocation to the charter school No later than days after providing the notice of intent to revoke the charter the chartering authority shall hold a public hearing in the normal course of business on the issue of whether evidence exists to revoke the charter NOTICE OF FACTS IN SUPPORT OF REVOCATION The factual bases for issuance of this Notice of Intent to Revoke are set forth below The District incorporates all of the substantial evidence and supporting documentation contained in the August Notice of Violations Attachment A LAUSDs Notice of Violations August DETAILED FINDINGS OF FACT I VIOLATIONS OF LAW STUDENTS DUE PROCESS RIGHTS RALPH M BROWN ACT CALIFORNIA PUBLIC RECORDS ACT CONFLICT OF INTEREST LAWS ED CODE CD A Violation of Students Due Process Rights At the GAMES Board meeting on March which was attended and observed by the CSD assigned administrator the Board had added to the agenda and discussed an incident that had occurred the same day involving two students At that same meeting the Board voted to expel one of the students Although the parent was provided a Notice of Suspension that suspended the student for two days the school failed to provide the parent or student with notice of the expulsion recommendation or an opportunity to be heard by the Board In response to a CSD Notice to Cure issued April the school denies that the Board expelled the student but rather asserts that the Board only discussed the expulsion recommendation and that the parent disenrolled the student on or about the following day Under Education Code section which GAMES charter indicates it follows if a pupil is expelled from a public school the pupil or pupils parent may appeal the decision and shall be entitled to a hearing to determine whether the pupil should be expelled The hearing shall be held within schooldays and before a hearing officer or impartial administrative panel Any classification of public schools students which affects the fundamental interest of the student in education must be examined under state constitutional provisions with that strict and searching scrutiny appropriate to such a case Serrano v Priest Cald see also Butt v State of California Cal th Since charter schools are public schools charter school students have the same constitutionally grounded fundamental interest in education as all public school students Expulsion affects a students fundamental interest in education therefore charter school students facing expulsion are entitled to constitutional due process protection Cal Const art I subd a EVIDENCE Attachment A NOTICE OF VIOLATIONS Exhibit March Notice of Suspension Exhibit Correspondence from parent Exhibit May letter from GAMES to CSD Exhibit Declaration of Ruben Diaz Specialist Administrator GAMES Response GAMES responded that while the alleged violation unquestionably did not occur the Charter School nevertheless acknowledges that it can improve its processes around student suspension and expulsion GAMES proposed the following remedial actions cid Strict Compliance with Charter Policy and Procedures to Ensure Due Process The GAMES Board and administrators will carefully follow the GAMES Charter Element in any future suspension andor expulsion proceedings cid SuspensionExpulsion Training Will Be Provided to the Board and Administrators The Law Offices of Young Minney Corr LLP will provide a mandatory training to the Board and to all School administrators who handle student discipline matters to ensure that there is a thorough understanding of the appropriate due process required by law and under the GAMES charter and policy The GAMES Board voted on September to hold this training during its regular Board meeting on October cid Letter to Parent Regarding Lack of Commencement of Expulsion Process The Charter School will send a letter no later than September to the Parent in question confirming that the expulsion process on the Student never commenced and confirming that the Student is currently in good standing at the Charter School Attachment B GAMES Response September On October GAMES submitted further response to CSD letter dated October from Board President Wanda Briscoe Attachment D GAMES Supplemental Response The letter responded to CSDs reply to GAMES Response containing additional actions needed Attachment C CSDs Reply to GAMES Response GAMES agreed to the CSDs additional remedial actions including cid Agreement to submit to CSD an acknowledgement that the recommendation for expulsion is nulledvoided and that the matter is closed cid Agreement to work with CSD to revise Element of its charter petition without need to materially revise the charter petition cid Agreement to submit copies of the suspensionexpulsion training dates and materials presented during the trainings for Charter School leaders and Governing Board members Attachment D GAMES Supplemental Response October Districts Position GAMES failed to refute the violation or remedied the violations Aside from making a statement that it would comply with the Districts additional remedial actions GAMES did not provide sufficient affirmative and tangible evidence to date that it has remedied the violations Notwithstanding GAMES agreement to the additional proposed remedies to prevent future violations to students due process in disciplinary proceedings their responses do not amount to the violation being remedied Furthermore it is important to note that the CSD administrator was present at the board meeting where the student was expelled by the board without due process and notice Attachment A Exhibit Declaration of Ruben Diaz Although GAMES indicates that the student is currently in good standing at the school the school continues to deny that it expelled the student on the same day the alleged incident occurred Contrary to the declaration of CSD administrator present at the board meeting the Principal presented the GAMES board with the incident from that very day and that the Board acted on the expulsion without notice Notice could not have been provided pursuant to the charter petition or for the purposes of complying with the Brown Act since the incident occurred that day Moreover The GAMES Board has not provided evidence of the proposed items stated in their Supplemental Response of October B Ralph M Brown Act Violations cid GAMES made a lastminute change to the posted Board agenda for its meeting on March Notably the agenda was changed to include the expulsion matter described above The above action violated the Brown Acts requirement to post an agenda containing a brief general description of each item of business to be transacted or discussed at the meeting including items to be discussed in closed session at least hours before a regular meeting Cal Govt Code Section a Further the Brown Act prohibits action or discussion on any item not appearing on the posted agenda Cal Govt Code Section a No legal exceptions applied which would have allowed the GAMES board to take action on the expulsion item which was not on the posted agenda item Cal Govt Code Section b EVIDENCE Attachment A Notice of Violations Exhibit March GAMES Board minutes Exhibit Declaration of Ruben Diaz Specialist Administrator cid Despite specific assurances of Brown Act compliance in response to CSDs April Notice to Cure GAMES again failed to post its regular Board meeting agenda at least hours prior to meeting on May Cal Govt Code Section a The Board had to adjourn midmeeting in response to public objection to the late posting and change of the agenda since it was posted EVIDENCE Attachment A Notice of Violations Exhibit Declaration of Ruben Diaz Specialist Administrator cid GAMES violated the publics right to attend meetings anonymously on May In the beginning of the Board meeting the members of the public were passed a signin sheet to write their name The form did not have any directions explain the rights to remain anonymous Additionally the governing board president asked members of the public to introduce themselves and the organization they represent GAMES failed to provide notice of closed session items on agenda for meeting on May Cal Govt Code Section a GAMES violated its own procedures as well as the Brown Act on May when it initially refused to hear public comment on agenda items and then in response to public protest allowed only minutes per speaker despite its own published procedures that provide minutes Cal Govt Code Section requires every agenda for regular meetings to provide an opportunity for members of the public to directly address the board on any item of interest to the public EVIDENCE Attachment A Notice of Violations Exhibit May agenda and signin Exhibit Declaration of Ruben Diaz Specialist Administrator Exhibit GAMES published Instructions for Attendance andor Presentations to the Board by Parents and Citizens May GAMES Response REMEDIAL ACTIONS TAKEN The Board retained the law firm of Young Minney Corr LLP to conduct board governance training This training occurred on November and included training on the Brown Act conflict of interest laws and responsibilities of the board The Charter School remedied the alleged Brown Act violations of the meetings of March and May by reagendizing all action items and properly took action on those items again during a special Board on June The Charter Schools legal counsel was present at this meeting and ensured that the Brown Act was properly followed Attached as Exhibit please find minutes from the June Board meeting The GAMES Board is utilizing Brown Actcompliant Request to Speak forms attached as Exhibit PROPOSED REMEDIAL ACTIONS Every new GAMES Board member and administrator will receive a comprehensive training on the Brown Act conflicts of interest laws best governance practices and the states transparency laws including the Public Records Act The Board and administrators will also schedule annual training by a qualified educational finance professional to review fiscal control policies and best practices for public charter schools On October GAMES submitted further response to CSD letter dated October from Board President Wanda Briscoe Attachment D GAMES Supplemental Response The letter responded to CSDs reply to GAMES Response containing additional actions needed Attachment C CSDs Reply to GAMES Response GAMES agreed to the CSDs additional remedial actions including cid Agreement to submit via email to the CSD copies of the GAMES Board agendas the day the agendas are posted to the public from December to July cid Agreement to submit to the CSD copies of the GAMES Board meeting minutes from December to July cid Agreement to submit to the CSD evidence of Brown Act Training cid Agreement to submit to the CSD a report after every board meeting attended by GAMES counsel to summarize how the current GAMES Board and any new members are developing capacity to ensure ongoing compliance into the future whether counsel is present or not Districts Position GAMES failed to refute the violation or remedied the violations As noted in CSDs Reply Attachment D it deems this violation cured only as long as all proposed remedial actions are taken Although some corrective actions have been provided since some of the remedies are just proposed remedial actions this is not evidence that GAMES has successfully remedied all violations Moreover The GAMES Board has not provided evidence of the proposed items stated in their Supplemental Response of October C Conflict of Interest Violations GAMES paid in to Ms Wanda Briscoe thenBoard president and current Board president as a fundraising consultant Under conflict of interest laws applicable to public entities and public officials the Board President as a public official had a direct financial interest in the financial transaction which paid her fees as a fundraising consultant California Government Code Section prohibits a public official from being financially interested in a contract or sale in both his or her public and private capacities Thomson v Call Cal d stating the purpose of section is to make certain that every public officer be guided solely by the public interest rather than by personal interest when dealing with contracts in an official capacity EVIDENCE Attachment A NOTICE OF VIOLATIONS Exhibit Board meeting agendas and minutes Exhibit IRS form reporting in income for consulting services Exhibit check register showing payments of to Board President Wanda Briscoe consultant in June July August and September cid Over the past five years several GAMES Board members and employees have failed to file or have filed late California Form in violation of Political Reform Act requirements Cal Gov Code sections EVIDENCE Attachment A NOTICE OF VIOLATIONS Exhibit CSD Form records GAMES Response GAMES provided the following response cid Since the incidents alleged during the time period the GAMES Board retained Charter Impact as its business services provider in August Charter Impact is comprised of a team of charter school professionals all supporting the main principal Neil Shah The team is hired based on level of education and work experience and in particular charter school experience Every individual working for Charter Impact has California charter school finance experience Charter Impact provides fullservice charter school specific business management services cid The GAMES Board of Directors is composed of financially disinterested volunteer Board members who understand their fiduciary and ethical obligations to GAMES as both a nonprofit public benefit corporation and a public charter school No paid employees and no one who has a personal financial interest in a contract with the Charter School serve on the Board cid GAMES understands its obligation to comply with all applicable and current conflict of interest laws and policies GAMES also understands its obligation to comply with LAUSDs conflicts of interest laws and ethics policies as affirmed in its current charter GAMES will continue enhanced and ongoing training and professional development for board members and administrators and will vigorously enforce all conflicts of interest laws GAMES affirms that it will promptly investigate and act on any and all reports of financial misappropriation or any violation of law and policy cid GAMES currently operates under legally compliant Fiscal Controls cid GAMES has a process in place for the filling out collection and filing of Form from all Board members and applicable employees The GAMES Principal brings the Form to the Board annually collects the forms and submits them as required to LAUSD Attachment B GAMES Response September On October GAMES submitted further response to CSD letter dated October from Board President Wanda Briscoe Attachment D GAMES Supplemental Response The letter responded to CSDs reply to GAMES Response containing additional actions needed Attachment C CSDs Reply to GAMES Response GAMES agreed to the CSDs additional remedial actions including cid Agreement to submit a signed written statement by each current GAMES Board member and any new Board members assuring compliance with applicable conflict of interest laws policies and the LAUSD Policy on Charter School Authorizing by December and as they become new members of the Board Attachment D GAMES Supplemental Response October Districts Position GAMES failed to refute the violation or remedied the violations Procuring the services of Charter Impact does not remedy or address the issue of conflict of interest and selfdealing from the governing board level Although GAMES states that their board is composed of financially disinterested members it continues to be a concern that the governing board does not understand and heed conflict of interest laws applicable to public entities and public officers This analysis is based on past conflict of interest issues at GAMES In Ms Briscoe received compensation as a fundraising consultant while serving as board president In through CSD oversight it was determined that an employee of the school the Administrative Consultant was also the owner of the property GAMES leased The GAMES board accepted the resignation of this employee through a letter sent to Ms Briscoe in her capacity as Chair This notice was provided after the time when Ms Briscoe also accepted remuneration an exchange which is tantamount to the matter which led to the resignation of the other member Violations of conflict of interest laws at the governing board and governing board leadership level continue to be a critical concern for the District Moreover The GAMES Board has not provided evidence of the proposed items stated in their Supplemental Response of October Aside from selfserving statements in its responses that GAMES understands conflict of interest laws it has not shown that these violations have been remedied D CALIFORNIA PUBLIC RECORDS ACT cid GAMES has failed to respond to at least two Public Records Act PRA requests in a timely manner in violation of the California Public Records Act Cal Gov Code section et seq Apart from the discrepancy between GAMES and the person placing the PRA Requests the June correspondence between both parties CSD included in the correspondence show the fulfillment of the PRA over days overdue In the emailed mention above the person requesting the PRA shared Regarding my multiple requests had GAMES responded to the first request there wouldnt be a need for a second request via email April rd a third request in person at the school site via GAMES Principal April th a fourth request via email directly to Wanda Briscoe April th and finally a fifth request during the May th GAMES Board of Directors meeting whereas I also made my preference known to receive all responses and or documentation via electronic communication FYI per the CPRA public records requests do not have to be in written form If you need copies of the aforementioned requests I am sure your client Ms Briscoe on behalf of GAMES should be able to provide this information to you EVIDENCE Attachment A Notice of Attachment D GAMES Supplemental Response October Districts Position GAMES failed to refute the violation or remedied the violations In spite of CSDs repeated inquiries about the misappropriation of the from the Christmas fundraiser the GAMES board had not acted upon recouping those funds or provided a plan on how those funds would be returned to the GAMES community GAMES supplemental response also does not demonstrate specific plans and merely states that it would provide evidence of efforts taken to recoup the funds It is important to note that its own private investigator revealed on April that the misappropriation of the funds had taken place Six months later the GAMES board has not affirmatively acted upon these findings and its proposed remedies states that it will send a demand letter and will contact collection agency It is concerning and does not amount to successfully remedying the violation that even these simple resolutions have not been acted upon to date again calls into question the capacity of the governing board and administration to operate the school Moreover The GAMES Board has not provided evidence of the proposed items stated in their Supplemental Response of October B Failure to Maintain and Produce Adequate Records Effectively Monitor Fiscal Operations and Act Promptly to Remedy and Prevent Fiscal Irregularities In several requests and notices issued to GAMES in April and May the CSD has requested records and documentation such as Board agendas and minutes and IRS forms The CSD still has received only partial responses to these notices Notably GAMES has not provided most of the requested documentation pertaining to and On March the GAMES Board president reported to CSD alleged misappropriation of funds back in Although records show that the GAMES Board was aware of the allegations at the time from until November when GAMES retained Oracle to investigate the alleged misappropriation the GAMES Board apparently did not conduct further investigation seek to recover the funds or take adequate steps to improve fiscal controls On May in response to a Notice to Cure GAMES informed the CSD that it has taken or will take steps to investigate and improve its internal fiscal practices EVIDENCE Attachment A NOTICE OF VIOLATIONS Exhibit GAMES letter to CSD dated May GAMES Response GAMES provided the following response cid REMEDIAL ACTIONS TAKEN GAMES has provided to CSD all of the Board agendas and minutes that it has on file from and The Charter School is not withholding documents from CSD Attached as Exhibit please find all Board agendas and minutes from through that the Charter School was able to locate The Charter School was able to obtain most of the IRS Forms from and as requested by CSD Attached as Exhibit please find the IRS Forms that the Charter School has been able to locate to date cid PROPOSED REMEDIAL ACTIONS According to Principal Greene the GAMES office was broken into and several records from and were stolen Principal Greene called the police and attempted to make a report However Principal Greene stated that the police would not make a report because there were no signs of forced entry GAMES will purchase a locked cabinet in which to store corporate records The keys for the locked cabinet will be given to the Charter Schools Principal and Board President only All corporate records including but not limited to Board meeting agendas and minutes tax documents and District and Staterequired documents will be maintained in the locked cabinet in an organized fashion GAMES has asked Charter Impact its back office services provider to contact the IRS to obtain the remaining Forms Attachment B GAMES Response September On October GAMES submitted further response to CSD letter dated October from Board President Wanda Briscoe Attachment D GAMES Supplemental Response The letter responded to CSDs reply to GAMES Response containing additional actions needed Attachment C CSDs Reply to GAMES Response GAMES agreed to the CSDs additional remedial actions including cid GAMES agrees to provide all of the IRS forms Attachment D GAMES Supplemental Response October Districts Position GAMES failed to refute the violation or remedied the violations Aside from evidence of lack of governance and operational capacity to operate a charter school GAMES has not acted upon procuring replacement for the requested forms from the IRS notwithstanding the representation that they were unable to provide the full set of requested forms due to a break in at the school over the summer It is concerning that an organization operating a public charter school does not have systems in place to ensure records are maintained and that backup records are held Moreover the governing board did not indicate that they had requested copies of the forms from the federal government after the alleged theft The governing board and administrations proposed remedy to delegate the retrieval of records to outside entities like Charter Impact again calls into question the capacity of the governing board and administration to operate the school The GAMES Board has not provided evidence of the proposed items stated in their Supplemental Response of October III GAMES VIOLATED MATERIAL PROVISIONS OF ITS CHARTER ELEMENT GOVERNANCE ELEMENT SUSPENSION AND EXPULSION PROCEDURES Ed Code c A Governance and Element Provisions All issues raised above also constitute material violations of various provisions of the governance provisions in the GAMES charter including violations of the following provisions cid Members of GAMES executive board any administrators managers or employees and any other committees of the school shall comply with federal and state laws non profit integrity standards and LAUSDs Charter School policies and regulations regarding ethics and conflict of interest EVIDENCE Attachment A NOTICE OF VIOLATIONS Exhibit GAMES Charter Petition p In addition GAMES has failed and continues not to respond promptly and fully to recent CSD notices and requests for documentation including failure to provide all requested Board agendas and minutes and copies of IRS Form for GAMES contractors and vendors for the past five years in violation of Element of the GAMES charter This is a violation of the following provision in the charter cid GAMES shall promptly respond to all inquiries including but not limited to inquiries regarding financial records from the District and shall consult with the District regarding any inquiries GAMES acknowledges that it is subject to audit by LAUSD including without limitation audit by the District office of the Inspector general EVIDENCE Attachment A NOTICE OF VIOLATIONS Exhibit GAMES Charter Petition p GAMES Response GAMES provided the following response cid This alleged violation contains only language from the GAMES charter petition The Charter School believes that it has responded to the substance of the alleged violation above in response to violations regarding conflict of interest violations and fiscal mismanagement by acknowledging and refuting the alleged violations and taking remedial action and proposing remedial actions Attachment B GAMES Response September On October GAMES submitted further response to CSD letter dated October from Board President Wanda Briscoe Attachment D GAMES Supplemental Response The letter responded to CSDs reply to GAMES Response containing additional actions needed Attachment C CSDs Reply to GAMES Response GAMES agreed to the CSDs additional remedial actions including cid GAMES understand that this alleged violation will be considered cured when the Board agrees to submit submits or complies with the actions requested in the CSDs analysis Attachment D GAMES Supplemental Response October Districts Position GAMES failed to refute the violation or remedied the violations Procuring the services of Charter Impact does not remedy or address the issue of conflict of interest and selfdealing from the governing board level Although GAMES states that their board is composed of financially disinterested members it continues to be a concern that the governing board does not understand and heed conflict of interest laws applicable to public entities and public officers This analysis is based on past conflict of interest issues at GAMES In Ms Briscoe received compensation as a fundraising consultant while serving as board president In through CSD oversight it was determined that an employee of the school the Administrative Consultant was also the owner of the property GAMES leased The GAMES board accepted the resignation of this employee through a letter sent to Ms Briscoe in her capacity as Chair This notice was provided after the time when Ms Briscoe also accepted remuneration an exchange which is tantamount to the matter which led to the resignation of the other member Violations of conflict of interest laws at the governing board and governing board leadership level continue to be a critical concern for the District Aside from selfserving statements in its responses that GAMES understands conflict of interest laws it has not shown that these violations have been remedied Aside from evidence of lack of governance and operational capacity to operate a charter school GAMES has not acted upon procuring replacement for the requested forms from the IRS It is concerning that an organization operating a public charter school does not have systems in place to ensure records are maintained and that backup records are held Moreover the governing board did not indicate that they had requested copies of the forms from the federal government after the alleged theft The governing board and administrations proposed remedy to delegate the retrieval of records to outside entities like Charter Impact calls into question the capacity of the governing board and administration to operate the school Moreover The GAMES Board has not provided evidence of the proposed items stated in their Supplemental Response of October B Expulsion Procedures Element As stated above under Violations of Law a pupil was expelled without proper notice and a hearing in violation of the students due process Furthermore the Boards action violated the following provisions of the charter cid GAMES shall provide due process for all students including adequate notice to parentsguardians and students regarding the grounds for suspension and expulsion and their due process rights regarding suspension and expulsion including rights to appeal cid A student recommended for expulsion is entitled to a hearing if requested by the parent or guardian to determine whether the student should be expelled The student will continue to be suspended during the expulsion process The hearing shall be held in a timely manner if requested not to exceed days after the Principal or designee determines that one of the acts listed under Grounds for Suspension and Expulsion has occurred The hearing will continue to be presided over by the Board of Directors Written notice of the hearing shall be forwarded to the student and the students parentguardian at least ten days before the date of the hearing by the principal or his designee The notice shall include cid The date and place of the hearing cid A statement of the specific facts charges and offenses upon which the proposed expulsion is based cid A copy of the GAMES student discipline guidelines andor grounds for suspension and expulsion which relate to the alleged violation cid The opportunity for the student or the students parentguardian to appear in person or to employ and be represented by counsel cid The right to inspect and obtain copies of all documents to be used at the hearing cid The opportunity to confront and question all witnesses who testify at the hearing cid The opportunity to question all evidence presented and to present oral and documentary evidence on the students behalf including witnesses cid Expulsion Procedures Students recommended for expulsion are entitled to a hearing before the Board to determine whether the student should be expelled The expulsion panel consists of board members and an administrator not involved in the behavior determination The hearing shall be held within thirty school days after the Principal or designee determines that the student has committed an expellable offense Pending the expulsion hearing the school will ensure that the students and their families receive classroom materials and current assignments cid The Expulsion Board Members will conduct the expulsion hearing The hearing will be held in closed session unless the student makes a written request for a public hearing three days prior to the hearing cid Written notice of the student and the hearing shall be forwarded parentguardian at least ten days before the hearing date The notice shall include o The date and place of the hearing A statement of the specific facts charges to and offenses upon which the proposed expulsion is based o A copy of the schools disciplinary rules which relate to the alleged violation Notification of the students parentguardian obligation to provide information about the students status at the school to any other school district or school to which the student seeks enrollment o The opportunity for the student to appear in person or to employ and be represented by counsel or a nonattorney advisor o The right to inspect and obtain copies of all documents to be used at the hearing o The opportunity to question all witnesses who testify at the hearing o The opportunity to question all evidence presented and to present oral and documentary evidence on the students behalf including witnesses o Written Notice to Expel cid The Principal or designee shall send written notice of the decisions to expel to the student or parentguardian within days of the decision This notice shall include the following o The specific offense committed by the student for any of the acts listed in Grounds for Suspension and Expulsion above o Notice of the students or parentguardian obligation to inform any new district in which the student may attend the students current status with GAMES o Notice of the right to appeal the expulsion to the full Board of Directors of GAMES The expulsion panel is made up of select Board members and the Principal Notice of the students or parentguardians obligation to inform any new district in which the student seeks to enroll of the students status with GAMES o The reinstatement eligibility review date o A copy of the rehabilitation plan o Type of educational placement during the period of expulsion EVIDENCE Attachment A NOTICE OF VIOLATIONS Exhibit GAMES Charter Petition pp GAMES Response cid This alleged violation contains only language from the GAMES charter petition The Charter School believes that it has responded to the substance of the alleged violation above in response to violation of students due process by refuting the alleged violation and proposing remedial actions Attachment B GAMES Response September On October GAMES submitted further response to CSD letter dated October from Board President Wanda Briscoe Attachment D GAMES Supplemental Response The letter responded to CSDs reply to GAMES Response containing additional actions needed Attachment C CSDs Reply to GAMES Response GAMES agreed to the CSDs additional remedial actions including cid GAMES understand that this alleged violation will be considered cured when the Board agrees to submit submits or complies with the actions requested in the CSDs analysis Attachment D GAMES Supplemental Response October Districts Position GAMES failed to refute the violation or remedied the violations Aside from making a statement that it would comply with the Districts additional remedial actions GAMES did not provide sufficient affirmative and tangible evidence that it has remedied the violations to date Notwithstanding GAMES agreement to the additional proposed remedies to prevent future violations to students due process in disciplinary proceedings their responses do not amount to the violation being remedied since they are just proposed actions Furthermore it is important to note that the CSD administrator was present at the board meeting where the student was expelled by the board without due process and notice Attachment A Exhibit Declaration of Ruben Diaz Although GAMES indicates that the student is currently in good standing at the school the school continues to deny that it expelled the student on the same day the alleged incident occurred Contrary to the declaration of CSD administrator present at the board meeting the Principal presented the GAMES board with the incident from that very day and that the Board acted on the expulsion without notice Notice could not have been provided pursuant to the charter petition or for the purposes of complying with the Brown Act since the incident occurred that day Moreover The GAMES Board has not provided evidence of the proposed items stated in their Supplemental Response of October IV CONCERN REGARDING GENERAL CAPACITY TO OPERATE CHARTER SCHOOL In addition to and as confirmed by the specific violations described above based on document review interviews and observations conducted as part of annual oversight CSD staff continues to have concerns regarding the general lack of capacity demonstrated by the current GAMES governing board and administration to operate the school effectively and ethically in compliance with the terms of the charter and applicable law EVIDENCE The District incorporates all the above evidence herein Attachments A through D and exhibits GAMES Response REMEDIAL ACTIONS TAKEN GAMES provided the following response As GAMES promised in its May response to a Notice to Cure from the CSD legal counsel has been present at the two Board meetings which have occurred since that time June and September GAMES created new Request to Speak cards for Board meetings which uphold the right of the public to attend Board meetings anonymously Attached as Exhibit please find the Request to Speak card The Board is considering removal of Board members who do not attend meetings ADDITIONAL PROPOSED REMEDIAL ACTIONS GAMES commits to having legal counsel attend Board meetings at a minimum through the March Board meeting and possibly through the June meeting The Board will make a determination on or about the March Board meeting as to whether the presence of legal counsel is still needed to ensure compliance GAMES will recruit up to three new Board members who have experience on a charter school board on a public entity board or operating a charter school GAMES engage in the recruitment process deliberately as it does not wish to inject instability into the Charter Schools governance by adding new members in a hasty manner The GAMES Board will engagement in the recruitment process between now and the end of the calendar year with a target goal of bringing on new members on or around the March Board meeting However if the CSD does not agree with a deliberate approach to increasing Board capacity the Charter School would be glad to hear alternate suggestions or recommendations from CSD GAMES will also consider additional parent representation on the Board The Board already has a Board member application form and is currently developing a rubric which Board members can utilize to evaluate potential candidates GAMES anticipates voting to adopt this rubric during its October Board meeting Attachment B GAMES Response September On October GAMES submitted further response to CSD letter dated October from Board President Wanda Briscoe Attachment D GAMES Supplemental Response The letter responded to CSDs reply to GAMES Response containing additional actions needed Attachment C CSDs Reply to GAMES Response GAMES agreed to the CSDs additional remedial actions including cid Agreement to evaluate Charter School administration for ongoing effectiveness cid Agreement to provide evidence of documentation used to evaluate school administrators and leadership including making necessary adjustments and the implementation of the terms defined in the charter at the end of each year and for the term of the charter cid Agreement that the Board shall remove Board members who do not attend Board meetings as well as add a parent representative in accordance with its Bylaws by December cid Agreement to conduct a Board selfassessment and prepare a deliberative plan to add new members to the Board no later than July cid Agreement that new Board members will go through a CSD Capacity Interview Districts Position GAMES failed to refute the violation or remedied the violations The District has considered the pupil academic achievement for all groups of pupils served by GAMES as the most important factor in determining whether to revoke the charter Ed Code c The school has a API Growth Score of reflecting a growth of points and met growth targets for most subgroups Their SPF rating for last year was Service and Support and their AGT in ELA and Math were both at predicted Notwithstanding the pupil academic achievement of the school as stated throughout this Notice of Intent to Revoke and Notice of Facts in Support of Revocation the District has ongoing concerns regarding the governing boards capacity to exercise its fiduciary obligations and operate the school effectively and ethically The evidence herein demonstrates a pattern of violations of law conflict of interest issues and selfdealing fiscal mismanagement and breach of material terms of its charter The GAMES governing board has a pattern stemming from at least of having issues related to governance and conflicts of interest Based on these concerns the District does not believe that GAMES proposed plan to recruit additional board members without replacing members who had been on the board when these violations occurred as well as board leadership who engaged in the very issues raised in this revocation process is sufficient to successfully remedy the violations Accordingly the District hereby issues this Notice of Intent to Revoke and Notice of Facts in Support of Revocation to the governing board of GAMES Charter School The date and time specified for a public hearing concerning revocation is as follows December pm DATE TIME LOCATION Los Angeles Unified School District Board Room st floor Beaudry Avenue Los Angeles CA Sincerely Jos ColeGutirrez Director Charter Schools Division Attachments Supplemental Facts GAMES Board Agenda Dated c Will Greene Principal GAMES Board via Ms Briscoe Janelle Ruley via email only Robert C Perry Leticia Vellanoweth Rubn Daz GARR ACADEMY OF MATHEMATICS AND ENTREPRENEURIAL STUDIES GAMES CHARTER SCHOOL SUPPLEMENTAL INFORMATION December Public Hearing Date December Board Report No The following document is based on new information obtained after the Facts in Support of Revocation was produced and served on the LAUSD Board of Education and GAMES Charter School BACKGROUND The August Notice of Violations issued to GAMES Charter School outlined the following grounds for revocation Violations Of Law Students Due Process Rights Ralph M Brown Act California Public Records Act Conflict Of Interest Laws Ed Code cD Fiscal Mismanagement SelfDealing And Misappropriation Of Public Funds Failure To Maintain Fiscal Records Ed Code cC Violation of Material Provisions of its Charter Element Governance Element Suspension and Expulsion Procedures Ed Code c A Concerns Regarding General Capacity To Operate Charter School SUPPLEMENTAL INFORMATION The following information provides further information of GAMES continued violation of law and failure to remedy the following ground for revocation outlined in the August Notice of Violations Violation of Law Brown Act On December GAMES charter schools board of directors held a Special Board Meeting See attached agenda Special Board Meeting December Agenda Staff from the Charter Schools Division attended and observed the meeting The GAMES board moved into closed session After closed session the board reconvened and the Board President reported that a decision was made that the GAMES board would not sign the MOU proposed by LAUSD The agenda item for discussion of the proposed MOU with LAUSD was not agendized as a closed session item Item III B lists the matter as Memorandum of Understanding with Los Angeles Unified School District o The Board will review and possibly take action to approve a proposed Memorandum of Understanding with Los Angeles Unified School District See Agenda LAUSDs Charter Schools Division served this document and attachments to the GAMES board on December See Attached cover letter and documentation of overnight mail and email service After discussing the other agenda items the Board President then announced that the meeting was adjourned A community member who arrived at the meeting after the meeting started objected to not having the opportunity to address the board for public comment The Board President announced that public comment request forms had not been filled out by anyone A community member addressed those present protesting that the Boards actions nonadherence to the Brown Act are one of the reasons for LAUSDs plan to revoke the charter Based on the above information the GAMES board continues to violate the Brown Act as identified in the Notice of Violations in August including the following provisions Section a of the California Government Code which requires in part Every notice for a special meeting shall provide an opportunity for members of the public to directly address the legislative body concerning any item that has been described in the notice for the meeting before or during consideration of the item cid The GAMES board did not allow the public to address the board It was apparent that there was a member of the public who wished to address the board Since one of the purposes of the Brown Act is to afford the public an opportunity to comment the member of the public should have been given an opportunity to fill out the public speaking card and address the board Section a Requires each item to be transacted or discussed in a closed session to be briefly described on an agenda for the meeting cid The agenda item failed to identify the proposed MOU with LAUSD as a closed session item See attached agenda Since the Board President reported after closed session that the board decided not to sign LAUSDs proposed MOU the item was evidently discussed in closed session when it was not labeled as a closed session item Section Closed Session by Legislative Body Prohibited Under the Brown Act closed sessions must be expressly authorized by explicit statutory provisions Closed sessions cannot be conducted unless they are expressly authorized by statute The following are statutory exceptions to the open meeting requirement of the Brown Act cid Personnel Exception cid Pending Litigation cid Real Property Negotiations cid Labor Negotiations a cid Public Security cid License Application Further statutory references are to the California Government Code unless otherwise stated cid The discussion of the proposed MOU with LAUSD did not fall under the above exceptions and there was no description in the agenda that identifies the subject of the proposed MOU as an item which would fall within the above statutory exceptions SUMMARY Based on the above information the GAMES governing board continues to violate the Brown Act which was identified as one of the grounds for revocation in the August Notice of Violations In its September response to the Notice of Violations GAMES indicated the following remedies The Board retained the law firm of Young Minney Corr LLP to conduct board governance training This training occurred on November and included training on the Brown Act conflict of interest laws and responsibilities of the board The Charter School remedied the alleged Brown Act violations of the meetings of March and May by reagendizing all action items and properly took action on those items again during a special Board on June The Charter Schools legal counsel was present at this meeting and ensured that the Brown Act was properly followed Attached as Exhibit please find minutes from the June Board meeting The GAMES Board is utilizing Brown Actcompliant Request to Speak forms attached as Exhibit The special board meeting of December exemplifies that the remedial actions taken by the GAMES board were not effective and that the Brown Act violations were not remedied The governing boards failure to provide members of the public an opportunity to address the board is disconcerting especially since the revocation of the school is a matter of grave concern to stakeholders parents and students of GAMES This concern is magnified since the GAMES board refused as suggested by the Charter Schools Division to send a letter to the parents notifying them of potential revocation of the charter school The recent violations of the Brown Act and lack of accountability to its parents and students reinforce the Districts ongoing concerns regarding the governing boards capacity to exercise its fiduciary obligations and operate the charter public school effectively and in compliance with all applicable laws Dominguez Melida COMMITTEE Stephen English Chair LA City Controllers Office Pamela Schmidt ViceChair Early Education Coalition Quynh Nguyen Secretary LAUSD Student Parent Scott Folsom Executive Committee Tenth District PTSA Stuart Magruder Executive Committee American Institute of Architects Joseph P Buchman Legal Counsel Burke Williams Sorensen LLP Thomas A Rubin CPA Oversight Committee Consultant Bill Brewington ThirtyFirst District PTSA Maria Cabildo LAUSD Student Parent Paul Escala CA Charter School Association Garrett Francis Assoc General Contractors of CA Abigail Marquez LA City Mayors Office Ron Miller LA Co Federation of Labor AFLCIO John Naimo LA Co AuditorControllers Office Barry Waite CA Tax Reform Assn Susan Linschoten Alternate LA Co AuditorControllers Office Elizabeth Lugo Alternate LAUSD Student Parent Gary C Anderson PhD Bond Administrator Daniel Hwang Administrative Analyst RESOLUTION BOARD REPORT NO SCHOOL UPGRADE PROGRAM WHEREAS On July the Board of Education adopted a Resolution Ordering an Election and Establishing Specifications of the Election Order for the purpose of placing Measure Q a Billion bond measure on the November election ballot to fund the renovation modernization construction and expansion of school facilities and WHEREAS In conjunction with this action the Board also adopted as amended the Bond Package Summary that identified the target amounts of bond proceeds to be allocated to various categories of need In preparing the bond measure more than Billion of needs were identified despite the fact that more than Billion had been invested in constructing new schools and repairing and modernizing existing school facilities and WHEREAS The Bond Package Summary has become outdated Five years have passed since it was adopted by the Board of Education and Measure Q was approved by the voters New information about the condition of the Districts facilities is available from the completed planning and assessment effort and the ongoing Facilities Condition Assessment The Districts instructional vision and the needs of our schools have also evolved over the course of the past five years and WHEREAS The School Upgrade Program was developed to reflect the intent and objectives of Measure Q as well as the current needs of our school facilities and educational goals The School Upgrade Program Spending Targets is essentially an updated version of the Bond Package Summary The spending targets were restructured to enable a more efficient comprehensive and holistic approach to developing and executing capital projects and WHEREAS District staff is proposing that the Board of Education establish the School Upgrade Program approve the overarching goals and principals of the School Upgrade Program SUP which will drive the development of future projects to upgrade build and repair District Bond Oversight Committee S Beaudry Avenue rd Fl Los Angeles CA cidT cidF cidbboclaschoolsorg wwwlaschoolsorgbond RESOLUTION SCHOOL UPGRADE PROGRAM PAGE school facilities to improve student health safety and educational quality within specific categories of need approve the allocation of from the various sources to support the development of projects under the SUP and approve the target amounts that will be allocated to the Facilities Services Division FSD Strategic Execution Plan SEP Information Technology Division ITD SEP Transportation Services Division TSD SEP and the Office of the Inspector General OIG and WHEREAS If the Board of Education does not approve the proposed action staff will be unable to move forward with the next phase of the Districts Bond Program Furthermore the development and execution of more than Billion of future projects to improve student health safety and educational quality will be delayed NOW THEREFORE BE IT RESOLVED THAT The School Construction Bond Citizens Oversight Committee recommends that the Board of Education adopt the School Upgrade Program and associated actions proposed by District staff as described herein and in the Board Report No a copy of which is attached hereto in the form it was presented to the BOC with the following revision In the School Upgrade Program Spending Targets attachment to attached Board Report No in the line item for Upgrade and Equip Schools with st Century Technology Common Core Technology Project the Proposed Spending Target amount should be reduced from to and the amount in the Unallocated column for that line item should be reduced to and a new line item for Unallocated should be created showing in the Unallocated column This resolution shall be transmitted to the Los Angeles Unified School District Board of Education and posted on the Bond Oversight Committees website That a written response as required by the Charter and Memorandum of Understanding between the Oversight Committee and the Board be provided to the Oversight Committee within days reporting either on action taken or proposed to be taken in response to this resolution and each recommendation herein Bond Oversight Committee S Beaudry Avenue rd Fl Los Angeles CA cidT cidF cidbboclaschoolsorg wwwlaschoolsorgbond NEW BUSINESS TAB of Education Report No For Board Meeting INTEROFFICE CORRESPONDENCE Los Angeles Unified School District Early Childhood Education Division TO INFORMATIVE Members Board of Education DATE November John E Deasy PhD Superintendent of Schools FROM Maureen S Diekmann Executive Director SUBJECT CALIFORNIA SCIENCE CENTER FOUNDATION CONTRACT NO CONTRACT AMOUNT REQUEST FOR RATIFICATION OF AFTERTHEFACT CONTRACT The Early Childhood Education Division has a longstanding professional learning relationship with the California Science Center For at least the past three years administrators and teachers have participated in numerous professional learning opportunities largely focused on the museums I Am a Scientist materials The decision was made during the summer to continue this relationship with the museum and train nineteen teachers who work in support of the thirteen Los Angeles Universal Preschool LAUP preschool programs in LAUSD Since this workshop series is funded by a grant with Los Angeles Universal Preschool LAUP and since we did not originally approach this agreement as a series of workshops but rather as individual standalone professional learning opportunities we did not secure a contract through the appropriate process The first workshop is an afterthefact and the two remaining are for a later date This office plans to have a proper contract andor PO before any services begin and avoid any afterthefacts The terms of the proposed agreement are as follows Three full day professional learning sessions based on three I am a Scientist preschool science units and kits at a contract amount of Funding is from a grant from Los Angeles Universal Preschool LAUP I would be pleased to provide any additional information you may need Please contact me by email at maureendiekmannlausdnet or at c Michelle King Matt Hill David Holmquist Enrique Boullt Jaime Aquino Jefferson Crain George Silva Board of Education Report No For Board Meeting cidcidcid INTEROFFICE CORRESPONDENCE Los Angeles Unified School District Office of the Deputy Superintendent of Instruction INFORMATIVE DATE December TO Members Board of Education Dr John E Deasy Superintendent FROM Dr Donna Muncey Chief of Intensive Support and Intervention Nader Delnavaz Director of School Improvement Grant SUBJECT AWARDED CONTRACTOR NAME Los Angeles Education Partnership CONTRACT NO CONTRACT AMOUNT REQUEST FOR APPROVAL OF AFTER THE FACT CONTRACT Request for approval of After the Fact Contract This contract is intended to update and replace Contract No which was originally approved by the Board on June for three years including two option years for a total of The option to renew the contract was not activated as the funding was not approved in order to do so The Renewal Application for Cohort of which Washington Prep is part was not available for submission until September The District did not receive the SIG grant award notification GAN for until September The Superintendent signed the GAN on September and the new funding number was established in midOctober Without the GAN Budget Services and Accounting could not establish the new funding in the system and we could not exercise the contract option to continue the second year with LAEP This contract request is for inclusive of one option year and continues the work of the Los Angeles Education Partnership LAEP as the nonprofit Educational Management Organization EMO the EMO designated to support Washington Prep High School As a Restart Model for the School Improvement Grant Washington Prep must work with an EMO which in this case is LAEP Approval of this contract will allow SIG funding to continue to flow to the school and allow LAEP to continue the work begun in the summer of Why is this necessary Approval of this contract will allow SIG funding to continue to flow to the school and thereby allow LAEP to continue the work begun in the summer of The SIG implementation plan for Washington Prep includes LAEPs professional development and support for summer and the school year The PD was provided as per the plan in summer The PD plan and support are defined and detailed in the Scope of Work for Why do we need to do this now The SIG implementation plan for this school includes summer PD provided by LAEP and PD with support indicated in their scope of work for Member Board of Education Dr John E Deasy Superintendent cidcidcid December What would happen if this were not approved Although unlikely there exists a possibility that we could be penalized the million granted but more critically the support and PD provided to the school and new principal would be halted The protocols and PD begun for this year would also be halted and could destabilize their PD program in a year critical for CCSS training and support for the teacher support and evaluation process Overall we stand to risk a loss of funding approximately for the school What are the terms of the proposed agreement As per their Scope of Work the LAEP will provide professional development beginning in summer and continue throughout the school year on a variety of topics including data informed instruction and intervention teacher effectiveness teaching and learning framework parent Education and AG requirements Two full time coordinators are provided and monthly meetings with staff and stakeholders continue the work of last year The goal is to provide supplemental resources to boost student achievement If you have any questions or require additional information please contact me at c Michelle King David Holmquist field creates the need for more training opportunities These additional funds will allow us to fill the industry demand and provide further classroom hours Apprenticeship and Journeyman Training Trust of So Cal Plumbing and Piping Industry serves as a community partner through classroom instruction onthejob training and work experience across the District Long established relationships between LAUSDDACE and this partner have led to further student achievement in this training area Why do we need to do this now Contract capacity increase of funding has been made available for use in the current fiscal year What would happen if this were not approved If no action is taken these contract funds would revert back to CDE and the number of places in this Apprenticeship program would not fill the needs of local industry What are the terms of the proposed agreement This contract capacity increase of is for the last year of an existing multiyear contract Training profit to DACE CORRESPONDENCE Los Angeles Unified School District Division of Special Education TO Members Board of Education Dr John E Deasy Superintendent of Schools INFORMATIVE DATE December FROM Sharyn Howell Executive Director Division of Special Education SUBJECT Frontier Ford CONTRACT NO IFB CONTRACT AMOUNT NOT TO EXCEED REQUEST TO AUTHORIZE THE PURCHASE OF PASSENGER VANS TO REPLACE AGING VANS CURRENTLY AT THE CAREER AND TRANSITION CENTERS Why is this necessary The Division of Special Education in conjunction with the Transportation Branch has provided aging vans to the Career and Transition Centers CTCs to support their ongoing vocational training work programs These vehicles were purchased between and and have an average of over miles each These vehicles all with high mileage have accrued high costs due to repairs and replacement of parts Our intent is to replace the aging vans with new vans In addition it is the Divisions plan to expand the number and use of vans at the Career Center sites in order to provide opportunities for our students with special needs to have vocational work experiences in their local communities Why do we need to do this now The vans all have high mileage continue to accrue costs have been deemed beyond economical repair and are ready to be salvaged by the Transportation Branch Also as the Career and Transition Center work programs continue to expand at our current sites ie landscaping catering building services farming autodetailing retail shredding etc the need for more vans has become essential to the success of these programs What would happen if this were not approved The Los Angeles Unified School District would continue to accrue high repair costs which currently exceed the value of the vehicles In addition the opportunities to provide students with real offcampus intercommunity work experiences would be highly limited What are the terms of the proposed agreement The intent is to purchase outright Passenger GBW Full Size Passenger Vans from Frontier Ford the lone bidder All the General Requirements and Vehicle Specifications have been approved by the Transportation Branch cid cid cid cid cid cid cid cid cid cid cid cid cid cid Report No For Board Meeting INTEROFFICE CORRESPONDENCE Los Angeles Unified School District Facilities Services INFORMATIVE TO Members Board of Education Dr John E Deasy Superintendent of Schools DATE October FROM Roger Finstad Director Maintenance and Operations SUBJECT CONTRACTOR HEAT TECH C HOT WATER BOILERS CONTRACT NO CONTRACT AMOUNT PER YEAR FOR THREE YEARS PLUS TWO ONEYEAR OPTIONS RECOMMENDATION TO AWARD Maintenance and Operations is requesting the Board of Educations approval to award Contract No for the purchase of hot water boilers to be used by Maintenance and Operations at various locations Districtwide Why is this necessary This contract is needed to provide the lowest overall competitive cost for the purchase of hot water boilers Why do we need to do this now The previous contract is expiring and there is continuous need for the purchase of hot water boilers What would happen if this were not approved If the contract is not approved there would be an increased administrative cost and burden to the Maintenance Operations Branch for the purchase of these materials Additionally it is anticipated that purchases of hot water boilers will exceed the public contract code that limits the Districts total purchase of a commodity to per year Future purchases will need to advertise formally for each purchase thereafter What are the terms of the proposed agreement The terms of the contract will be months plus two oneyear options Funding will be provided on an as needed basis by the individual department making the purchase If you have any questions please contact me at rogerfinstad lausdnet or at c Michelle King Matt Hill David Holmquist Yvette MerrimanGarrett Enrique Boullt Jaime Aquino Jefferson Crain Mark Hovatter Board of Education Report No For Board Meeting INTEROFFICE CORRESPONDENCE Los Angeles Unified School District Facilities Services TO Members Board of Education Dr John E Deasy Superintendent of Schools DATE October FROM Roger Finstad Director Maintenance and Operations SUBJECT CONTRACTOR TOTAL ENVIROMENTAL MANAGEMENT SC RENTAL OF AIR CONDITIONERS AND CHILLERS CONTRACT NO CONTRACT AMOUNT PER YEAR FOR THREE YEARS PLUS TWO ONEYEAR OPTIONS RECOMMENDATION TO AWARD Maintenance and Operations is requesting the Board of Educations approval to award Contract No for the rental of air conditioners and chillers to be used by Maintenance and Operations at various locations Districtwide Why is this necessary This contract is needed to provide the lowest overall competitive cost for the rental of air conditioners and chillers Why do we need to do this now The previous contract is expiring and there is continuous need for the rental of air conditioners and chillers What would happen if this were not approved If the contract is not approved there would be an increased administrative cost and burden to the Maintenance Operations Branch for the purchase of these materials Additionally it is anticipated that rental of air conditioners and chillers will exceed the public contract code that limits the Districts total purchase of a commodity to per year Future purchases will need to advertise formally for each purchase thereafter What are the terms of the proposed agreement The terms of the contract will be months plus two oneyear options Funding will be provided on an as needed basis by the individual department making the purchase If you have any questions please contact me at rogerfinstad lausdnet or at c Michelle King Matt Hill David Holmquist Yvette MerrimanGarrett Enrique Boullt Jaime Aquino Jefferson Crain Mark Hovatter Board of Education Report No For Board Meeting INTEROFFICE CORRESPONDENCE Los Angeles Unified School District Los Angeles School Police Department INFORMATIVE TO Members Board of Education Dr John E Deasy Superintendent of Schools DATE December FROM Steven K Zipperman Chief of Police SUBJECT ABSOLUTE SOFTWARE INC CONTRACT NO CONTRACT AMOUNT REQUEST FOR RATIFICATION Background This contract scope of work will serve to validate internal LAUSD Common Core Technology Project CCTP methodologies and will highlight best practices learned from urban metropolitan school districts that currently have to technology programs The five schools were selected to represent the wide array of building types age and type of school The schools selected are Franklin HS Lizarraga ES Sotomayor HS Westchester HS and Harte Preparatory Selections were made by age of the school type of school elementary comprehensive high school multiple academy high school and middle school and site layout multistory with elevator multistory without elevator ground floor bungalows Why is this necessary As the District moves forward in the implementation of technology programs it is essential that internal systems for safety and security be validated through a professional peer review to ensure optimal safety and security Why do we need to do this now Due to the scope of the proposed technology deployment for CCTP Phase and Phase L a significant number of devices may be deployed throughout the entire District If approved Phase and Phase L will begin by January This timely assessment will help to ensure that our systems are validated refined and amended as needed in order to enhance student safety and facilities security Members Board of Education Dr John E Deasy Superintendent December What would happen if this were not approved A No vote prevents an independent professional peer review of the Districts procedures and protocols in the school site assessment related to safety and security for technology projects A Yes vote allows the contractor to visit school sites meet with key District personnel from Districts central office and schools to review existing safety auditsassessments and discuss specific threats and vulnerability concerns visit the schools conduct interviews and conduct internalexternal securitysafety assessments as well as assess schoolcampus climate assess security of District buildings and school grounds utilize the nationally recognized Crime Prevention through Environmental Design Concept CPTD in completing the assessments as part of the assessments examine the key factors specified in the Proposal including lighting perimeter barrierscontrol foot and vehicle traffic patternsflow limited parking lots limited athletic facilities eveningnight campus considerations external monitoring procedurestechnology closed circuit television doorwindow security visitor management systems storage areas for devices intrusion alarm system masterroom key controls and the use of technology What are the terms of the proposed agreement This contract is a onetime fourmonth contract funded under the Common Core Technology Project and funded through Bond dollars If you have any questions or require additional information please contact me at stevenzippermanlausdnet or at Prepared by Deputy Chief Jose Santome he may be reached at josesantomelausdnet or c Michelle King Matt Hill David Holmquist Enrique Boullt Gerardo Loera Jefferson Crain George Silva Mark Hovatter cidcidcidcid Members Board of Education Dr John E Deasy Superintendent January What are the terms of the proposed agreement The terms of the current master agreement is for a fiveyear period commencing January and ending January which includes two oneyear options The estimated annual contract value is million and the aggregate contract value for the fiveyear period is not to exceed million Purchases are funded from individual school and office budgets and include various sources of funding If you have any questions please contact George Silva at c Michelle King Enrique Boullt Matt Hill Jaime Aquino David Holmquist Jefferson Crain TAB
