the period of November to December is of which are rehires or reassignments and are new hires With the exception of assignments all of the actions are for positions which are schoolbased or provide direct support to the schools or their operations Teacher Assistant positions although unclassified are included in the data as they are indicated as classified in the BTS system and they are processed by the Personnel Commission All new hires to regularpermanent positions are for A or C basis positions The new hires consist of a Heating and Air Conditioning Fitter Maintenance Worker ANGELES UNIFIED SCHOOL DISTRICT Board of Education Report SUMMARY OF CHARTER SCHOOL PERFORMANCE BIRMINGHAM COMMUNITY CHARTER HIGH SCHOOL BOARD OF EDUCATION REPORT January The Charter Schools Division has analyzed the performance of the charter school using established criteria in the following four areas I Student Achievement and Educational Performance II Governance and Organizational Management III Fiscal Operations IV Fulfillment of the Charters Educational Program I Student Achievement and Educational Performance First the Charter Schools Division must confirm whether the charter school has met at least one of the following minimum criteria set forth in Education Code b for schools in operation at least four years Attained its Academic Performance Index API growth target in the prior year or in two of the last three years both schoolwide and for all groups of pupils served by the charter school or Ranked in deciles to inclusive on the API in the prior year or in two of the last three years or Ranked in deciles to inclusive on the API for a demographically comparable school in the prior year or in two of the last three years or A The entity that granted the charter determines that the academic performance of the charter school is at least equal to the academic performance of the public schools that the charter school pupils would otherwise have been required to attend as well as the academic performance of the schools in the school district in which the charter school is located taking into account the composition of the pupil population that is served at the charter school B The determination made pursuant to this paragraph shall be based upon all of the following i Documented and clear and convincing data ii Pupil achievement data from assessments including but not limited to the Standardized Testing and Reporting Program established by Article commencing with Section for demographically similar pupil populations in the comparison schools iii Information submitted by the charter school Note If a charter school has not been in operation for at least four years this section of Education Code serves as reference The Charter Schools Division will present findings based on its analysis of the schools performance data to date and of the academic operational and fiscal soundness of the charter school based on Charter Schools Division oversight Bd of Ed Rpt No Page of Board of Education January LOS ANGELES UNIFIED SCHOOL DISTRICT Board of Education Report Birmingham Community Charter High School has met the minimum statutory requirement as evidenced in the Data Summary Report Student Discipline Discipline and expulsion policies used at District schools must comply with the California Education Code LAUSD charter schools must comply with the provisions related to suspensions and expulsions that are put forth in the Charter Schools Divisions Required Language for Charter Petitions Birmingham Community Charter High Schools grounds for student suspension and expulsion are aligned with those listed in Education Code Section et seq As the data below shows BCCHS had suspensions and expulsions for the school year In the school reported suspensions and expulsion As of the date of this report the school reports suspensions and expulsion for the current school year The school has prioritized having a safe and positive school climate through a focus on prevention and with programs to meet the social needs of students The schools agreement with the Office for Civil Rights and Uniform Complaint Procedures represent Birminghams commitment to provide a learning environment that is free from discrimination and harassment including in their discipline practices The school has established a Birmingham Opportunity Center BOC for students referred via the Student Study Team who are behind in credits are underachieving academically have poor attendance or are exhibiting behavior problems The opportunity program offers an alternative educational track for students who could benefit from remediation Partnerships with community agencies such as Hathaway House provide wraparound services to Birminghams students and families with free on and off campus counseling opportunities In addition a schoolbased Probation Officer coordinates an intervention program for students identified as being atrisk SUSPENSIONEXPULSION School Location Code Suspension As of the date of this report Expulsion As of the date of this report Suspension Expulsion Suspension Expulsion Birmingham Community Charter Special Education According to the December CASEMIS report Birmingham Community Charter High School enrolled Special Education students at a rate that is reflective of the District average Birmingham had a special education enrollment rate of which mirrors the Comparison Schools Median The school is committed to continuing its efforts to identify and serve students with disabilities The school provides both strategic and intensive targeted intervention as needed for students The school reports improving student achievement by examining student assessment data frequently within all departments to check for understanding and respond appropriately through dataproven instructional strategies to address learning gaps BCCHS employs a full time Social Worker two School Psychologists Multiple Bd of Ed Rpt No Page of Board of Education January LOS ANGELES UNIFIED SCHOOL DISTRICT Board of Education Report Resource and Special Day Class Teachers andor Paraprofessionals and a Counseling Staff of eight to support and manage the schools Special Education program Learners with special needs are provided with interventions at increasing levels of intensity to accelerate their rate of learning Progress is closely monitored to assess both the learning rate and level of performance of individual students Particularly through the IEP process the school provides parents information about their childs progress the instruction and interventions used the staff who are delivering the instruction and the academic goals for their child OCT Enroll d E p S l l o r n E d E p S l l o r n E h g i H e in Charter Median District Birmingham Community Charter High Resident Schools Median Comparison Schools in Charter Median District EVALUATION VISIT RESULTS EL Reclassified Reclassification Rate EL Reclassified Reclassification Rate Following are definitions of the School Performance Evaluation ratings An evaluation of accomplished applies to operations characterized overall by strengths There are very few weaknesses and any that do exist do not diminish the students experience While an evaluation of accomplished represents a high standard of operating it is a standard that should be achievable in all schools It implies that it is fully appropriate for a school to continue its operations without significant adjustment The school would always be expected however to continue to take advantage of opportunities to improve An evaluation of proficient applies to operations characterized by a number of strengths There are weaknesses but neither singly nor collectively do these have a significant adverse impact on the student experience An evaluation of proficient may be arrived at in a number of circumstances The school may provide a productive student experience but it may not provide consistent challenge for students Typically operations will be characterized by strengths but one or more weaknesses reduce the overall quality of the student experience An evaluation of developing applies to operations characterized by weaknesses which require remedial action by the school Some if not all staff responsible for the operation evaluated as inadequate require support from senior managers in planning and carrying out the necessary actions to effect improvement There may be some strengths but these are overshadowed by the impact of the weaknesses An evaluation of unsatisfactory applies when there are major weaknesses in operation that require immediate remedial action on the part of the school The student experience is at risk in significant respects In almost all cases staff responsible for operations evaluated unsatisfactory will require support from senior managers in planning and carrying out the necessary actions to effect improvement This may involve working alongside effective peers in or beyond the school Bd of Ed Rpt No Page of Board of Education January LOS ANGELES UNIFIED SCHOOL DISTRICT Board of Education Report I Student Achievement and Educational Performance Charter Schools Division oversight deemed Student Achievement and Educational Performance at the school to be Developing Areas of particular strength include The schoolwide API of showed an increase of points from For the last three consecutive years BCCHS met their schoolwide API growth targets In th grade CAHSEE passage rates reflect in ELA and in Math The school earned a cohort graduation rate of The school achieved a Similar Schools Ranking of Areas recommended for improvement include Based on the school not meeting AYP criteria for all statistically significant subgroups and not meeting API growth targets for English Learners the school is encouraged to strengthen its instructional program to ensure academic program benefits all students II Governance and Organizational Management Charter Schools Division oversight deemed Governance and Organizational Management at the school to be Proficient Areas of particular strength include The school leader has a strategic view of the direction of the work and development of the school in order to achieve the schools goals Examples include an inclusive and positive school culture increased operational transparency targeted professional development to increase calibration and effectiveness tracking of student progress postBCCHS school enrollment and the use of data to inform instructional practices Parent and community involvement is encouraged through a variety of efforts including an interactive website Aeries Parent Portal access to student informationteachersteacher grade books an electronic marquee staff email Connect Ed phone messaging system a parent outreach center parent institute classes and coffee with the principal meetings School Board members report receiving regular communication from the CEO and CBO to enable them to monitor school performance and the school budget This was further supported during document review of Board meeting agendas which regularly agendize the sharing of fiscal and operational updates School Board members demonstrated awareness of the academic outcomes which reflect school wide performance They identified the increase in the schools API as encouraging news They shared that Math and English are areas for further growth as well as English Learner and SPED subgroup performance The governing Board has prioritized the fiscal soundness of the school by building a solid fiscal reserve Bd of Ed Rpt No Page of Board of Education January LOS ANGELES UNIFIED SCHOOL DISTRICT Board of Education Report The school provided evidence that Board members have been Brown Act trained Additional training on how to be a more effective Board has been scheduled for November Areas recommended for improvement include School leadership is aware of the need to further develop Human Resources systems and procedures The governing Board shall continue to ensure that issues related to the Office for Civil Rights OCR agreement are closely monitored for compliance The school Board is also encouraged to develop greater clarity on the roles between the school Board and school management III Fiscal Operations Charter Schools Division oversight deemed Fiscal Operations at the school to be Proficient Areas of particular strength Per audit o The school is showing a positive trend in both net income and net assets o All ratios calculate within the recommended ratio o Unqualified opinion o No deficiencies findings material weaknesses The school has School Site Fiscal Policies and Procedures Enrollment over the last three years is stable The norm enrollment is Charter Management Organization is strong fiscally The audit shows a total combined Net Assets of M Areas recommended for improvement include The June bank reconciliations show combined total of Balance Per Book of Cash and Cash Equivalents of The audit shows Cash and Cash Equivalent Needs further review Revisit assumptions use in projections interim reports show variances between reporting periods There are differences between the Unaudited Actuals submitted to LAUSD compared to the report presented to the Audit Committee on February The minutes need to clarify if there were revisions prior presentations IV Fulfillment of the Charters Educational Program Charter Schools Division oversight deemed Fulfillment of the Charters Educational Program at the school to be Proficient Areas of particular strength include The school has created a number of Small Learning Communities SLCs including Medical Academy with ScienceHealth MASH Social Justice Academy Performing and Visual Arts Bd of Ed Rpt No Page of Board of Education January LOS ANGELES UNIFIED SCHOOL DISTRICT Board of Education Report Academy Business and Technology Academy Freshman Academy and Creative and Liberal Arts Academy School has established a Common Core partnership with LACOE for the training of all instructional staff and has initiated schoolwide writing strategies The school offers a Freshman Seminar course to help transition new students into high school by addressing concepts such as academics socialemotional needs and ethical behaviors performance and practices The school has established a Birmingham Opportunity Center BOC for students referred via the Student Study Team who are behind in credits are underachieving academically have poor attendance or are exhibiting poor behavior The opportunity program offers an alternative educational track and credit recovery for students who could benefit from remediation The school has a designated Instructional Coordinator in collaboration with department leads who provides expertise and support to SLCs for reflection and improvements to instructional strategies and outcomes This also helps facilitate differentiation to meet the various needs of their students Areas noted for improvement include The school is encouraged to continue to monitor the implementation of Learning Targets Checking for Understanding and Higher Levels of Questioning to ensure greater consistency in the use of these strategies across classrooms The CSD recommends continuing to explore strategies that increase student engagement and reduces teacher talk School is encouraged to consider implementing some of the Project Based Learning activities currently prevalent in electives courses into the core content classes to increase engagement and rigor Bd of Ed Rpt No Page of Board of Education January Birmingham Community Charter High Loc Code CDS Code CRITERIA SUMMARY A charter school that has operated for at least four years is eligible for renewal only if the school has satisfied at least one of the following criteria prior to receiving a charter renewal Attained its Academic Performance Index API growth target in the prior year or in two of the last three years both school wide and for all groups of pupils served by the charter school ranked to on the API statewide or similar schools rank in the prior year or in two of the last three years both schoolwide and for all groups of pupils served by the charter school SB The academic performance of the charter school must be at least equal to the academic performance of the public schools that the charter school pupils would otherwise have been required to attend as well as the academic performance of the schools in the school district in which the charter school is located taking into account the composition of pupil population served at the charter school Ed Code Schoolwide Academic Performance Index API Base API Growth each specified year The numbers used are from the Language Census collected by the state each March The reclassification rate is calculated by dividing the number reclassified by the number of prior ANGELES UNIFIED SCHOOL DISTRICT Board of Education Report SUMMARY OF CHARTER SCHOOL PERFORMANCE THE ACCELERATED SCHOOL TAS BOARD OF EDUCATION REPORT January The Charter Schools Division has analyzed the performance of the charter school using established criteria in the following four areas I Student Achievement and Educational Performance II Governance and Organizational Management III Fiscal Operations IV Fulfillment of the Charters Educational Program I Student Achievement and Educational Performance First the Charter Schools Division must confirm whether the charter school has met at least one of the following minimum criteria set forth in Education Code b for schools in operation at least four years Attained its Academic Performance Index API growth target in the prior year or in two of the last three years both schoolwide and for all groups of pupils served by the charter school or Ranked in deciles to inclusive on the API in the prior year or in two of the last three years or Ranked in deciles to inclusive on the API for a demographically comparable school in the prior year or in two of the last three years or A The entity that granted the charter determines that the academic performance of the charter school is at least equal to the academic performance of the public schools that the charter school pupils would otherwise have been required to attend as well as the academic performance of the schools in the school district in which the charter school is located taking into account the composition of the pupil population that is served at the charter school B The determination made pursuant to this paragraph shall be based upon all of the following i Documented and clear and convincing data ii Pupil achievement data from assessments including but not limited to the Standardized Testing and Reporting Program established by Article commencing with Section for demographically similar pupil populations in the comparison schools iii Information submitted by the charter school Note If a charter school has not been in operation for at least four years this section of Education Code serves as reference The Charter Schools Division will present findings based on its analysis of the schools performance data to date and of the academic operational and fiscal soundness of the charter school based on Charter Schools Division oversight Bd of Ed expulsion policies used at District schools must comply with the California Education Code LAUSD charter schools must comply with the provisions related to suspensions and expulsions that are put forth in the Charter Schools Divisions Required Language for Charter Petitions The Accelerated Schools grounds for student suspension and expulsion are aligned with those listed in Education Code Section et seq As the data below shows The Accelerated School had suspensions and expulsions for the school year In the school reported suspensions and expulsions As of the date of this report the school report suspensions and expulsions for the current school year The school reports that it has recently revised its suspension and expulsion policies and procedures to ensure a more cohesive the December CASEMIS report The Accelerated School enrolled Special Education students at a rate similar to the District average The Accelerated School had a special education enrollment rate of which was three percentage points lower than the LAUSD Similar Schools from CDE Median The school is committed to continuing its efforts to identify and serve students with disabilities The school provides both strategic and intensive targeted intervention as needed for students Multiple forms of interventions include Saturday school tutoring small group differentiated instruction in grades K grade offers an intervention during th period and finally a coteaching model exists between general education teachers and RSP teachers OCT Enroll d E p S l l o r n E d E p S l l o r n E h g i H e c n e d i District The Accelerated School LAUSD Similar Schools from CDE Median Resident Schools Median Comparison Schools in Charter Median District EVALUATION VISIT RESULTS LOS ANGELES UNIFIED SCHOOL DISTRICT Board of Education Report EL Reclassified EL Reclassified Reclassification Rate Reclassification Rate Following are definitions of the School Performance Evaluation ratings An evaluation of accomplished applies to operations characterized overall by strengths There are very few weaknesses and any that do exist do not diminish the students experience While an evaluation of accomplished represents a high standard of operating it is a standard that should be achievable in all schools It implies that it is fully appropriate for a school to continue its operations without significant adjustment The school would always be expected however to continue to take advantage of opportunities to improve An evaluation of proficient applies to operations characterized by a number of strengths There are weaknesses but neither singly nor collectively do these have a significant adverse impact on the student experience An evaluation of proficient may be arrived at in a number of circumstances The school may provide a productive student experience but it may not provide consistent challenge for students Typically operations will be characterized by strengths but one or more weaknesses reduce the overall quality of the student experience An evaluation of developing applies to operations characterized by weaknesses which require remedial action by the school Some if not all staff responsible for the operation evaluated as inadequate require support from senior managers in planning and carrying out the necessary actions to effect improvement There may be some strengths but these are overshadowed by the impact of the weaknesses An evaluation of unsatisfactory applies when there are major weaknesses in operation that require immediate remedial action on the part of the school The student experience is at risk in significant respects In almost all cases staff responsible for operations evaluated unsatisfactory will require support from senior managers in planning and carrying out the necessary actions to effect improvement This may involve working alongside effective peers in or beyond the school Bd of Ed Rpt No Page of Board of Education January LOS ANGELES UNIFIED SCHOOL DISTRICT Board of Education Report Charter Schools Division oversight deemed Student Achievement and Educational Performance at the school to be Proficient I Governance and Organizational Management Charter Schools Division oversight deemed Governance and Organizational Management at the school to be Proficient Areas of particular strength include Interviews with different stakeholders served as evidence that the governing board has an established system that regularly monitors clear policies and procedures providing all stakeholders effective and appropriate complaint procedures and due process Documents shared at the time of the visit served as evidence that the governing board has an established system that consistently monitors policies and procedures to ensure health and safety for all students and staff including but not limited to school safety plan and training regarding child abuse awareness and bloodborne pathogens II Student Achievement and Educational Performance Charter Schools Division oversight deemed Student Achievement and Educational Performance Management at the school to be Proficient Areas of particular strength include Academic Performance for the past three years show TAS increasing from API up to API a total of points CST trends indicate the percentage of students scoring Proficient and Advanced have been increasing for the last three years in ELA and Math Areas noted for improvement include CDE Data shows targets for both Latino and that TAS met growth Socioeconomically Disadvantaged subgroups but did not meet the goal for EL students The school leadership would benefit from exploring ways to ensure all subgroups meet growth targets especially EL Students III Organizational Management and Operations Charter Schools Division oversight deemed Organizational Management and Operations at the school to be Proficient Areas of particular strength include Classroom visits student interviews and staff interviews showed that the school consistently collects monitors and analyzes student grade and school level performance data to inform and instructional decision making eg development of PD resource allocation evaluate intervention etc Bd of Ed Rpt No Page of Board of Education January LOS ANGELES UNIFIED SCHOOL DISTRICT Board of Education Report Interview with leadership a review of agendas and classroom visits served as evidence that the school has an established system in place and consistently monitors the procedures to comply with the Modified Consent Decree The school actively identifies students with disabilities or suspected disabilities assesses them promptly develops IEPs as necessary in a timely manner provides Special Education services and supports in accordance with students IEPs and maintains current and accurate records in Welligent School leadership implements the Discipline Foundation Policy including alternatives to suspension and consistently provides adequate due process for suspensions and expulsions IV Fiscal Operations Charter Schools Division oversight deemed Fiscal Operations at the school to be Proficient Areas of particular strength include Cash and cash equivalents of are positive This generates a cash reserve of which is well above the recommended reserve of This financial area has remained positive from Audit for states positive net income is Fiscal years through showed negative net income This is the first time in four years the schools expenditures have not exceeded its revenue Net assets are positive Financial trend analysis shows the schools net assets have continuously remained positive since fiscal year to Net assets include a capitalized lease on their building The building is leased from LAUSD for per year Areas recommended for improvement include None noted Bd of Ed Rpt No Page of Board of Education January Accelerated Loc Code CDS Code CRITERIA SUMMARY A charter school that has operated for at least four years is eligible for renewal only if the school has satisfied at least one of the following criteria prior to receiving a charter renewal Attained its Academic Performance Index API growth target in the prior year or in two of the last three years both school wide and for all groups of pupils served by the charter school ranked to on the API statewide or similar schools district in which the charter school is located taking into account the composition of pupil population served at the charter school Ed Code Schoolwide Academic Performance Index API Base API Growth cidcidcidcidcidcidcidcid cidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcid cidcidcidcidcidcid cidcidcid cidcid cidcidcidcidcidcidcid cidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcid cidcidcidcid cidcidcidcid cidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcid cidcidcidcidcidcidcidcid cidcidcidcid cidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcid cidcidcid cidcidcidcidcidcidcidcid cidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcid cidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcid cidcidcidcidcidcidcidcid cidcidcid cidcid cidcidcidcidcidcidcidcid cidcidcidcidcidcidcid cidcidcidcidcidcid cidcidcidcidcidcidcidcid cidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcid cidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcid cidcidcidcidcidcidcidcid cidcidcidcidcidcidcidcid cidcidcidcid cidcidcidcidcidcidcid cidcidcidcid cidcidcidcid cidcidcidcidcidcidcidcid cidcidcid cidcidcidcid cidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcid cidcidcidcidcidcid cidcidcid cidcidcidcidcidcidcidcid cidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcid cidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcid cidcidcidcidcidcidcidcid cidcidcidcidcid cidcidcidcidcid cid cidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcid cidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcid cid cidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcid cidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcid cidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcid cid cidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcid cidcidcidcidcid cidcidcidcid cidcidcidcidcidcidcidcid cidcidcidcidcid cidcidcidcid cidcidcid cidcidcidcidcid cidcidcidcidcidcidcid cidcidcid cidcidcidcid cidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcid cidcidcidcidcidcid cidcid cidcidcid cidcidcidcidcid cidcidcidcid cidcidcidcid cidcidcidcidcidcidcid cidcidcid cidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcid cidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcid cidcidcidcidcidcidcidcid cidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcid I N F O R M A T I V E WEST ACADEMIC LEADERSHIP ACADEMY CHARTER SCHOOL PETITION Findings of Fact for Denial of Petition By the Los Angeles Unified School District BOARD OF EDUCATION REPORT January The charter review process requires the authorizer to evaluate whether the charter petition meets the criteria for approval Education Code b states the required petition elements and conditions for denial Education Code outlines additional petition criteria I INTRODUCTION On October WEST Academic Leadership Academy WALA or Charter School submitted a charter school petition application to the Charter Schools Division of the Los Angeles Unified School District District or LAUSD The proposed school seeks to serve students in grades in Southwest Los Angeles in Board District or California Education Code b provides that a school district governing board shall grant a charter for the operation of a school under this part if it is satisfied that granting the charter is consistent with sound educational practice Education Code b further provides that the governing board of the school district shall not deny a petition for the establishment of a charter school unless it makes written factual findings specific to the particular petition setting forth specific facts to support one or more of the following findings The charter school presents an unsound educational program for the pupils to be enrolled in the charter school The petitioners are demonstrably unlikely to successfully implement the program set forth in the petition The petition does not contain the number of signatures required by subdivision a of Education Code The petition does not contain an affirmation of each of the conditions described in subdivision d of Education Code The petition does not contain a reasonably comprehensive description of all required elements The petition for WALA does not meet the criteria under Education Code b II GROUNDS FOR DENIAL LAUSDs analysis of the charter school petition submitted on or about October to the District by WALA indicates A The petitioners are demonstrably unlikely to successfully implement the program set forth in the petition for WALA Educ Code b The nonprofit corporation that is identified as the governing entity for the charter school CHOSEN Leadership Institute Inc has been suspended as shown on the CA Secretary of State website and petitioners have not provided any evidence to the contrary The petitioners have presented an unrealistic financial and operational plan o The Charter Schools planning budget assumes receipt of the Public Charter School Grant Programs PCSGP planning and implementation award of year and year Since the Charter Schools budget assumes the Charter Schools receipt of the PCSGP award and the Charter School does not include an alternative funding plan the petitioners therefore have not demonstrated their ability to successfully implement the Charter Schools program o The Charter Schools multiyear budget includes receipt of StartUp Capital year one Fundraising over three years and Private FoundationGrant over three years without providing sufficient details regarding the sources of these local revenues or any evidence demonstrating that such funding will actually be available to the Charter School Since these revenue amounts represent a significant portion of the Charter Schools budget totaling in year one and the Charter School relies on these unidentified local revenue sources for its startup funding the petitioners therefore have not demonstrated their ability to successfully operate the School o Charter School does not demonstrate how it will fund technology equipment even though technology will be an integral part of its educational program and used widely as part of the Charter Schools educational program For instance the petition states that students will use laptops or computer stations at school and teachers will be providedloanedequipped with a laptop but the Charter Schools multiyear budget does not specifically include expenditures for such equipment B The WALA petition does not contain a reasonably comprehensive description of all required elements Educ Code b Description of the Schools Educational Program Element The petition does not contain a reasonably comprehensive description of the charter schools educational program o The petition fails to provide sufficient description of the components features or structure of the proposed program variously termed online hybrid and independent study to allow LAUSD to conduct a comprehensive evaluation of the proposed program It further states that WEST Academic Leadership Academy can operate the independent study school program as a school program within a school or as a standalone alternative school of choice or charter school o The petition does not provide a comprehensive description of its flexible scheduling model approach which requires student to be in attendance either in the on ground hybrid or online format at least of the statutory instructional minutes or how the model will provide sufficient instructional minutes be monitored or otherwise provide a sound educational program o The petition does not contain reasonably comprehensive descriptions of instruction supports and interventions for English Learners students with disabilities and students who are socioeconomically disadvantaged For example the petition does not comprehensively describe how the school will meet the needs of English Learners Instead it only provides the following summary statement which demonstrates a lack of awareness about individual student needs and the schools responsibility to ensure a quality program for each student Should WEST Academic Leadership Academy have a high percentage of students who are classified as English Language Learners it is fully prepared to address their specific needs o The Charter School does not assure in the petition that it will comply with applicable requirements regarding transitional kindergarten o The petition does not describe the Charter Schools obligations regarding students with special education needs in a manner consistent with LAUSD policies and procedures For instance the petition insufficiently describes the provision of special education services and supports for students with disabilities including the acquisition of support providers the development of Individual Transition Plans the Student Success Team process and the Response to Intervention process for general education and special education o The petition does not address Common Core State Standards or California MAPP assessments except for a summary statement that they will be implemented Measurable Pupil Outcomes Element The petition does not contain a reasonably comprehensive description of measurable pupil outcomes o The WALA petition fails to clearly and comprehensively describe measurable student outcomes For example the petition provides that WALA participants will exceed the average performance levels of students in comparable public schools as measured by math and English scoresacademic grades Not only does it omit any mention of the California MAPP assessment program elsewhere the petition refers to the nowobsolete STAR Tests as one of two sources of data the school will use The petition also identifies as comparable schools a string of schools that are almost all located in Inglewood Unified School District or Culver City Unified School District This lack of focus on a specific location or neighborhood located within the jurisdiction of LAUSD reflects petitioners failure to identify a target address or location for the school beyond Southwest Los Angeles Methods to Assess Pupil Progress toward Outcomes Element The petition does not contain a reasonably comprehensive description of methods to assess pupil progress toward outcomes o The petition fails to describe internal assessments benchmarks or tiered interventions and provide a comprehensive description of interventions Governance Structure Element The petition does not contain a reasonably comprehensive description of the charter schools governance structure o The Charter School does not describe sufficient assurance that the Charter School will comply with the Brown Act While the petition specifies that the Charter School will comply with the Brown Act the CHOSEN Leadership Institute Incs corporate boards Bylaws allow the corporate board to operate in a manner which is inconsistent with the requirements of the Brown Act For instance the Bylaws allow board meetings to be held without notice and allow the board to take action without a meeting if all members consent to such action o The Charter Schools corporate board Bylaws submitted with the petition allow for practices that may run contrary to conflict of interest laws including Government Code et seq and LAUSD policy For instance the Bylaws allow up to of the board of trustees to be interested persons which includes any person who is currently compensated by the corporation for services rendered to the corporation within the previous twelve months The Bylaws also allow board members to receive compensation from the corporation for services if they abstain from voting on matters pertaining to their compensation These practices allowed by the Bylaws may conflict with the restrictions of Government Code et seq and LAUSD policy o The petition does not sufficiently demonstrate the relationship of the Charter Schools governing board to the leadership of the Charter School and any relevant site committees in the organizational charts provided in the petition Specifically the petition references an Advisory Board that will make recommendations to the Charter Schools management team but this site committee is not included in the organizational chart o The petition does not provide a reasonably comprehensive description of the responsibilities of the charter schools corporate governing board related to the operation of the Charter School While the petition states that the Charter Schools independent study program will be governed by CHOSEN Inc it states that the corporations management team is prepared to be responsible for the policy setting decisions in the limited areas specified However the Charter School does not identify who is part of the management team or definitively specify what their governance responsibilities will include The petition is similarly vague regarding the governance responsibilities of the Director and provides no description of what the charter school board will do to ensure accountability of the Director related to the operation of the Charter School This is especially crucial given that the Director will help manage all the shared resources of the Charter School Employee Qualifications Element The petition does not contain a reasonably comprehensive description of employee qualifications o The petition states the Charter School will rely heavily on college instructors and independent study expertsconsultants to supplement its teacher talent pool but does not describe the qualifications of the individuals who fall within these categories o While the Charter School will integrate technology as part of its educational program and will widely use technology to drive higher levels of achievement and prepare students for the information driven economy of the st Century it confusingly will not require technological experience as a required qualification for teacher applicants o The petition incorrectly states that all fulltime certificated and classified staff employed at the Charter School shall have the same rights and benefits as covered faculty and staff in LAUSD o The petition states that the Charter Schools Administrative staff will be trained on and have access to School Pathways an online dataattendance processing program but in its discussion of the Charter Schools data management plan the petition inconsistently states that the Charter School is only considering utilizing School Pathways o The petition does not sufficiently describe who evaluates each category of employees working at the Charter School Health and Safety Procedures Element The petition does not contain a reasonably comprehensive description of the charter schools health and safety procedures o The petition contains background checks inconsistent assurances regarding employee criminal Means to Achieve a Reflective Racial and Ethnic Balance Element The petition does not present a reasonably comprehensive description of means for achieving racial and ethic balance o The petition does not describe the Charter Schools annual outreach efforts for achieving and maintaining a racial and ethnic balance among its students that is reflective of the general population residing within the territorial jurisdiction of LAUSD For instance there is no description of the methods the Charter School will use to advertise and recruit students and no description of the geographic areas that will be targeted in its outreach effort Admission Procedures Element The petition does not present a reasonably comprehensive description of admission requirements o The Charter Schools admission procedures may run contrary to the legal requirement that the Charter School shall admit all students who wish to attend For instance the petition states that students shall have the right to attend the Charter School if they fulfill all admission and application criteria Among other things the Charter School requires all applicants to submit a California community college admissions application to be admitted This admission requirement may have the effect of denying admission to some students who do not or cannot submit a college admissions application but otherwise desire to attend the Charter School o The petition does not include any description of the manner in which the Charter School will implement a public random drawing process in the event that applications for enrollment exceed school capacity Among other deficiencies the petition does not describe the methods the Charter School will use to communicate to all interested parties the rules to be followed during the lottery does not specify the location and the time the lottery will occur so the most interested parties will be able to attend and does not describe the preferences to be granted to certain students in the lottery Annual Independent Financial Audits Element The petition does not present a reasonably comprehensive description of annual independent financial audits o The petition does not specify who is responsible for contracting and overseeing annual independent financial audits and fails to specify that the auditor whom the Charter School will contract with to conduct an independent audit will have experience in education finance o The petition does not describe the plans and systems to be used by the Charter School to provide information for an independent audit o The petition does not describe the process the Charter School will follow to address any audit findings andor resolve any audit exceptions including the timelines by which annual audit exceptions will typically be resolved by the Charter School Suspension and Expulsion Procedures Element The petition does not present a reasonably comprehensive description of student suspension and expulsion procedures o The petition does not provide a reasonably comprehensive description of the Charter Schools student suspension and expulsion procedures For instance the petition fails to identify any offenses for which students may be disciplined fails to identify any student suspension and expulsion procedures and fails to address student expulsion appeal rights Clearly describedoutlined procedures are necessary to avoid inconsistent capricious and unfair student disciplinary practices and necessary to afford students adequate due process TAB O R M A T I V E Board of Education Report No For January Board Meeting INTEROFFICE CORRESPONDENCE Los Angeles Unified School District Office of the Superintendent TO Members Board of Education Dr John E Deasy Superintendent FROM Edgar Zazueta Chief of Staff External Relations SUBJECT Legislative Proposals Board Report INFORMATIVE DATE January Board Report includes the proposed list of LAUSDs sponsored bill proposals for The proposed list submitted for your approval is a compilation of the requests that were submitted to our office by District leadership The Office of Government Relations began the formulation process this past fall by giving all Board local district and leadership offices the opportunity to submit legislative proposals for review Our memorandum asked LAUSD offices to identify pressing and relevant issues that require statutory changes in The proposed list does not intend to capture all of the LAUSD legislative priorities for Similar to previous years our attention will continue to be focused on state budgetary issues The state budget development process differs from the traditional legislative process and it is therefore unnecessary to request legislators to introduce bill proposals on every budgetary priority The Office of Government Relations will respond to unforeseen issues that will develop throughout the year The priorities and actions of the office will be guided by the adopted policies of the Board of Education as well as stated priorities of the Superintendent The Districts advocacy team will strive to inform the Board of Education of the most relevant issues as they develop throughout the year Please do not hesitate to contact us should you have further questions If you have any questions please contact me at c Michelle King David CORRESPONDENCE Los Angeles Unified School District Office of the Superintendent TO Members Board of Education Dr John E Deasy Superintendent FROM Donna E Muncey PhD Chief of Intensive Support and Intervention INFORMATIVE DATE December SUBJECT CLASS SIZE REDUCTION CSR WAIVER FOR REGULAR QUALITY EDUCATION INVESTMENT ACT QEIA SCHOOLS After determining that the majority of QEIA schools would not meet class size reduction targets by the end of the District staff received approval from the Los Angeles Board of Education to submit CSR waivers to the State Board of Education SBE The waiver requested relief from the CSR targets retroactively from July through the duration of the QEIA program Although the CSR waivers were approved by the SBE at the following CSR targets to for grades K to for grades the California Department of Education CDE would not recommend approval of waiver for the duration of the QEIA program Instead CDE recommended a twoyear approval of the waiver The SBE followed the recommendation of CDE and granted the District a twoyear waiver which will come to its conclusion at the end of the academic year On behalf of the QEIA schools the Office of Intensive Support and Intervention would like to submit renewal waivers to ensure participation in the program through the academic year A historical progression of the QEIA waiver application is as follows September Consulted with United Teachers Los Angeles leadership regarding the Districts need to file CSR waivers November Received Los Angeles Board of Education approval to submit CSR waivers to CDE and SBE Federal and State Education Programs wrote the waiver on behalf of the QEIA schools December Submitted CSR waivers to CDE for review Members Board of Education Dr John E Deasy Superintendent December March Received SBE approval of CSR waivers for September Received notification from LACOE to submit renewal waivers to CDE for November Consult with United Teachers Los Angeles leadership regarding the Districts need to file renewal CSR waivers January Submit CSR waivers to CDE for review May Receive SBE approval of CSR renewal waivers for If you have any questions please contact Superintendent DATE FROM Tony Atienza Director Budget Services and Financial Planning SUBJECT Investing Priorities for Equitable Learning Environments for all LAUSD Students BUDGET IMPACT STATEMENT Budget Impact Prioritize stabilizing schools rehiring staff to fill needed positions and restoring programs as the first round of LCFF funding is delivered to the District and the Superintendent delivers budget priorities to the Board No budget impact since this resolve is only asking the Superintendent to prioritize the funding we receive Increase student achievement and graduation No budget impact the assumption is that we will use available funding to increase student achievement Reduction of Staffing Ratios to National Averages Elementary Class Size Middle Class Size High School Class Size Counselor Administrator Ratios Clerical Ratios Classified Ratios National Averages Unknown Unknown Change in Staffing Required to Achieve Ratio FTEs FTEs FTEs FTEs FTEs Unknown Unknown Cost based on average salary benefits million million million million million Unknown Unknown Eliminate Statutory Rehiring Lists Return Severed Employees Working in Temporary Status to Permanent Status Implementation time frame directly impacts the cost to eliminate current statutory rehire lists as normal employee attrition via retirements and other departures are backfilled with employees from the rehire list over time thereby reducing the cost to rehire the remaining employees on the list Assuming the current lists were retired today the costs are reflected below Estimated cost to eliminate current Human Resources rehiring lists is million restoring positions Estimated cost to eliminate current Personnel Commission rehiring lists is million restoring positions The cost to return severed employees working in temporary status is included in the costs above since these employees are on the rehire lists being eliminated There will be an unknown budget impact related to daytoday substitutes as a result of teachers moving out of the substitute pool while demand for substitute teachers across the district may remain constant increase or decrease Increase Student Staff and Community Safety in and around school communities As a guiding principle this item has no cost unless a specific action is taken to augment or enhance staffing or services Those costs will be identified in the Budget Impact Statement attached to a resolution or Board Report when the action is taken by the Board Incremental salary restoration equivalent to COLA of and develop a strategy for districtwide restoration over time with bargaining unit partners A increase in salaries would cost approximately million at full implementation and would be an ongoing annual increase in operating costs Incremental implementation of a compensation increase would incur a portion of the million total cost each year and ongoing until full implementation of the total million increase is achieved The cost increase in each year of a phased implementation plan will depend on the timeline identified for implementation Seek input on funding priorities from parents students staff and community members and bargaining units Develop immediate funding priorities should LCFF funding be released in FY This information has already been gathered by Budget Services and Financial Planning in response to Board Resolution To Engage the Los Angeles Unified School District Community and Establish Fiscal Priorities Telephone Email TonyAtienzalausdnet Contact Person Tony Atienza Class size is available in the NCES data set other ratios are currently available for Includes only Principals and Assistant Principals A comparison to national clerical ratios is not possible because NCES data aggregate school district administrative support staff school and library support staff student support staff and other support services staff into a single ratio whereas LAUSD clerical ratios are solely schoollevel clerical staff ratios A national average for classified staff to student ratio could not be identified Source National Center for Education Statistics Table Table cidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcidcid TAB Board Member Resolution For Action Ms Garcia Ms Galatzan Dr Vladovic Celebration of Black History Month Whereas Carter G Woodson a Harvardtrained historian like WEB Du Bois before him believed that truth would not be denied and that reason would prevail over prejudice and as a result announced Negro History Week in to raise the awareness of the contributions of African Americans Whereas The first event was celebrated during a week in February encompassing the birthdays of Abraham Lincoln and Frederick Douglas two key figures in the history of African Americans Whereas When this week was officially established in the Library of Congress National Archives and Records Administration National Endowment for the Humanities National Gallery of Art National Park Service Smithsonian Institution and United States Holocaust Memorial Museum joined in to pay official tribute to the generations of African Americans who struggled with adversity to achieve full citizenship in American society Whereas this year marks the th anniversary of Freedom Summer a voter registration project in Mississippi part of a larger effort by civil rights groups such as the Congress on Racial Equality CORE and the Student NonViolent Coordinating Committee SNCC to expand black voting in the South Whereas this year also marks the th anniversary of The Civil Rights Act of the nations benchmark civil rights legislation that prohibits discrimination on the basis of race color religion sex or national origin Passage of the Act ended the application of Jim Crow laws in which the Court held that racial segregation purported to be separate but equal was constitutional Whereas The Governing Board of the Los Angeles Unified School District stated that the academic performance of African American students which is among the four lowest academic performing groups gave demands for an urgent action by the Los Angeles Unified School District Whereas The District recognizes the importance of culturally relevant and historically accurate education in improving academic performance and has implemented the Academic English Mastery Program AEMP in several of its schools and Whereas Black History Month is an opportunity for all students and stakeholders to enrich their educational experience and to deepen their understanding of the role of African Americans in the development of the United States and the world now therefore be it Resolved That the Governing Board of the Los Angeles Unified School District recognizes February as Black History Month and be it finally Resolved That the Superintendent will work with all schools of the District to recognize and celebrate Black History Month through culturally relevant activities and through indepth discussions of historically relevant topics TAB BOARD OF EDUCATION OF THE CITY OF LOS ANGELES Governing Board of the Los Angeles Unified School District REGULAR MEETING ORDER OF BUSINESS Including Closed Session Items South Beaudry Avenue Board Room am Tuesday January Pledge of Allegiance Roll Call of Members Public Comments The public can address the Board at the commencement of the meeting in the Board Room on any item that is described in this notice or other issues under the purview of the Board of Education At the conclusion of the closed session portion of the meeting announcements required regarding actions taken by the Board of Education will be made in the Board Room Open Session Items Board Member Resolutions for Initial Announcement Mr Kayser Creating Equitable Classrooms For Action at the February Regular Board Meeting Whereas The Los Angeles Unified School District LAUSD is the second largest school district in the nation with over students Whereas The LAUSD and the Governing Board are committed to creating the most equitable and productive learning environments for all students Whereas The LAUSD has over schools consisting of more than students currently eligible for Title I funding Whereas The LAUSD has historically funded schools with Title I populations of and above and Whereas The LAUSD only currently funds schools with student populations of or greater which defunded over schools for the school year now therefore be it Resolved That the Board of Education of the City of Los Angeles directs the Superintendent to approve the Title I distribution for any school with a population of or greater for the academic year and the subsequent years Bd of Ed Regular Board Meeting CS Order of Business am Mr Kayser Extending Transparency to All Schools For Action at the February Regular Board Meeting Whereas The Los Angeles Unified School District LAUSD is the second largest school district in the nation with over students Whereas The LAUSD and the Governing Board are committed to creating the most accountable accessible and transparent schools for all constituents Whereas The LAUSD in enacted a policy the LAUSD School Accountability Report Card first distributed in January which brought accountability access and transparency to all stakeholders in regards to the performance and environment of local LAUSD schools Whereas Vast partnerships were built in including the Office of Mayor Antonio Villaraigosa The California Community Foundation The United Way of Los Angeles and many more to support the implementation and distribution of the report card Whereas All LAUSD schools including all independent conversion and affiliated charters were participants in the initial roll out of LAUSD School Accountability Report Card program Whereas Since the inception of the LAUSD School Accountability Report Card program independent and conversion charter schools have not provided complete information and Whereas All parents students community members and stakeholders deserve to have the most complete information from their school of choice now therefore be it Resolved That the Board of Education directs the Superintendent to mandate that all LAUSD approved charters including independent conversion and affiliated submit all required information as their noncharter LAUSD peers have done since Resolved Further That the Board of Education of the City of Los Angeles directs the Superintendent to require the following language in each new charter petition and charter renewal petition A charter seeking approval renewal or material revision by the Board of Education will adhere to deliver the required information set forth by the LAUSD School Accountability Report Card by the same date as the local LAUSD noncharter school in their respective area Failure to do so will invoke the process of revocation and be it finally Resolved That this be incorporated into the Charter Authorizing Policy as referred to in Board Rule Bd of Ed Regular Board Meeting CS Order of on any actions taken Adjournment Please note that the Board of Education may consider at this meeting any item referred from a Board Meeting five calendar days prior to this meeting Education Code b The Board of Education may also refer any item on this Order of Business for the consideration of a committee or meeting of the Board of Education Requests for disability related modifications or accommodations shall be made hours prior to the meeting to the Board Secretariat in person or by calling Individuals wishing to speak at a Board meeting must sign up at the meeting There will be no sign ups in advance of the meeting Speakers must sign up prior to the item being acted upon by the Board Speakers should plan to arrive early as items with no speakers may be acted on at the beginning of the meeting If you or your organization is seeking to influence an agreement policy site selection or any other LAUSD decision registration may be required under the Districts Lobbying Disclosure Code Please visit wwwlausdnetethics to determine if you need to register or call Materials related to an item on this Order of Business distributed to the Board of Education are available for public inspection at the Security Desk on the first floor of the Administrative Headquarters and at httplaschoolboardorgRegBdCS Items circulated after the initial distribution of materials are available for inspection at the Security Desk Bd of Ed Regular Board Meeting CS Order of Business am
